Studies show that steaming vegetables in the microwave may be the best way to preserve most vitamins and minerals, especially vitamin C which rapidly decreases with other cooking methods.\nMoreover it doesn't tast oily as negligible amount of oil used in it\n2. Boiling\nBoiling is often considered a poor method for healthy cooking because nutrients are pulled from the food and into the cooking water. But boiling may not be as bad as we thought. Studies show that It retains vitamin C content better than frying, but not as well as steaming .\n3. Roasting\nRoasting vegetables exposes them to high heat for longer periods of time which can decrease vitamins, but not all nutrients are lost. The benefit of roasting is that it brings out the best flavors in vegetables making them much more delicious without adding unhealthy fat and sodium. If you find steamed vegetables bland, a few roasted vegetables mixed in can improve the flavor while still providing plenty of nutrients.\n4. If it smells bad or doesn't taste good, it's not good anymore.\nIf you are cooking a whole chicken for 2 hours, it's going to be very dry. So, no you won't get sick. Make some gravy", "You are fine. Let\u2019s go with the assumption the chicken broth was spoiled. There are two things you are worried about, living things like bacteria/molds and toxins generated by living things. The living things are killed by heat (especially a 1 hr cook, which by the way is way overcooked for any chicken). The majority of toxins produced by molds and bacteria are will not be broken down at cooking temps (high temps like 1000 deg will start breaking down those molecules), but you replaced the liquid with water and that would have diluted any toxins to a point where they are not deadly (and hopefully not symptom inducing).", "It sounds like you caught it right away and took appropriate steps. You should be fine.", "Was the broth spoiled or just old? If it smelled ok, it was fine, you could have used it.\nIf it was bad, with the change if water and another hour in the oven, it's probably safe, I don't know about the taste ir the smell, though.", "I wonder what your definition of \u201cold\u201d is for the broth. If it was sealed, but had an expired date, within 2\u20133 months you\u2019re unlikely to experience a problem, especially if you A) check to see if it smells off before using it and B) make sure you bring it to a boil and hold it there for 15\u201320 minutes.\nIf your broth was already opened, it\u2019s more worrisome. Then the details really matter, age down to the day, that sort of thing.\nYour general process was good, and something I might do myself, with one change. If I had any hint that the broth was bad, I\u2019d have rinsed the chicken carefully and washed the baking pan before adding the water.\nOr I might have changed gears and decided to poach the chicken, cooking it on the stove top in simmering water for at least 20 minutes. Water boils at 180, while typical cooking temperature for chicken is 165. I\u2019d want to make sure all surfaces of the meat were uniformly brought up to at least 180, so poaching it is good choice.\nBut if the broth smelled bad, all bets are off and I\u2019d have tossed it. Crust(healthiest pizza):\n-Butter or coconut oil, for greasing baking sheet\n-2 (3/4) cups cauliflower flour\n-1/4 cup almond flour\n-2 tablespoon tapioca flour\n-1 cup shredded buffalo mozzarella cheese\n-1(1/2) pastured eggs.\nPreheat the oven to 300 F. Grease a sheet of parchment paper with butter or coconut oil.\nPlace all the ingredients in a large bowl. Using your hands, mix well to combine.\nDivide the crust in half, forming two balls.\nPlace each ball onto the sheet of buttered(or coconut oil) parchment paper, and flatten with greased hands into an 8-inch round, making sure the crusts are even with no holes.\nBake for 15mins turning the crusts halfway through to be sure they\u2019re cooked evenly.\nRemove crusts and increase oven heat to 350 F.\nTop with desired toppings then return to oven and bake until edges begin to crisps.\nCauliflower Flour\n-3 medium size cauliflower stalks, leaves removed.\n-3/4 cups grated parmigiano-reggiano.\n-1(1/2) teaspoon garlic powder\n-1(1/2) teaspoon onion powder\n-Salt & pepper to taste.\nJuicer Method: Cut the cauliflower into medium-size chunks & pass through a juicer so that most of the liquid is removed from the pulp.\nDiscard juice & save pulp. Move to step 1 below.\nFood processor method: Cut the cauliflower, place in a food processor , and pulse until broken into tiny pieces(smaller than grain of rice).\nTransfer the cauliflower to a clean kitchen towel, and squeeze pulp, trying to extract as much water as possible.\nTransfer the pulp into a microwave safe bowl. Microwave in 15\u201320 second increments(your goal here is to start to dry out the cauliflower).\nStrain, to extract more water before moving onto step 1, below.\nPreheat the oven to 350 F\nSpread the pulp on a parchment lined sheet tray and transfer to the oven. Cook for 10\u201315mins, keeping a close eye on the cauliflower. You want the volume of the cauliflower pulp to reduce by half, but you do not want the cauliflower to burn. If it is browning too quickly, reduce heat to 300 F.\nOnce reduced, add the parmigiano, garlic, onion powder, salt and pepper.\nRemove from the oven & let cool to room temp.", "Use whole grain flour like oats, quinoa, wheat etc for the pizza base. "Food"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "May 13, 2019", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Andrew Stoner", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What is the signature dish of Acapulco?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "117", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "273": {"ans_list": ["Like this!", "I don\u2019t have any recipes that I can claim to be the original one, but the one that Joseph Mc Cray gives seems that it may be it, or something close to it. I hope it works out for you and tastes just like the original that you say you miss and remember so much.\nBut your question brings up another question\u2026\u2026\u2026\nCol Sanders developed his recipe and cooking techniques using a pressure cooker in the 1930s and began franchising his recipe, cooking techniques along with his name and image first to other mom and pop restaurants in the early \u201850s, the first being in Ogden, UT. From there the company began to grow and expand across the country and in those days he watched over the quality control of his product. There are stories about him going to a franchise, sampling the chicken, and if the product had been changed or not meet up to his standards, he would start yelling and cursing at the owner with the colorful language he was famous for, march back into the kitchen, gather up the pressure cookers that he had provided them with and remove them from the store.\nThat was the \u2018Original Kentucky Fried Chicken\u2019.\nIn 1964 he sold out the franchise for 2 million dollars and a lifetime salary, and it was shortly after that that he first started to publicly accuse the new corporate owners of changing his recipe and most noticeably complained about the change in his gravy. He was a stickler about all of the aspects of his meals but considered the gravy \"most sacred\". He referred to it (the changed recipe gravy) as \"sludge\" and \"wallpaper paste\".\nSo, what that means is that the original old KFC that you say you miss the tastes so much of, you would have to have eaten that particular chicken at one of the original Kentucky Fried Chicken franchises sometime during or prior to 1964.\nI am 72 years old and, as a young teen in growing up in Phoenix, Az, I don\u2019t recall ever having tasted any chicken from KFC, and if I had and I don\u2019t remember having done so, I can honestly tell you that there is no way I would be able to claim that I remember what the original tasted like. I have a feeling that there are not too many people around today that claim to remember and miss the original, and for those that actually did tastes and ate the original, they are pretty darn old today, my age or older.\nSo, my question to you is\u2026\u2026.\nWhat year did you eat KFC with the original recipe and where was it? If you ate any KFC after 1964, you never ate any of Col. Saunders \u2018Original\u2019 recipe chicken.\nOh, if any reader is interested in seeing exactly how Col Saunders made his chicken, view this clip of him doing just that along with Minnie Pear on Tennessee Ernie Ford\u2019s daytime tv show in the early 1960s using his original stovetop pressure cookers.", "Soak chicken In buttermilk overnight in fridge. Coat in flour fry once Canola or vegetable oil the oil is 350 degrees Fahrenheit. Turn a few times in oil. Temp two spots ensure 165 degrees. Excellent chicken.", "Try this:\n2 cups all purpose white flour\n2 tsp table salt\n1 1/2 tsp dried thyme\n1 1/2 tsp dried basil\n1 tsp dried oregano\n1 Tbsp celery salt\n1 Tbsp black pepper\n1 Tbsp dry mustard powder\n4 Tbsp paprika\n2 Tbsp garlic salt\n1 Tbsp ground ginger\nThis is the purported original recipe. The problem you will run into is pressure frying it. Those aren\u2019t made for home use anymore. You would have to purchase a large, commercial fryer restaurant unit to get a pressure fryer, and you are taking your life into your hands if you try with a regular pressure cooker. You might check eBay and see if you can find one. Presto used to make a home pressure fryer in the 50s and 60s, but stopped mostly because of dangers associated with it and Kentucky Fried came on line, making it cheaper and easier to purchase it yourself as opposed to the work of making chicken at home. I have an old unit that dates to about 1958, still in working condition, but it is sure a lot of work to bread the chicken and use the pressure fryer. Your meat will not brown if it is wet; use oil if desired, but your marinade must be dried off first.", "Once the meat lifts off the pan you can move with tongs.flip immediately also make sure the flame isn\u2019t to hot.", "It depends on the marinade. The problem with marinading is that you\u2019re adding ingredients that may burn at lower temperatures than meat, so you may never get a decent browning going on if you\u2019re cooking it in a pan.\nTo brown meat, you\u2019re looking to get the Maillard reaction\ngoing (140\u00b0C-165\u00b0C), so for some marinade ingredients this will be too high, so there\u2019s literally nothing you can do if you\u2019re cooking it in a pan. Over direct heat (barbecue, grill/broil, etc), you may get better results, because the meat is not in contact with the pan, and the marinade can\u2019t pool and burn in a big mess (as often happens with soy heavy marinades).\nJust accept that the chemical reaction is sometimes working against you, and you\u2019re going to sometimes get some charring when you marinade meat.\nI generally only cook marinated meat on my charcoal barbecue; stuff like mu ping, fajitas, and satay. If I do marinade something to be cooked inside, I\u2019ll squeeze it out, make sure there\u2019s as little marinade on it as possible, and add the marinade to the dish later. I\u2019ll generally use my wok on a really high heat if I do this.\nHere\u2019s some pork chops for C\u01a1m t\u1ea5m cooking on my grill. Even on a grill, you can see the marinade blackens a little, which is fine.", "First you have to rub all the marinade off.\nTake the meat out of the marinade and wipe it all off with your hands. Allow it to drain a couple minutes. Dry the meat with a paper towel. The purpose of the marinade is to add flavor but not to burn before the meat is cooked.\nIf you want to reincorporate the marinade, you can reduce it and add it to the finished product as a sauce.\nAlso, you should consider adding seasoning while cooking. Some marinades will have a lot of salt, and some are more about aromas. It really depends on what kind of marinade you are working with.\nKeep in mind, marinades with lots of sugar will tend to burn faster. Espagnole (brown), tomato. From each of these basic sauces, one can make a myriad of other sauces with the addition of additional ingredients.\nKnife skills", "Cooking isn\u2019t about recipes, it\u2019s about technique.\nThere are five basic cooking methods: roasting, frying, saut\u00e9ing, grilling and poaching. There are variations of each of those methods, but if you distill cooking techniques down to their essence, that\u2019s what you\u2019re gonna get.\nSo, rather than try to memorize a bunch of recipes, or try to determine which ones should serve as your foundation for cooking knowledge, learn those techniques. Once you have mastered each, you can cook anything.\nIf I know how to fry French fries, I can fry chicken nuggets. Grilling a steak requires the same technique as grilling a pork chop, a chicken breast or a piece of salmon. The same goes for roasting. If I can roast a rack of lamb, what\u2019s holding me back from roasting a loin of pork?\nSo, study technique. That\u2019s more important than a recipe book.", "Cooking rice and pasta correctly", "Hi Elynn\u2026 I call them base recipes\u2026 you can then build on them.\nMince and onions\u2026 becomes ragu, chilli, taco filling\u2026 then change the meat, becomes stew, chicken pie etc\nSoup, begin with leek and potato\u2026 or tomato, then add other ingredients.\nGrilling\u2026 well just marinade differently\nThats a start!", "I would say a good place to start is sauces\nThere are Five classic mother sauces, that in some variation becomes just about any sauce you\u2019d ever need.\nA great sauce can make a dish.\nBasically a mother sauce is the basic foundation sauce that when modified becomes a daughter or secondary sauce.\nyou'll need to first understand how a Roux works. A million websites discuss how to heat butter and saut\u00e9 flour to various colors of done, from blonde to dark.\nFirst is B\u00e9chamel sauce. Basically your roux of Flour , Butter, and add milk. It\u2019s a creamy white roux of a sauce. Some basic seasonings and you\u2019re there.\nSecond would be Velout\u00e9 sauce. It\u2019s a roux with a stock of some sort. Chicken, veal, fish, etc.\nThird are dark sauces from the next called Espagnole sauce. It\u2019s a roux based sauce with some dark stock like beef stock. So it starts like a Velout\u00e9 but you incorporate a bit of tomato paste.\nFourth is Hollandaise sauce. The famous eggs Benedict or asparagus sauce. It\u2019s one of the trickiest to master because sometimes it\u2019s over heated, it can break the egg in it can scramble, or it\u2019s greasy. But essentially it\u2019s made in a mixing bowl over a low steaming pan of water. You\u2019ll have to research it to learn but there are tons of good websites. One tip is take a kitchen cloth towel, wet it in cool water. Form it into a twisted \u2018rat tail\u2019 and form a ring on the counter that will create a nest to sit the bowl in. When you are working over steam and it\u2019s getting to hot, place the bowl on the towel ring and it will hold it and cool while your whisking.\nThe fifth sauce is Tomato Sauce. It is not a jar tomato sauce, but it\u2019s a base that could make the best sauce you\u2019ve ever had. here is the recipe to master ( Sauce Tomat 101\n)\none thing you\u2019ll learn is that some mother sauces combine to form third sauces. It can get complicated.\nso concentrate on one mother sauce and grow to a secondary sauce.\nan example would be making a b\u00e9chamel sauce and progressing into\u2026 sausage gravy for biscuits and gravy!\nit will take hours to learn a sauce, and your lifetime to master.\nfirst learn the roux.\nif you want to look at the starting points. Chef Escoffier consolidated the recipes of many great chefs into his hotel kitchen and in turn he adjusted the recipes of these chefs and produced some fantastic methods ( not recipes, because they are a foundation for knowledge not an instruction list).\nlearn his methods and you\u2019ll do great.\nas a side note\u2026 learn some culinary math. Scaling.. conversions.. etc. algebra is often used in recipe conversions. If a recipe calls for 8 cups of something and you only have 5\u2026 a little algebra helps you rapidly find the conversions of all other ingredients.", "One of the most foundational recipes is mirepoix. It is a combination of aromatic vegetables that forms a base for some of the most important dishes in Western cuisine.\n50% onion\n25% carrot\n25% celery\nGradually learn where to place potent ingredients like garlic and win the day. Next up: Learning the five \u201cMother Sauces\u201d required for most recipes.\nB\u00e9chamel\nVelout\u00e9\nEspagnole\nTomato sauce\nHollandaise\nIn the process, hone (pun intended) your knife skills. Remove the bacon and set aside. Add the onion to the pot and season with salt and pepper. Cook the onion until lightly caramelized and then add the garlic. Cook the veggies for a minute longer and toss in some tomato paste. Cook the tomato paste for a couple of minutes, until it begins to caramelize.\nNext, pour in the beans, cover them with chicken stock and add: the reserved bacon, a little apple cider vinegar, molasses, brown sugar, cayenne pepper, your favorite mustard, a bay leaf and Worcestershire sauce to the pot. Here\u2019s the ingredients:\nFast forward thirty years. Earlier that day (back when it was still relatively safe), I had been to the local wet market\u2014at Naga City in the Philippines\u2014and bought a few kilos of 10-count prawns (i.e., less than a dozen per pound)\u2014at about $10.00 per kilo! Nope. The capsaicin lies in the membrane and pith. So removing the seeds will neuter the sauce not a jot.\nSeeds are an irritant. They block nozzles, get stuck in teeth and add nothing. I\u2019d get rid of the darn things.", "I leave the seeds in. They make it more potent.", "if you are making hot sauce, seeding the peppers is really a matter of how hot you want the sauce\u2014 generally, it will be hotter with the seeds. That said, I\u2019m usually not a fanatic about seeding\u2014 I don\u2019t try to remove every last seed.\nIf I am making a hot sauce by fermentation, I usually don\u2019t seed the peppers before fermenting\u2014 that process will tend to mellow out the heat anyway. Once the peppers are fermented, I will do the cooking, adding of other ingredients, &c, then puree and strain. So the seeds contribute, but they don\u2019t overpower.\nIf I am simply cooking a hot sauce, I generally remove the seeds because in that process, they can add a lot of heat I would rather not have. But again, once I have cooked, I puree and strain so there aren\u2019t any seeds in the final product.\nIf I am making a fresh hot sauce, I definitely remove the seeds because they can add enough heat to overpower the sauce, and they also have an undesirable texture. Usually, this kind of sauce is more of a salsa\u2014 dices and cuts of ingredients\u2014 so the mouth texture is important, so I remove the seeds.\nSo basically, if you are making hot sauce, remove the seeds, but you don\u2019t need to worry about removing every last seed."], "topic_list": ["Hot Sauce", "Peppers", "Chili Peppers", "Spicy Food", "Spices", "Sauces", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [18, 1, 479], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Adam Kimbrough", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "question_title": "Is seeding peppers a must when making hot sauce?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "1,154", "name_list": ["Malcolm Minchin", "Iris Lemley", "Bill Blais"], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "117": {"ans_list": ["If you are using Bakewell Cream baking powder, the substitution is 1:1. You can use it the same way you would use any other double-acting baking powder.\nBakewell Cream is a different product; it is a substitute for cream of tartar. If you use it strictly to replace cream of tartar, the substitution is 1:1. Just use the same amount. If you are using it to replace baking powder, you must also use baking soda. What are the ratios?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "306", "name_list": ["Ilene Klinghoffer"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"]}, "652": {"ans_list": ["It's all about thickness and timing. First form the patty. The diameter isn't as important as the thickness. My experience has been 3/4\" to 1\" thick. Thinner if you want no pink, thicker if you laugh at gray meat. Form it gently, Don't compress anything, yet. It should still hold itself together, but if its in your and you wiggle it, it should take much to shake it apart. Now, before you does it on the grill, take your thumb and put a one to one and a half 1\" depression in the middle. This will help it cook evenly as well as control the pink. With no divot, the burger will pull itself inwards and become a bit bulbous. That leads to an unnecessarily pink middle. On to the flame!\nThe highest you can get the heat the better. If it is on a grill watch for flare ups! Put the burger down and let it sizzle until the grill, gives it back to you. In other words when you initially put it down the searing will stick it to the pan . DO NOT PANIC. After a few more minutes the carmelization part of the cooking has peaked when will soon head to burning. Flip it over, same process. It won't take as long this time so be wary. One final tip, don't use the spatula to squeeze out the juices. Lots of people do this, and unless they want a dry burger,it's a crime!\nTime on each side will vary from cooking source to cooking source. But it's usually about 7 mins then flip 6 mins and take of the grill. Put them on a player and cover in foil for 10 mins to allow the juices to re-acquaint themselves win their meat-home.", "I like my burgers cooked to medium, or a little more.\nHamburger isn\u2019t steak. If you\u2019re using the right beef, 80/20 ground chuck, dryness shouldn\u2019t be an issue, unless you\u2019re really well done-ing it. Seriously, get 80/20 ground beef. That\u2019s 80% lean to fat. 20% fat is a significant amount, more than a steak. You don\u2019t need your burger to be rare or mid rare and still be juicy.\nTechnique plays a big part in cooking a burger properly. Start with a 7oz patty. They cook up nicely. I suggest you form them in a ring too. A burger ring helps you to make perfectly proportioned patties, which cook evenly.\nOnce you\u2019ve got your patties, drop them on the grill and season them generously with salt and pepper, about 1/4 tsp of salt and 1/8 tsp of pepper. Now wait about 2 minutes. With your spatula, pick up the burger and give it a quarter turn, put it back on the grill and leave it alone. Wait another 2 minutes.\nNow pick up the burger and flip it over. Don\u2019t touch it, let it cook for three minutes. Again, pick it up, quarter turn, put it down and wait three more minutes.\nSeason it again with salt and pepper, pull it off of the grill and enjoy. It should be a perfect medium. If you want less red in the center, just add a minute to each step of the cooking process.\nEasy peasy.", "I\u2019m going to respond to this question once and only once because more of the same type of questions will flood my Inbox. Zhengzhou Fusmar Machinery is a professional pellet making machine\nmanufacturer. This article will tell us how to design a perfect formula, and how to allocate the proportion of each ingredient according to nutritional requirements.\nAccording to the characteristics of the feed, the common feed for broilers can divide into energy feed, protein feed, vitamin feed, mineral feed, and special additives feed. Feed pellet machine\nis dispensable equipment to make animal feed pellets.\nEnergy Feed\n1. corn: It is one of the most important energy feeds for broilers. Rich in starch and crude fat. When formulating the diet, the amount of corn generally accounts for 40% to 70% of the diet.\n2. broken rice: It is the broken grain rice screened in rice processing. The starch content is high, the crude fiber content is low, and it is easy to digest. Its nutritional value is similar to that of corn, and the dosage is about 30% to 50% of the diet.\n3. wheat: High nutritional value, energy content close to corn, more protein content, amino acid than other cereals, vitamin B is also very rich, palatability is good, the amount of easier to stick chicken mouth and affect feeding. It can generally account for 10% to 25% of the diet.\n4. barley: It contains 15% to 20% of the skin, the energy is about 75% of the corn, the crude fiber content is 3 times higher than the corn can account for 10% to 15% of the diet.\n5. rice bran: It is a by-product of rice processing, mainly composed of skin and rice embryo. Its crude fat, crude protein, and crude fiber content are higher than rice, rich in vitamin B, often used as auxiliary materials, the amount should not be too much, generally accounting for 8% to 10% of the diet.\n6. wheat bran: It is a by-product of wheat processing. It contains crude protein, vitamin B, and manganese, etc., has a laxative effect, the dosage should not be too large, the general broiler dosage does not exceed 8%.\nProtein Feed\nProtein feed can divide into plant protein feed and animal protein feed. Plant protein feeds such as bean cake, peanut cake, cottonseed cake, rapeseed cake, and so on. Animal protein feed such as fish meal, blood meal, meat and bone meal, feather meal, silkworm cocoon, and other processing by-products.\n1. bean cake: A by-product of soybean oil processing from soybean oil. Bean cake contains more than 40% protein, ranking first in plant protein feed, and is rich in lysine, with high nutritional value, generally accounting for 15% to 20% of the diet.\n2. cottonseed cake: its protein content is second only to the bean cake, up to 30% to 35%, but it should not be used simply as a dietary plant protein feed, because of the lack of lysine. The amount can not exceed 10% of the diet, because the cottonseed cake contains gossypol, too much feeding can cause poisoning.\n3. rapeseed cake: 25% to 30% crude protein, low lysine content, higher methionine content than bean cake, but the rapeseed cake contains mustard enzyme. Which can promote the decomposition of sinapinic acid into toxic substances, so the amount of feed should not be too much, generally less than 5%.\n4. Fish meal: It has high nutritional value and comprehensive amino acid content. The crude protein content of high-quality fishmeal is higher than 60%, the salt content is less than 2%, and the water content is below 12%. Fish meal can generally be used in an amount of 5% to 12% of the diet.\n5. Blood powder: It is a brown powder feed made by cooking, pressing and drying the blood of animals. The crude protein content is as high as 70%-80%, rich in lysine, but lacks methionine, cystine and isoleucine, and has low solubility. It is not easy to digest, and has poor palatability. It should be mixed with other protein feeds. Not more than 3% of the diet is appropriate.\nGreen Feed\nDue to the high moisture content of fresh green and green feed, the dosage should not be too large, so as to avoid causing squatting and affecting fattening of broilers. Green leaves, grass leaves, etc. are dried and pulverized to become high-quality grass powder or leaf powder, such as alfalfa powder, eucalyptus leaf powder, etc. are good vitamin supplement feeds, generally accounting for 2% to 5% of the diet.\nMineral Feed\nWhen the mineral content in natural feed is insufficient, or when some elements are unbalanced, attention should be paid to replenishing the mineral feed in the diet, especially for high-yield broiler breeders and broilers with fast-growing growth. Should pay attention to supplement. The commonly used mineral feeds are mainly the following:\n1. stone powder: Calcium content is 35% to 38%. The dosage generally accounts for 1% to 3% of the diet, and the broiler breeder can reach 5%.\n2. shell powder: Containing about 38% of calcium, often used as feed for calcium supplementation. It usually accounts for 1% to 3% of the diet, and up to 5% of the broiler breeders during the laying period.\n3. salt: In the preparation of the diet according to the actual salt content in the feed, and then consider the amount of salt added to avoid excessive or insufficient salt. The general dosage does not exceed 0.38% of the diet.\nAdditive Feed\nIn order to promote the normal growth of broilers, prevent the disease, increase the yield and economic benefits. In modern broiler breeding, the use of additives such as amino acids, vitamins, trace elements, antibiotics, antioxidants, antifungal agents. The types and dosages to add should determine according to actual needs. For example, in most feed diets, vitamins and trace elements are incomplete. It should note that appropriate proportions of multivitamins and trace element additives should add, generally accounting for 0.05% to 0% of the diet. It is often rainy and humid in summer, often with anti-fungal agents and antioxidants. Add the additive to the feed and mix well and mix well. Before the broiler is marketed, the feed should not contain any drugs.\nZhengzhou Fusmar Machinery provides complete feed pellet prodcution line\nfor chicken feed, and also we will provide perfect feed formula to customer for reference."], "topic_list": ["Broiling", "Broiler Chicken", "Poultry (food)", "Raising Chickens", "Chickens", "Perfection", "Chicken (food)", "Design", "Cooking", "Food"], The results will be somewhat different\nA glaze made only with egg whites will be clear and crisp, giving a shiny finish and darker color to breads and pastries. Egg white glazes are often used to adhere things like seeds, large crystal sugar, and other decorative and flavorful toppings. Egg yolks will contribute more of a warm, golden color, and won't be quite as crisp, since they contain more fat and less protein than the whites.", "The pastry will be less fattening. Although, they might sometimes be consumed at restaurants.\nPakistani cusine is spicier while Afghan is mild and closer to Iran.\nAfghan cuisine is based mainly on proper meal foods and bread. Both of which are closer to Iran yet still very unique.\nSimillarities with Iran:\nThere are many more foods that are eaten around cultural events like Samanak in Nowruz.\nBreads are extremely popular in both countries\u2019 cuisine and a staple. There are many different types of bread and overall both countries share less then they have in common but there are many that are shared. This is due to how desserts sometimes just may have always been native to a place but most of the time it was developed at an exact time and place. During the Safavids, Afghanistan was under a lot of influence and adopted many desserts to the point they became native(some chefs may have been Afghan and some foods inspired by Afghan cuisine but it still would be Safavid). While, Mughal desserts are not too unpopular and some like Gulab Jamun, very popular but they are considered from Pakistan and India. while desserts with Iran are considered native.\nIran and Afghanistan have more similar drinks. My husband no longer consumes samples at Trader Joe\u2019s.", "Do Olive Garden cooks wear gloves when handling food?\nOlive Garden cooks and food prep workers all wear gloves when handling food. They wear hair nets and beard nets as well. Cooks are constantly touching food such as raw chicken, shrimp, beef, fish, and vegetables. The first thing that anyone has to do when handling or prepping food is to thoroughly wash their hands and put on gloves. When you cook meat two things will happen (well, more than two...).\nOne is that it will lose moisture. The longer you cook it the more moisture (i.e. water) you will lose, and there's no getting it back.\nThe second thing that happens is that the connective tissues break down to collagen, which is what you are perceiving as being moist and tender when you cook it for a long time. If it is cooked but not to the point where these connective tissues break down then it is likely a second cook will make it more tender. It will also continue to dry out the meat.\nAfter your second cook, be sure to let it rest. I would also suggest slicing it thinly against the grain after cooking as this will make it easier to chew, further helping with the mouthfeel.\nFinally, be aware that the amount of time the meat stays between 40\u00b0F-140\u00b0F the more risk there is of food poisoning. Cooking a second time does not eliminate any toxins produced by the bacteria up to that point (it will only kill bacteria), so be sure to eat it right away as letting it cool and reheating it again introduces more risk. Guidelines say meat should be kept for only one hour between 90\u00b0-140\u00b0"], "topic_list": ["Brisket", "Corned Beef", "Ground Beef", "Cooking Techniques", "Learning to Cook", "Beef", "Meat", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [15, 34, 4, 28], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Gaurav More", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 1, 0], "question_title": "Can a beef brisket be tenderized by cooking a second time?", "respond_collected": 4, "no_of_view": "181", "name_list": ["Tarun Naskar", "John M. These are dishes rather than meals.\nFor me, it's any pastry or bread baked from scratch.\nCarmelized onions. Don't let people tell you it can be done in 20 or 45 minutes. More like, hours. I'm a home cook with no formal training. It takes time to slice up a lot of onions, and you must cook them slowly. You have to keep an eye on them and make sure the onions brown evenly. But the result is delicious. Using a mandoline for slicing the onions saves time and it's better for having evenly cut pieces.\nDark roux for a Louisiana dish. I'm not a native, but it takes me time to get the sauce brown and pay attention so it doesn't burn. I read one version where someone browned flour in the oven first. I haven't tried it yet.\nGazpacho from scratch. For a tomato soup, I think it's much better to remove the seeds. That takes a little longer.\nMashed potatoes. And, those that are not hungry right away, maybe looking for something later on, say mid morning. So, make some hard boiled eggs, get in the habit of having an egg. Or two. Hard boiled reduces the use of frying, or poaching. It's quick, and easy. Also, make a batch of pancakes, they can always be reheated in a pinch.\nBut, first that long day of cooking, why not make homemade stew with potatoes, carrots, onions, celery,.spices Leftovers can be frozen for a quick late night hungry pangs.\nOr make chicken catchatoire. The meat will fall off the bones. And you can serve it along with pasta on the side, like zitti. And have fresh garlic bread, to dip into the juices of your meal.", "Chilli con carne takes a while to cook. Any type of broth for raven is a good choice. Broth usually takes 3\u20135 hours. Pulled pork takes a long time", "Lasagna, pot roast, short ribs, anything smoked if you have a smoker, brisket, chicken pot pie, dozens of cookies, pies, roast chicken. I guess most of that stuff is meat that cooks for a long time. Shows you where my head\u2019s at.", "Smoked meats like brisket, pork shoulder, ribs, chicken. Dehydrated foods like jerky. Dried beans, bread, pies, cakes, roasts.", "Cassoulet.\nConfit lamb shanks.\nPot au feu.\nA real, good tomato sauce.\nRecipes for all these can easily be found online.", "Make some homemade pizza:\nDough\n6 tablespoons warm water (may need up to 1 or 2 tablespoons more water)\n2 tablespoons white wine\n3/4 teaspoon active dry yeast\n1/2 teaspoon honey\n1 teaspoon salt\n1 tablespoon olive oil\n1 1/2 cups flour\nAssembly\nCornmeal for sprinkling\nFlour for dusting counter\n1/2 pound torn-up buffalo mozzarella\nFew leaves of torn-up basil\nWhatever toppings you want\nWhisk wine, water and yeast in a medium bowl until yeast has dissolved. Add honey, salt and olive oil and whisk. Add flour and no matter how dry it looks, work it with a spoon and your fingers until it comes together as a dough. Add more water one tablespoon at a time if you need, but in my experience, this is almost never necessary.\nSprinkle some flour on the counter and knead the dough for a minute or two.\nIf you are finding this step difficult, one of the best tricks I picked up from my bread-making class is to simply pause. Leave the dough in a lightly-floured spot, put the empty bowl upside-down on top of it and come back in 2 to 5 minutes, at which point you will find the dough a lot more lovable.\nLightly oil a bowl (a spritz of cooking spray perfectly does the trick) - dump the dough in, turn it over so all sides are coated, cover it in plastic wrap and leave it undisturbed for an hour or two, until it has doubled in size.\n[Easiest way to tell if a dough has risen enough? Dip two fingers in flour, press them into the dough, and if the impression stays, it's good to go. If it pops back, let it go until it doesn't.]\nPreheat your oven to its highest temperature. If you have a pizza stone, put it in the oven for at least 15 minutes to warm up beforeputting the pizza on it.\nMeanwhile, make some sauce [recipe below].\nOnce the dough has doubled, turn it out onto a floured counter and gently deflate the dough with the palm of your hands. Form it into a ball and let it rest on a floured spot with either plastic wrap over it (sprinkle the top of the dough with flour so it doesn\u2019t stick) or an upended bowl. In 15 minutes, it is ready to roll out. Do so on the floured counter until pretty darn thin.\nPlace parchment paper on cake lifter and sprinkle with cornmeal, and build pizza on there. Once the dough is spread out to desired size, spread a thin layer of oil on the bread. Sprinkle some cheese on top of the oil. (The oil and cheese help prevent the bread from getting soggy from the sauce). Add the desired amount of sauce and then some extra cheese. Add desired toppings.\nSprinkle the pizza stone with cornmeal. If you don't have a pizza stone, sprinkle a baking pan with cornmeal. Open door and slide the pizza along with the parchment paper onto the stone, or put the pizza and parchment paper in the oven on a baking pan. [3/4 of the way through baking, remove the paper. This will allow the crust to crisp up and brown.]\nBake for about 10 minutes, checking at 7. Slice and serve.\nHere are some tomato sauce recipes:\nModerately Easy Tomato Sauce\n4 roma tomatoes\n1 to 2 tablespoons olive oil\n2 cloves of garlic, minced\nPinch of red pepper flakes\nSplash of white wine\n1/2 teaspoon sugar\n3/4 teaspoon salt\nBring medium pot of water to a boil. Poach the tomatoes for one minute only, and then drain them. As soon as they are cooled off enough that you can touch them, peel them. The peels should come right off. If they don\u2019t, make a slit in the skins. This always does the trick.\nDrain and dry the pot. Put it back on the burner over medium heat. Pour in olive oil and let it heat completely before adding the garlic and stirring it for a minute with a wooden spoon. Add the red pepper flakes and stir it for anther minute. You do not want the garlic to brown. Put the peeled tomatoes in the pot, along with the wine, sugar and salt. Break the tomatoes up with your spoon.\nLet the sauce simmer for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes break down. Carefully taste without burning your tongue and adjust seasonings, if necessary.\nMakes enough for one small/medium pizza.\nBasic, Awesome Tomato Sauce\n1 tablespoon butter\n2 large shallots, finely chopped\n1/2 to 1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes\n1 teaspoon salt\nA couple glugs red wine\n1 28-ounce can whole tomatoes\n1 15-ounce can pureed tomatoes\nMelt butter in saucepan over medium-high heat until foam subsides. Add shallots, red pepper flakes and salt, sauteing them together for a few minutes, until the shallots are translucent and beginning to color. Add the red wine, letting it sizzle and cook down slightly, then the whole and pureed tomatoes. Breaking the whole tomatoes up with a wooden spoon, let the sauce simmer for a few minutes. (No need to cook it down very much, as the extra liquid will be helpful to cook the pasta, and it will finish cooking in the oven.) Season to taste.\nMakes approximately 5 cups of sauce\nBasic Marinara Sauce\nMakes about 4 Cups\n- 1 can (28 ounces) crushed tomatoes\n- 5 cloves garlic, minced\n- 2-3 Tablespoons fresh basil, minced\n- 1 Teaspoon dried oregano\n- 1/2 Lemon, juice only\n- Salt and pepper to taste\nYou can cook this sauce if you want to make it a bit thicker, but honestly, I just stick all the ingredients in a blender and blend them up. I like the fresh, light flavors. If you cook them too much they get thick and like a pasta sauce.\nOr make some Chicken Pot Pie Crumble -\nCHICKEN:\n1 1/2 Lbs chicken\n1 tablespoon butter\n1 tablespoon oil\nCrumble Topping:\n2 c. flour\n2 tsp baking powder\n3/4 tsp salt\n1/2 tsp pepper\n1/8 tsp cayenne pepper\n6 Tbsp unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes and chilled\n3/4 c. Parmesan cheese\n1 c. heavy cream\nFILLING:\n1 tablespoon oil\n1 onion , chopped fine (about 1 cup)\n3-4 carrots, diced (about 1 cup)\n1/2 cup celery, chopped fine\n3/4 cup frozen peas\nsalt and pepper (to taste)\n4 tablespoons (1/2 stick) unsalted butter\n1/2 cup flour\n1 cup milk\n3 cups chicken broth\nFOR THE CHICKEN: Stab chicken with a fork several times or a meat tenderizer. Dice chicken into small bite size pieces. Spread chicken out and generously sprinkle with salt, pepper and flour. Melt 1 tablespoon of butter and 1 tablespoon of oil in Dutch oven over medium heat. Saute chicken until it is just done. Transfer cooked chicken to large bowl. Do not wash Dutch oven.\nFOR THE TOPPING: preheat oven to 450 F. Combine flour, baking powder, salt, pepper, and cayenne in large bowl. Sprinkle butter pieces over top of flour. Using fingers, rub butter into flour mixture until it resembles coarse cornmeal. Stir in Parmesan. Add cream and stir until just combined. Crumble mixture into irregularly shaped pieces onto a baking sheet. Bake at 450-degrees until fragrant and starting to brown (10-13 minutes). Set aside.\nFOR THE FILLING: Heat 1 tablespoon oil in now-empty Dutch oven over medium heat. Add onion, carrots, celery, salt and pepper. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally, until just tender. Add in frozen peas and heat up for a few minutes. Transfer cooked vegetables to bowl with cooked chicken; set aside.\nHeat butter in empty Dutch oven over medium heat. When foaming subsides, stir in flour and cook 1 minute. Slowly whisk in chicken broth and milk. Bring to simmer and stir until sauce thickens, about 1 minute. Add salt and pepper to taste. Remove from heat and stir chicken-vegetable mixture into sauce.\nPour mixture into 9x13 pan (or if you have small individual-sized oven-safe dishes, you can use those). Scatter crumble topping evenly over filling. Bake on rimmed baking at 400-degrees sheet until filling is bubbling and topping is well browned (about 12-15 minutes). Serve hot and enjoy!", "Stews or stir-frys. Gotto go check the fridge now because I'm getting hungry@", "Beef Bone Broth \u2014 buy 4 pounds of beef marrow bones (check your local Asian grocery store for a good selection if you can\u2019t find any at your chain grocery store). Roast the bones in a 400 degree F oven for about 20 minutes. Place them in a deep stock pot and sprinkle a little vinegar on them, then add 16 to 20 cups of water, plus some rough chopped onions, celery and a bay leaf or two.\nIf you like the flavor of anise, add 2 whole anise stars or some anise powder and a slice of ginger or a little ginger powder.\nHeat on high heat until boiling then cover with a lid and simmer on very low heat for at least 10 hours. When cool enough to handle, pour the broth through a strainer to remove all the bits and pieces.\nUse this bone broth in any recipe calling for beef broth. Store in covered containers in the refrigerator for up to a week, or freeze.\nI like to make pho with it. While you are at your Asian grocery store, buy rice noodles, Thai basil, mint leaves, limes, scallions, flank steak and Asian beef meatballs (found in the frozen foods section). But keep in mind that as others have said, cake flour is a low-protein flour, so if you can find the protein content of the maida, that would be helpful.\nAs to your initial suggestion that cake flour is cornstarch and all purpose flour, while that\u2019s not exactly true, it is a substitute that many people use when they don\u2019t have cake flour. Try it out and see what happens. The key is to be very gentle in handling and mixing your ingredients. Good luck.", "There\u2019s no cornstarch in cake flour. It\u2019s milled more finely from young wheat and often bleached to weaken gluten even further.", "No, cake flour is NOT plain flour mixed with cornstarch (at least in the US). Cake flour is usually bleached and has a lower protein content than all purpose flour or pastry flour. The low protein content lends to a shorter delicate crumb desirable in cakes.\nIf you don\u2019t have cake flour on hand, then mixing all purpose flour with cornstarch will work as a substitute, so I think that\u2019s where you got that idea.\nI had no idea what atta and maida flours were so I had to look them up. Apparently they are flours used in India, which is probably where you are. Atta flour is higher in protein, so it would be equivalent to US bread flour. Maida flour is closer to cake flour. So if you need cake flour, you would use the Maida.", "no it is a low protein flour ,cake flour consists of 7-8% of protein content while general all purpose flour consists of 11-12% of protein content,and then bread flour 14+%,the protein makes the product chewy ,some make a substitute flour for cakes by adding cornstarch to AP flour.ATTA is whole grain and wont make cake,,,I believe \u201cMAIDA \u201c will be close to cake flour.\nRead more: Difference Between All Purpose Flour and Cake Flour | Difference Between Difference Between All Purpose Flour and Cake Flour", "I\u2019m not familiar with those two brands, of flour. England", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What is a good substitute for glutathione in a food prep spray?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "167", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "628": {"ans_list": ["You can make great tasting bread by using a preferment made with a very small amount or commercial yeast added to flour and water and allowed to sit overnight at room temperature in a covered bowl. I used to make sourdough bread, but keeping my starter well fed and then activating it after taking it out of the fridge, got to be a pain.", "Well, if your starter doesn\u2019t become airy and bubbly and gain in volume in a matter of one week or less, then you probably need to start over. In my experience, it is best to use half whole wheat flour and half bread flour to feed your starter. I put about 1 pound of each into a big container with a tight fitting lid and shake it up really well. Then I put a glass or heavy plastic container on a kitchen scale and measure 200 grams of flour mixture into it. Next, I pour the exact same amount of clean, purified water (not tap water as it has chemicals and chlorine in it which kill your yeast and other bacteria essential for a healthy starter), 200 grams, and stir it up really well. Next I take the container\u2019s lid and rest it over the container without sealing it so that some air can circulate. Then I cover the whole thing with a lightweight dish towel, which will keep bugs from finding your starter and provide some darkness/privacy for the starter to get busy. I check on it after two days to see if it is bubbly. If not, wait another day, checking every 24 hours. When it is bubbly and raised, it is ready to be fed and/or used in a bread recipe. I feed my starter daily with 100 grams of water, 100 grams of flour mix, and 30 grams of starter. I throw away the old starter. If I am going to bake, then the DAY BEFORE I will make 400+ grams of starter by taking 210 grams of flour, 210 grams of water, and 30 grams of starter, mixing well , covering and, the next day I have enough starter for making four big loaves of bread. I hope this helps. Good luck."], "topic_list": ["Sourdough", "Yeast (baking)", "Bread Baking", "Fermentation", "Yeast", "Bread", "Baking", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [35, 50], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Dex Jackson", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "When do you give up on a sourdough starter (yeast, cooking, baking, pastries, breads, cakes, batter, fermentation)?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "413", "name_list": ["Jim Watkins", "Lynn Marinaro"], "date_list": ["Apr 19, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "307": {"ans_list": ["No, however soaking will reduce salt and nitrite/ nitrate content. Few doors were ever locked back in those times. To our dismay, no one was home. In a house with two parents and seven of us kids, somebody must be around somewhere. Nope.\nJoe and I were starving and just had to eat something. We searched the cabinets, pantry and fridge. We found almost empty boxes of Apple Jacks and Shredded Wheat cereals, peanut butter and jam plus leftover veggies in the refrigerator; but they were stuff like spinach and beets. Margarine does not fry nor cook like butter as they have different chemical properties. You can use the margarine, but it will not taste the same, have the same texture for the beignet, or probably rise like the butter would. Good luck though.", "When I was a kid, back in the 50s/60s, we used to see ads on TV for Imperial Margarine in which they always said \u201cIt tastes and spreads like the 70 cent spread.\u201d I asked my mom what they meant by that. She explained that Imperial is a margarine, not butter. Back in the 1930s, when margarine became popular, the dairy industry raised a big fight when margarines compared themselves to butter, or called themselves \u2018corn oil butter\u2019 or \u2018vegetable butter\u2019 or whatever.\nIn the state of Wisconsin, which has a very big and powerful dairy industry, they even passed laws against artificial coloring in margarine, so their margarine came in white only! Like Crisco. A package of margarine came with a little yellow coloring packet that you mixed in yourself!\nSo Imperial didn\u2019t even want to use the word \u2018butter\u2019 in their advertising. They compared their margarine to the \u201970 cent spread\u2019. Which was butter. (This was a long time ago! 8^) ).\nApparently the laws have changed. Blue Bonnet is not butter at all, it\u2019s margarine. Would it take the place of butter in a recipe? Well, yes. For the recipe to work requires only -fat-. You could use coconut oil or corn oil or even lard. Your beignets might taste a little different or have a slightly different texture, but the recipe will work great. Most people wouldn\u2019t notice the difference. (I mean YOU would because you made them and you know what\u2019s in them, but those you feed them to probably wouldn\u2019t). (Frankly, I think they\u2019d probably taste BETTER with lard!)\nAnyway, try it and see how it works!"], "topic_list": ["Unsalted Butter", "Baking Recipes", "Butter", "Cooking Tips and Hacks", "Baking", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [13, 59], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Karla Catalan", "upvote_list": [0, 1], "question_title": "Can I use blue bonnet butter for a beignet recipe when it asks for unsalted butter?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "644", "name_list": ["Wayne Wyche", "Len Freedman"], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"]}, "149": {"ans_list": ["Stacey, I don\u2019t know Akshay but according to his CV he studied at \u201dFordham University Gabelli School of Business in 2012\u2033, and became exec chef of restaurant Janoon five years after that (the restaurant getting one star in the 2017 Michelin guide with him in charge of the kitchen). I bake all my meats and potatoes when I want baked, then I make a veggie when we are ready to eat. That way you don't have a bunch of dishes.", "Clean up as you go", "Use premade ingredients as much as possible. For example, use spaghetti sauce in a jar instead of making it from scratch.\nMake everything in a single pot. For example, if making spaghetti, don\u2019t warm the sauce in a separate pan, just pour it over the just-drained, cooked spaghetti and stir. Serve it in the same pot.\nAvoid use of oil or fats. That makes dishes that require detergent to clean. Without oils or fats, dishes can often be rinsed clean.\nDon\u2019t measure things that don\u2019t actually require precision. Develop a feel for how much is appropriate, and keep the measuring spoons and cups clean. For example, when making oatmeal, if it comes out too thick, then add more water or milk. If it\u2019s too runny, that\u2019s OK, just call it \u201coatmeal soup\u201d and enjoy.\nUse the microwave oven and sous vide preparation as much as possible. Those have timers, so burning food is less likely than on a stove top. And temperatures never approach burning temps, in the case of sous vide.", "Clean as you go m. Wash your hands", "I clean as I go so not to have a big mess", "If you have a dishwasher, make sure any clean load has been emptied.\n\u201cMise en place\u201d is a French term meaning \u2018everything in its place\u2019. Starting with the vegetables/aromatics, wash and chop/mince, then place each one in an appropriate sized bowl/plate. Move on to the meats/seafood and prep those. Throw all scraps into the trash bin or a \u201ctrash bowl\u201d immediately. Have all other ingredients, such as cooking oils, spices/herbs and salt/pepper readily accessible.\nFill the sink halfway with hot water. Whip out your pots and pans and start cooking. As you use each ingredient, place the empty plate or bowl into the sink. Plate your meal and serve. Toss all cooking utensils into the sink, except the knives \u2014 leave those on the cutting board.\nWhen done eating, you can fish the plates, bowls and cooking utensils out of the sink and place those in the dishwasher (or wash and rinse them if you don\u2019t have a dishwasher, along with the dinner glasses and plates). Wipe the grease out of pots and pans using paper towels, then scrub the pots and pans in a sinkful of hot soapy water, rinse and allow to drip dry on a rack. Lastly, wash your knives with hot, soapy water, then the cutting boards. Any hard plastic cutting boards can also go into the dishwasher. Wooden and non-dishwasher safe cutting boards need to be washed, and then disinfected using a mild bleach solution, followed by a thorough rinsing and drying.\nWhen you have caught your breath, scrub the stove and wipe down the counters.\nOf course, the BEST method for not making a huge mess with dinner, is to order a nice takeout meal and use paper plates and plastic utensils!\nSupport your local restaurants if you are able, during this pandemic.", "Run a sink of hot soapy water, as you finish with a dish or utensil drop it into the water.\nAs you're prepping and cooking you'll need to wash your hands, every time you need to wash your hands wash what's in the sink. Every time you have a few minutes lag time, like waiting for water to boil, or waiting for a pan to heat up etc. wash some more dishes.\nWhen your done cooking, but before you eat, wipe down your counters, cutting board and stove. It only takes a minute.\nWhen your done eating you'll still have a bit of a mess but it will be very manageable.", "Plan ahead, work carefully and thoughtfully. Do as much initial prep as possible, for example, measuring out required amounts of rice or pasta, chopping onions, garlic, veggies and meats ahead of cooking, and putting each ingredient into its own bowl or container, so that everything is to hand when you need it.\nUse a kitchen knife as required, then wip and replace it in its block - less clutter that way.\nPlan the meal preparation in phases so that you use a minimum of implements at any one time; also use the minimum number of pots and pans.\nAfter a while it becomes second nature and makes life easier. Don\u2019t let anybody who doesn\u2019t work tidily loose in your kitchen!", "The single best thing to do is clean as you go and try to keep everything contained to as small of an area as possible. Get all of your ingredients together, weighed and measure before you start, then clean up after each stage of cooking whatever it is you're cooking.", "What is the best advice for not making a huge mess with dinner prep and cooking?\nI try to have all ingredients to hand so that preparation is a seamless effort. Vegetable peels go into a bucket immediately, for the compost heap. Packaging into the dirt box etc\nOnce the cooking process has started I clean whatever utensils I\u2019ve already finished with. I also tend to keep a sink of hot soapy water going to soak things in, until I can wash them properly. What words should I be looking for?\nGo to Kitchn\nwhere you will find bazillions of shootout comparisons of cooking methods favored by various foodies.", "You can go all technical with grading and the like but that is too much like work for me. I would go with a strip steak, also called a New York strip steak. It smells like the steak I remember having at home growing up and they are very tasty. It is the flavor I want. They often come with a layer of fat on one side. I like to cut that off and use some of it to \u201cgrease\u201d the pan by putting it in the pan while it heats. The fat will sizzle and you can move it around the pan to spread the fat around.\nWhen you are ready to cook the steak take it out of the fridge and let it sit for about an hour before cooking. This is important, because you have a different way of grading (judging the quality) than Canada, the US or Japan.\nHere\u2019s the comparison charts for 3 of the standards. Canada\u2019s is similar to the US, except instead of words, we call it A, AA and AAA.\nSo here\u2019s MY TOP FOUR CRITERIA where you should be starting with how to look for a steak.\nFIRST - The HIGHER the grade, the more expensive.\nJudging from your grading scale, I would say MS6 to MS9 would be restaurant quality meat, and most supermarkets would be more rated at MS2 to MS5. For the best flavor, you go with the higher grade as there would be more fat in the steak. I\u2019ll explain why when I explain MARBLING below.\n(From meatnbone[1])\nSECOND - MARBLING fat in the meat\nThe more marbled the meat, the higher the quality. There\u2019s only one real exception, the Filet Mignon, but I\u2019ll explain that later.\nHere\u2019s how it\u2019s judges in Australia:\n(From Wagyu International[2])\nSee how the little fat lines get into the meat at each of these 9 levels of steaks? That\u2019s the difference that you\u2019re looking for, as fat in the beef improves the tenderness and imparts a buttery taste as it gets higher.\nTHIRD - THE CUT of the Beef\nDepending on what part of the cow the steak is cut from, the most tender it can get with the most flavor. I won\u2019t explain those areas for now as it can get to be confusing, and won\u2019t make any difference really. There\u2019s only a few that I would be recommending.\n(From Otto Grills[3])\nHere\u2019s what I prefer from top to bottom of the most common cuts.\nFilet Mignon - This is considered to be by many as the top of the top. It\u2019s super expensive as this baseball sized piece of meat is all you can get from an ENTIRE cow. It\u2019s personally not my favorite cut, as I find it not as tasty as it\u2019s from the tenderloin, the least flavorful part of the cow, but there\u2019s plenty here who would worship this if they could.\nCooking a Filet needs a bit of finesse, and even I don\u2019t like to cook it myself. Supermarkets tend not to offer this, but it\u2019s pretty easy to get one directly from a butcher. There\u2019s not as much fat and the meat itself is supremely tender on it\u2019s own despite the lack of fat like in a rib steak.\n(From smoking-meat.com[4])\nPrime Rib Steak (Ribeye steak with bone-in) - I find this to be the best as it incorporates the best that a steak needs, tender beef, soft fat, and a bone to happily gnaw on. MY FAVORITE. It\u2019s usually not too pricey too.\n(From Honest Grade Meats[5])\nRibeye with Rib Cap then the Eye of Ribeye - It\u2019s still the same cut of steak, just without the bone. The Ribcap has extra connective tissue and fat, which imparts a LOT of flavor when cooked.\n(from Amazing Ribs[6])\nT-Bone and Porterhouse - These steaks are almost indistinguishable, and both are cut more or less from the same area, but one from the front of that part, and the other from the back of that part. There\u2019s plenty who call the Porterhouse as a king of steaks, and regard it better than the T-Bone.\nIt\u2019s still a pretty tasty steak regardless. I like grilling these from time to time. They also tend to be slightly more expensive than the Rib steak.\n(From Barbecue Bible[7])\nStriploin (also known as NY Strip or Sirloin in the UK) - Cut from another part of the cow, it can get to be fatty and still has a LOT of flavor.\n(from Jett Foods - Australian M5 strip[8] )\nSirloin (can also be called Top Sirloin or Rump in the UK) - This is probably the most popular overall in pubs and breakfast dishes (steak and eggs and such) because it can be tasty, and done right, can be reasonably well done. However, it\u2019s also VERY lean with little fat, and can be TOUGH. This is my least favorite common steak, and I don\u2019t really recommend it. There are those who love this cut, and when grinded up into ground beef, it can make a REALLY tasty hamburger beef patty.\nThere are two more that you can grill (though I find them really tough meats, and needs to be cut super thin and tenderized personally), the Tri-Tip and the Flank, and I wouldn\u2019t recommend you starting with these ones. When done right and tenderized, they can be incredibly tasty though. This would be better for a Steak 201 class.\nFOURTH - HOW IS THE MEAT FINISHED\nThis is more of a gourmet thing. All cows pretty much start the same way as they are fed with grass, then get moved to another food for the rest of their lives.\nThere are FOUR key foods that affects the taste of the meat.\nCORN AND SOY - Most cows that you get from the supermarket will probably be finished with corn.\nGRASS - This is more of a boutique feed for cows. The idea is that the cows are fed with lots of grass through it\u2019s entire life, but there MIGHT be some finishing with either grain (wheat) or corn as a grass-fed rancher had explained it to me that it\u2019s difficult to go completely grass fed finished. . Most cattlemen say that the meat is healthier and sweeter. You usually find this in a butcher shop or a farmer\u2019s market. Higher end steak houses tend to use this beef.\nWHEAT & BARLEY - Cows that are finished with this are the superstar elite of the steak world. Japanese cows (aka known as Wagyu, but also the famous Kobe and Matsumsaka sub-brands of Wagyu) are finished with this. This leads to reaaaally tasty tender steaks, but also really SUPER $$$ elite prices as well. Think $300\u2013400 US per steak. Only gourmet shops (and really good elite supermarkets) tend to carry this. Matsusaka and Kobe is considered to be the top of the top of these type of Japanese steaks, and is virtually impossible to eat anywhere outside of Australia except for a few restaurants around the world (only NINE in the entire USA).\nThere\u2019s a few more things here and there that matter, but just like Tri-Tip and Flank, that\u2019s a Steak 201 course. But this would be everything you need to start enjoying your explorations in Steak science!\nEDIT: I was reminded that I forgot to mention how WET AGING AND DRY AGING the meat (wet and dry aged) influenced the taste of the meat. Actually, it looks like I would be writing a STEAK 201 addition as I didn\u2019t plan on covering it in this message as that\u2019s more of a gourmet issue. For the OP, steak that\u2019s freshly slaughtered is like trying to eat leather. ALL meat needs to be aged (so it breaks down) in order to be edible.\nIn this Answer, I was covering more supermarket steaks as that\u2019s what I would assume you would be sourcing from to begin with. Supermarket steaks are \u201cWet Aged\u201d for 10\u201314 days before they\u2019re made available for sale. But DRY-AGED steaks are much better in flavor and tenderness and start at 21-days up to even a YEAR. The longer the meat is aged to break down and intensify in flavor, the more expensive as a rule of thumb.\nFootnotes\n[1] Beef 301: Meat N' Bone's Guide to labeling beef (From Choice to Wagyu A5)\n[2] The Wagyu cattle breed produces superior eating quality. History and production is described in Australia.\n[3] Otto\u2019s Steak Chart: 12 Beef Cuts You Should Know - Otto Wilde Grillers\n[4] Smoked Filet Mignon (Beef Filet) Wrapped in Bacon\n[5] Prime Rib Steak\n[6] The Rib Cap, The Best Cut On The Steer\n[7] T-Bone vs. Porterhouse Steaks - Barbecuebible.com\n[8] Frozen AUS M5 Wagyu Striploin Steak (\"~250g\")", "Just get any steak cut that is fresh and bright red.\nThat means New York Strip, Ribeye, Churrasco/skirt steak, hangar steak, et al.\nI would go with whichever steak you can get that is thicker between the NY Strip and the ribeye.\nPrime is what you are looking for. Choice is ok too.\nGrill it, pan sear it, roast it in the oven, cook it however you want. Season it well and thoroughly, especially if it is a thick cut. I\u2019m talking a copious amount of seasoning on the entirety of the outside portion of the steak.\nThat\u2019s it.", "Ask the butcher, they can usually recommend something good. Most household freezers and deep freezers do not get as cold as flash freezing does. Tough luck on that one, unless you have a lot of money to spend.", "Freeze the raw fries on a half-sheet pan, one layer only. Once they\u2019re frozen, pack them into a plastic bag then vacuum seal them to eliminate air. If you don\u2019t have a food saver or similar system for vac-packing, you can put the fries into a ziploc bag and either suck the air out through a straw, or immerse the bag in water to force the air out.", "To make from fresh, dry or air dry the fresh cut fries. Fry very hot for about 1/2 the normal fry time. If you are instead using frozen or defrosted commercial fries, apply a light spray of oil. For either type, freeze FAST on an open tray, bag up as soon as they\u2019re solid SOLID frozen, suck the air out and seal the bag (or use a kitchen vacuum bagger) and freeze COLD in a chest freezer. Simple.\nOr, if you just want to keep a part bag of defrosted fries in the freezer, put them in a zip bag, suck out as much of the air as you can, seal then freeze fat]st and hold cold in a chest freezer.", "Ice forms inside of bags with food in them in the freezer because the AIR INSIDE of the bag has moisture in it, & then it freezes, and ice crystals form on the foods, (all types of foods you put in the freezer, not just potatoes.)\nSo to limit or eliminate freezer-burn ice crystals what you NEED to do is:\n1.). Cool foods down first, by putting them in the fridge for awhile, first, till they are not hot & steaming anymore\u2026 (Steam is a sure sign of moisture!) THEN\u2026\n2.). Squeeze out as MUCH air as possible out of the food bag BEFORE sealing the bag shut TIGHTLY and putting it in the freezer!!\nThe more air you can get OUT of the bag the less chance of ice crystals (frost = \u201cfreezer burn\u201d) from forming on the foods. You can use a straw to suck the last bit of air out if a baggie, or buy one of those food vacuum sealers = the best way!!\nUntil then, squeeze it out (as much as possible) before sealing bags shut!!\nKeep air from TOUCHING foods in dishes you are freezing by putting plastic wrap or wax paper or aluminum foil around dish, touching the top surface of the foods (like on top of a foil pan of food.)"], "topic_list": ["Frozen Food", "French Fries", "Fried Foods", "Freezing", "Potatoes", "Ice", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [35, 27, 81, 97, 105], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Hannah Crenshaw", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "question_title": "How do I freeze French fries without ice forming on the outside?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "690", "name_list": ["Sharon Griffin Squire", "Kerry Berger", "Sandra McKenzie", "Bob McDougall", "Donna Norris"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"]}, "433": {"ans_list": ["Per food safety guidelines, cooked protein should be kept at 145 degrees F to technically stay safe for a maximum of two hours. Generally it has very little nutritional value, with very little to non existent anything other than carbs. That said it is a grain and we need it as a staple with our food. You can have options and the one I recommend is Basmati rice. It has some protein and sodium and is very high in potassium besides its excellent, fragrant taste. You can soak it for an hour, discard the water and boil in lots of water till it\u2019s half cooked, drain the water cover and steam on minimum heat for another 5 to 6 minutes and you have great (almost) starch free rice.", "Aside from carbohydrates, I\u2019m sure there are a small amount of vitamins and micronutrients in rice in general, and fiber in the brown rice. Like other popular carbohydrates/starches like potatoes and pasta, it\u2019s used mainly as a vehicle for other foods and sauces and usually a side dish. But unlike most starches, it\u2019s commonly eaten in its pure steamed form. People don\u2019t usually eat a plain baked potato with their meal, without putting butter, sour cream and other fixings, so it\u2019s less fattening in that way, which is healthier. It\u2019s a pure grain, which in white rice is processed to remove the hull, but not as processed as pasta. Brown rice is better for you than white rice, because fiber is important, and most people don\u2019t eat enough fiber as it is. But if eating white rice is more palatable so that you eat more veggies with it, than I\u2019d say it\u2019s healthier than eating brown rice and not eating much of it and the veggies it went with. White rice is a healthier option than pasta and a non-plain baked potato. It keeps well, and it doesn\u2019t go bad like potatoes in the pantry, which cuts on food waste, which can be argued that its healthier than food traveling from long distances and then getting thrown away. So healthier for the planet can be healthy for you too.", "Rice is grass seed, I don't know about you but I'm a carnivore.", "Not a nutrition or whole foods expert. Just saying. I only have a basic understanding of these things and someone else can probably explain it better.\nWhite rice is a refined grain that has had the germ and bran removed. All you\u2019re left with are the carbohydrates so you basically get a bunch of calories but little else. The health benefits are that you stop being hungry and don\u2019t starve.\nIt doesn\u2019t matter what kind of white rice it is\u2026 \u201cregular\u201d or jasmine, basmati or arborio.\nYou mentioned brown rice. That\u2019s basically the white rice before it has been processed to remove the hull and bran. Many people don\u2019t like it as much because it still has the hull and is more firm in texture. Black rice, red rice, wild rice are all whole grains and all more firm in texture than refined white rice. But if you want named rice to be nutritious, you need to choose a brown jasmine rice or a black sticky rice.\nI should note that my answer pertains only to rice. Other grains, like barley and farro, have different rules. For instance, with those two you should avoid the term \u201cpearled\u201d in the description. Pearled barley would be similar to white rice. Hulled barley is cool.\nDon\u2019t even ask me about sorghum or quinoa\u2026\nPersonally, I can\u2019t think of any situation in which white rice would be healthier unless there are some medical conditions in which a proper diet calls for less bran. I planned on cooking it in the crockpot for 8 hours.", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "387", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "758": {"ans_list": ["Ham is a preserved leg of a pig \u2014 note that this technically precisely describes both the origin of the meat and the particular cut, however in an ordinary speech ham may means any type of preserved pork nowadays. While prescribing the origin and the cut, the traditional definition of ham doesn\u2019t actually say anythng about meat/fat ratio, amount of connective tissue, bone or binder in a reformed/chopped hams. Anything goes as long as it was originally something that a hog was walking on. It might be a whole salted and dried or smoked leg of a pig, or it might be chopped spiced leg meat cured with solt and liquid smoke and then packed into a can. It still could be called ham.\nSalami, on the other hand is a precise type of meat product \u2014 a sausage. Dry, firm sausage typically made from finely chopped pork and (or) horse meat and fat, salted, packed into pig or horse intestines, and then hung in the air to ferment and dry. Beef, venison, veal and goose are all also used to make salami, and the varieties are endless, so it is actually an even less narrowly described product than ham. However, traditionally little binder is used in salami, so it usually contains only meat, fat and spices (often with a 80%-to-20% ratio of meat to fat), while some lower grade hams (such as canned \u201cham and water product\u201d often found in budget US supermarkets) can have as little as 30\u201340% meat, the balance being fat, water and binders."], "topic_list": ["Salted Cured Meats", "Salami", "Ham (food)", "Food Comparisons", "Pork", "Chicken (food)", "Meat", "Cooking", "Nutrition", "Technology", "Food"], "view_list": [65], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Dreezy Mida", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What's the difference between ham and salami, especially regarding meat content?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "548", "name_list": ["Andrey Tupkalo"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"]}, "527": {"ans_list": ["Its easier.?", "I never knew that they do."], "topic_list": ["Hard-boiled Eggs", "Seafood", "Boiling", "Eggs (food)", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [2, 5], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Anthony Ford", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "Why do people put boil eggs in seafood boils?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "493", "name_list": ["Ilene. However, I buy the inexpensive nonstick fry pans from Sam\u2019s Club. They are all aluminum. Once the coating is scratched and mangled, I send to the recycler and get another one. Many nonstick fry pans and skillets eventually developed a relatively stick free surface as oils adhere to the surface and fill it the pores in the metal. Cast iron is an example, and why you have specialty instructions for cleaning them. I have a hand hammered wok that is the same way. But you would have to return the skillet to the manufacturer where they would run it through the normal scouring process and then recoat it. It would likely cost more than the price of a new pan if they would actually do that for you.", "Nope. And if your favorite pan is non-stick, you need to get out more. Virtually all non-stick pans are crappy to start, and just get crappier with use. (Too thin, wrong material.) If you care about the craft and want to get better, throw your worn-out nonstick pan away, and get tri-ply and cast iron. You can keep a non-stick skillet around for special purposes, but you'll be surprised how little you'll use it."], "topic_list": ["Non-stick Pans", "Coating", "Teflon", "Frying Pans", "Cooking Utensils", "Cookware", "Kitchen Utensils and Accessories", "Kitchens", "Cooking"], "view_list": [30, 27, 24], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Kevin Corley", "upvote_list": [2, 0, 0], "question_title": "Is it possible to reapply a nonstick coating on a favorite pan?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "355", "name_list": ["Stephen Narramore", "Joseph Mccray", "David Tigwell"], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"]}, "453": {"ans_list": ["Thanks for A2A. Your slow cooker has many hidden talents.\nIf you thought your slow cooker was impressive already, prepare to be even more wowed. Here are five slow cooker hacks that'll blow your mind.\nIt Can Moonlight As A Double Boiler\nFood blog Mommy's Kitchen solved one of the chronic issues with making overnight recipes in the slow cooker. Namely, for recipes that don't need a full 6-8 hours to cook overnight, you'll wake up to burned meals if you don't wake up in the middle of the night to turn the slow cooker off. Mommy's Kitchen solved the problem of crusty oatmeal by creating a water bath, which makes the oats cook slower. More sleep and better oatmeal? We're in. To turn your slow cooker into a double boiler, simply fill the insert about half way with water, and add the ingredients that would go directly into the insert into a bowl, which will then be set in the water.
