Sulforaphane, present in brassicas and nowhere else in large quantities, helps fight many illnesses, including cancer.\nHeat destroys myrosinase, so cooking broccoli (florets and leaves) for the shortest period of time in the smallest amount of water (quick steaming) retains more of it. Chopping it up into small pieces, though, and letting it sit for 40 minutes or longer, develops the most sulforaphane. The longer it sits, the more sulforphane is released. Also, chewing raw florets is beneficial. When I prepare broccoli, kale, or cauliflower, I always chew on a few raw pieces.\nThere are many antioxidants formed in the brassicas\u2014different ones are released at different points along the process, which target specific areas of the body, especially in the alimentary canal. So, eating some of it fresh and raw, cooking some of it right after chopping, and cooking some of it after letting it sit, chopped, for 40 minutes will give you the broadest range of antioxidants.\nIncidentally, frozen broccoli has been blanched, destroying myrosinase. So you won\u2019t get these benefits from frozen broccoli\u2026 unless\u2026 you sprinkle a tiny amount of dry mustard on the broccoli while it\u2019s being prepared. Mustard is another plant in the Brassicaceae family, and it reintroduces myrosinase to the broccoli.", "Is it true that cutting broccoli releases its nutrients?\nNo, not appreciably. Not in the sense of nutrients being lost. If you prefer chopped broccoli, it is fine to chop it up. You can eat it lightly steamed. Cooking too much can reduce some nutrients. I like to rinse the broccoli, remove the florettes, chop the heavier stems into bite sized pieces. Then put the stem pieces in a pan with a little oil, or in a steamer, and cook covered until they are tender, then add the bite sized florettes, and cook lightly. They should be bright green and a little crisp. Don't over cook. You can eat them alone, or with other veggies, or add to stir fry meat, or tofu. Whatever you like. Just start with the pieces that need to cook longest, and finish with the florettes or other veggies that don't need much cooking. Mushy broccoli is not very tasty.\nIt is true that the heavier stalks of the broccoli are more digestible after cooking, so in that way more nutrients are available to you. The heaviest part of the stem might get woody. I trim that part off. I would never boil broccoli. The broth from the steamer can be reserved for soup. The only veggies I boil are potatoes.\nTry broccoli, snow peas, and slivered almonds.\nIt is Spring here. The Purple Sprouting Broccoli I planted last Fall is producing a lot of florettes. I am eating them almost every day. If I keep picking them, they will produce until mid Summer.\nIn the garlic beds, the garlics I missed digging up last Summer have sprouted clumps of green garlic's. I am digging them out, replanting the biggest ones, and chopping the smaller shoots like scallions ( green onions). I add these to my veggies when I cook them.\nTry lightly steaming the florettes, chilling with ice, then sprinkling with lemon or vinegar. Add these to green salads.\nSometimes organic broccoli has aphids on the florettes. Not to worry. A quick soak in brine, and a good spray of water will remove them all. It is completely edible.\nIf you are growing Broccoli, harvest the center stalk a little higher up. Leave some side stems. They will grow out, and produce many smaller heads which you can also harvest. These stems after harvest will produce many more smaller broccoletti. Eventually they are too small to mess with. Harvest the seeds when they form, and sprout them in the kitchen next winter to add to a winter salad. The plant will make little long bean like seed pods. Collect them when the seeds are fully formed, and the pods are starting to dry out and get brown. If you wait too long they will pop open and scatter the seeds. You can finish drying them in a loose bag. Use an appropriate sieve to separate the seeds from the dried pods. Or winnow them if you know how. Broccoli sprouts are very good for you.", "The three factors that lead to nutrient loss are heat, oxygen, and light. The interiors of uncut produce are protected from oxygen and light but exposed when cut. The nutrient that suffers the heaviest hit in cut fruits and vegetables is probably vitamin C, although some vitamin A and vitamin E get lost as well. According to recent research in the Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, raw broccoli provides significantly more of this beneficial nutrient than cooked. Cooking locks sulforaphane in, making it unavailable to your body, Bottom Line, if you like broccoli, eat it raw. it's more nutritious.", "No.\nCutting food does not \u201crelease vital nutrients\u201d at all. That\u2019s all just misinformation.\nCooking food can do that, because heat can in a way, encourage the nutrients to come out. But then again some vitamins cannot survive the temperature and die, losing some.\nMost studies say that cooked vegetables are usually better than raw, but raw veggies are still nutritional and healthy.\nI hope this helps.", "No. It's a nonsensical idea. In the first place, any broccoli you buy in the store has already been cut when it was harvested. In the second place, while any method of cooking may destroy certain heat sensitive nutrients, simply slicing or dicing any vegetable reduces it to smaller pieces, without making any other changes. Unless you slice it, then leave it sitting in a bowl for several hours, your smaller pieces of broccoli have exactly the same vitamins and minerals they contained when all in one piece.", "No boiling it in water does.", "Noo"], "topic_list": ["Broccoli", "Nutrients", "Food Science", "Vegetables", "Cooking", "Healthy Eating", "Nutrition", "Health", "Food"], "view_list": [47, 77, 38, 34, 172, 5, 9], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Liya Elizabeth Jacob (\u0d32\u0d3f\u0d2f \u0d0e\u0d32\u0d3f\u0d38\u0d2c\u0d24\u0d4d\u0d24\u0d4d \u0d1c\u0d47\u0d15\u0d4d\u0d15\u0d2c\u0d4d)", "upvote_list": [1, 1, 0, 0, 3, 0, 0], "question_title": "Is it true that cutting broccoli releases its nutrients?", "respond_collected": 7, "no_of_view": "1,068", "name_list": ["Kim Carlisle", "James Boettcher", "Hardy Mletzko", "Jessie Hogg", "Beth Goldowitz", "Andy Hajik", "Nithish Sunny"], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "750": {"ans_list": ["I don\u2019t know what \u201cregular\u201d vanilla is. I would recommend an Indian snack recipe for the people who are at isolation and looking for something to kill their free time.\nThe ingredients might be available at everyone's home. So give it a try, its worth trying.", "I started baking my own pizza. It was one of those things I always wanted to do but never did due to lack of time \u2014 or rather, that's what I told myself. When I felt like having a pizza, I would get a mediocre one at Uni for lunch, or buy a crap prebaked one from the supermarket, cover it in cheese and all kinds of toppings, and finish in the oven.\nNow, I bake a pretty decent Neapolitan style pie whenever I want, and it's not even a lot of work, just some planning required.\nThe Dough:\n330 g white flour\n230 ml water\n1 - 1.5 tsp salt\n0.5 tsp instant dry yeast\nMix all ingredients in a bowl until a shaggy ball of dough forms. Let sit for at least half an hour for the flour to hydrate. Transfer to a floured surface and knead for ten minutes until the dough becomes soft and supple. Put back in the bowl, cover, and let rise at room temperature for up to 12 hours. Afterwards, transfer bowl into the fridge, where you'll leave it for at least one and up to five days to cold ferment.\nThe Pie:\n200 g fresh mozzarella\n50 g spicy salami / pepperoni\n70 g canned tomatoes\nFresh basil, salt, oregano, olive oil to taste\nOn the day you want to have pizza, take the dough out of the fridge two hours in advance, split in halves, and form round balls. You can repeatedly stretch the surface and tuck it in in the back, or use the work surface and your hands to pull the dough into a neat ball. Put in a slightly oiled, or heavily floured container /bowl, cover, and let rise for up to two hours. If you won't use both balls, move the other back to the fridge, covered.\nAdd salt, a small sprinkle of dried oregano, and a splash of olive oil directly into the tomato can, and use a stand mixer to blitz the tomatoes a few times, creating a chunky sauce.\nTear the mozzarella into one centimeter large chunks.\nPreheat the oven to max temperature, with a sheet pan inside, for at least half an hour before baking. Take the ball of dough, carefully transfer on a floured surface, and using your fingers press into a disc, leaving a centimeter around the edges for the crust. Then pick the disc up, hang on your knuckles, and shuffle it, rotating and stretching until near transparent. The longer it chills in the fridge, the more ready it is to stretch very thin. Once your desired size and thickness is reached, transfer on a piece of baking paper. Apply sauce, leaving the crust bare. Distribute salami and sprinkle the mozzarella chunks on top.\nTake the blazing hot sheet pan out of the preheated oven. Carefully transfer the baking paper with the pizza on top of it, and place back into the oven. The pizza will be ready in a few minutes, once the toppings start sizzling and the crust starts turning golden brown.\nLet sit for a minute or two before eating to avoid delicious liquid lava annihilating your mouth.\nEdit: here are some pictures. Note that after 24 hours of chilling in the fridge, the pizza was kinda small and thick, it didn't want to stretch:\nAfter 48 hours, the result was much better:"], "topic_list": ["Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [43, 188, 0], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 3, "question_author": "Kris Craig", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "question_title": "What are some recipes to try out in isolation?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "8,151", "name_list": ["Sienna Layne", "Anju Vijay", "Patrick Gono"], "date_list": ["Apr 23, 2020", "Apr 20, 2020", "Apr 19, 2020"]}, "18": {"ans_list": ["With the mandatory quarantine, rice is one of the best options to buy when you cannot be shopping frequently. I use either size depending on how much I am cooking. If I am only cooking a small amount for 1 or 2 people, I'll use that size cooker.\nSupposedly the slow cooker is meant to be used when you work all day, and want to come home, and your meal is finished cooking, and all you need to do is set your place setting up at your dinning room table, or your kitchen table. Don't forget to turn off your slow cooker. Do not let any vegetables or meat stay in the cooker once it's finished cooking. As it will be too soggy. And may lose its flavor.\nThe vegetables and meat, all go in at one time, cook for 8 hours, and it should be ready when you arrive home. Or sooner if you elect a higher level of cooking.. say, 4 hours. Or 6 hours, you should be able to decide how long you want it to cook..hopefully you will have a cooker that automatically shuts itself off when the cooking cycle is complete. .or that it at least goes to the warm cycle.\nThe only two drawbacks I find in using a slow cooker is, the vegetables are apt to be over cooked. Which can not be helped because everything goes into the pot at once. My second issue is, the meat is cooking in its own juices. And this can be a little greasy. Fat, from the grease from the meat. So, before I would attempt to make a gravy from the juices, I would remove the meat, keep it warm on a platter, covered, so it doesn't dry out. Then I would drain the juice from the slow cooker, separate the fat from it. Then in a separate pan on the stove, make a rue. This is done with butter and flour combined quickly, gradually add, the meat juice, little bit at a time, stir quickly to get out lumps, season to taste with salt & pepper, and other herbs of your choice.", "Many tougher cuts of beef, sold specifically as \u201cstewing beef\u201d or a \u201cpot roast\u201d for example, contain a lot of a substance called \u201ccollagen\u201d that holds the muscle fibers together and not a lot of fat. They\u2019re from a part of the animal that gets a workout, like its shoulders and hind quarters. The tender cuts are from the muscles that the animal hardly ever used, which contain a lot of fat but not much collagen. There are cuts of mutton that are similar.\nIf you try to cook these tougher meats fairly quickly (like you would a steak) or roast them at high temperatures (like a roast), the collagen binds to itself and to the meat, making it even tougher. The same would happen if, for some strange reason, you wanted to boil it like pasta.\nHowever, if you slow cook it at lower temperatures (and it\u2019s not just that simple, get yourself some knowledge about braising) the collagen eventually becomes a liquid, which separates the muscle fibers it usually binds together. The meat becomes tender instead of tougher. This process can\u2019t be rushed and has to be \u201clow and slow\u201d to get the right results.\nTrue barbecue uses the same technique with hot air rather than a little hot water.", "Any form of cooking needs to get the interior to a certain temperature (varies by food). Traditional cooking does so by making the outside quite hot, for a short period of time, since the rate of heat transfer is proportionate to the temperature difference. Slow cooking uses temperatures only slightly above the desired internal temperatures, which takes far longer, but avoids burning the outside and also provides more time for flavors to blend. The temperature is still hot enough to kill most microbes, though."], "topic_list": ["Learning to Cook", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [102, 0, 139], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Smith Gilliam", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "question_title": "How does slow cooking work?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "2,680", "name_list": ["Heddy Green", "Steven Haddock", "Davis Appleton"], "date_list": ["Apr 19, 2020", "Apr 18, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "276": {"ans_list": ["You take it to the dump which has facilities to accept it!", "Store until lockdown is over.\nTake it your local municipal waste and recycling centre.", "How much is \u201clarge amounts\u201d?\nUsed oil is valuable. It can be reprocessed into biodiesel. Most cities have companies that will collect it (and usually supply you with fresh oil at the same time), subject to minimum quantities to make the pickup worthwhile for them. Any commercial catering operation that does any significant frying will have a contract with such a company.\nFor domestic quantities, the problem is a little harder. Although food waste is collected, by local authorities, for composting, they don\u2019t collect waste oil but there are usually tanks for it provided at the recycling centre (when they are open).\nDon\u2019t, whatever you do, pour it down the drain. I have in the past poured it into a full dustbin, where it would go to landfill, but this is not a good thing to do.", "There are many many companies that take and even buy used vegetable oil to clean and turn into bio diesel. First, I\u2019d try some easy no-bake recipes. Think pudding mix, no-bake cheesecakes, or even a pudding pie. Those are easy, tasty, and don\u2019t require heat. Then, I would try some things that you can possibly cook in the microwave. While this isn\u2019t usually something a professional chef would do, it\u2019s good if you aren\u2019t good with stoves. You can make mug cakes, noodles, and even applesauce using the microwave. If you\u2019re making something like a microwave meal, however, I would add something to spice it up and take it to the next level. Think easy sauces, garnishes, and different platings. Next, I would make things using an oven or toaster oven. You could make pies, cakes, biscuits, oven-baked pancakes, roasted vegetables, baked meats, cookies, brownies, and so many more things just using the oven. This way, you can get more used to the heat without having to be near actual fire. Then, when you feel ready to start working with a stove, try using a stove without actual flames. Don\u2019t cook anything complicated, or anything with hot oil that can splatter. Try maybe some pasta, possibly even homemade pasta because that doesn\u2019t have to cook as long. Keep working with the stove, eventually making recipes using hot oil. And then, when you finally feel ready, you can use a real gas stove. Turn it on and keep it on low, and don\u2019t freak out if the flames jump out a little when you first turn it on. Be careful with the real stove. My experience has been its works great with meats and potatoes. My wife does a Shepherd\u2019s Pie in the IP, and its a fav of ours. I do country style ribs which are terrific as well. Always remember you have to add at least 1 cup of liquid before sealing the pressure cooker. The liquid can be water, or broth - but 1 cup is the minimum. As you work with it more, you will become familiar with the saute function, and many other things it can do. Even frozen the enzymes in the product will still be active. The reason one blanches is to deactivate the enzymes (basically they are still ripening the product only at a slower rate than when fresh) So you cannot keep an unblanched product as long as you might with blanched product, probably should not be kept more than 3 months. And yes, you can blanch in the microwave. Remember that blanching is to stop the enzymes and not cook the product so submerge in cold water to stop the cooking process.", "You can absolutely freeze fresh peas without blanching. And wonderfully what yer doing when doing that is\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026\u2026.\nCyro-Blanching!\nWhich isn\u2019t some Super Villain created by freezing a wilting Southern Belle.\nThose very clever cookies Alex Talbot and Aki Kamozawa of the blog Ideas In Food realised that rapidly freezing certain vegetables, peas and beans and asparagus and stuff like that with a similar diameter, had the same effect as regular blanching.\nIt\u2019s not going to work well with everything, not with alliums. Might well work with dark leafy greens though\nIDEAS IN FOOD\nHow to Cryo-Blanch Vegetables | The Food Lab\nThe Science of Cryo-blanching", "Peppers can be frozen without blanching. Their texture will suffer when thawed, but they work great in cooked dishes.\nI blanch peas, and most other green veg, before freezing. The color keeps better, and the process disables the enzymes that make green veg go gray and mushy.", "Can you freeze fresh peas without blanching them first?\nYes I have done so with no loss of taste or texture. When you want to use them, allow to thaw and just heat through so they retain their fresh bright green colour. Add some chopped mint and a pinch of sugar.\nThese vegetables also freeze well without blanching.\nLeeks - clean, getting rid of any soil which may be between layers. Drain very well. Slice as you would to use in future and freeze in smallish quantities. (about 2 cups) I separate the darker sections from the paler parts so I can choose what I need, depending on the dish being cooked.\nCelery - rinse off any dirt, Remove the leaves and store separately for the stock pot. Finely slice the stalks and pack in smallish quantities. (about 2 cups)\nTomatoes - If you have tomatoes getting a bit soft, either skin and freeze or place in the freezer with the skin on. As they thaw you can pull the skin off.", "Blanching (scalding vegetables in boiling water or steam for a short time) is a must for almost all vegetables to be frozen. It stops enzyme actions which can cause loss of flavor, color and texture. Blanching cleanses the surface of dirt and organisms, brightens the color and helps retard loss of vitamins.", "I freeze quite a few things and never blanch them. For me personally blanching just does not make any sense. If you plan to cook things you froze, why blanch them? If you intend to use them \u201cas is\u201d after thawing, then blanching makes even less sense.\nI like freezing extra things to use at a later date. This goes for cooked dishes as well (soups, stews, sauces, stock etc.). I will try to list right now produce I personally froze and used.\nPeas do great, they are in my opinion indistinguishable from fresh ones once cooked.\nCorn is also great. I slice mine off the cob and freeze in bags, but have a friend who freezes it whole and has corn on the cob in the middle of winter.\nTomatoes (diced and ground) do very well.\nBell peppers are also great. I take stems out and freeze them whole in bags. In winter stuff them without thawing and cook as usual.\nParsley roots, carrots, beets - sliced and portioned.\nCeleriac - cleaned and sliced.\nParsley greens, dill, cilantro - finely chopped.\nStrawberries - stems out, washed.\nBlueberries - whole, washed.\nSour cherries - washed, pits removed.\nPeaches - washed, halved, stones removed.\nI am sure there are other thing I just do not remember offhand. All vegetables are cooked in various stews and soups. Fruit is used for cobblers, pancakes, drinks, but can be eaten raw, depends on your preferences.\nAs I mentioned, I view blanching as an extra unnecessary step, works for me. Just think through how you are planning to use your produce and make sure that before freezing it is clean, sliced and portioned accordingly.\nI find that it is absolutely wonderful when in the dead of winter you can pull a few bags from your freezer and make incredible soup/stew or fragrant delicious desert with things you saved in summer. Tastes great, smells great, healthy and nutritious - all big pluses in my book\u2026.\nPS In my experience frozen produce is better NOT thawed before use. If thawed it might turn to mush. So add things to your dishes when they are still frozen and adjust your cooking times if necessary.", "I do know that you can freeze peas without blanching first. I have done this and I love those frozen peas almost as well as fresh ones! As to the second part of your question, I do not have experience in what other vegetables can be frozen without blanching so I cannot answer honestly.", "You can certainly freeze anything without blanching. What you have when you thaw these veggies is another thing. Most things will be mush and fit for soups and stews. Root crops will fare better, but will not resemble the raw state. You may be correct about the level of nutrition, but the taste might be debatable. It seems a very American cooking-show type things but not only is washing meat entirely unnecessary, it's actually creating more hazards than already existed.\nWe cook meat specifically to kill off bacteria present in the meat. Cold, or even warm water will do absolutely nothing to remove germs. Raw meat has bacteria and that's just the way it is. Again, that's why we cook it.\nWashing any peace of meat will not only not remove bacteria, it will spread the same bacteria all over your sink and anything the water might splash or drip on.\nThe only time I would ever \u201cwash\u201d meat of any kind would be bones if I was making a stock and even then, I'd only do it to make a clearer broth and it would have nothing to do with hygiene.\nSo no, do not wash your ham.\nAssuming you haven't just dropped it on your dusty kitchen floor. Sun dried tomatoes are sold Dr, no oil, in certain packaging. Maybe w preservatives, but people dry tomatoes in food dehydrators and store with no oil. I've even dried jarrred pasta sauce, as an experiment and to save space. It kept for months, no mold, and reconstituted easily. Backpackers do it all the time", "Although it is a bit tricky to store sun dried tomatoes but not difficult.\nAny type of tomato can be used for storing in dried form. Cut the tomatoes into either two pieces or four pieces. Four three - four days let the dry in direct sunlight by placing them on mesh. Sprinkle some common salt on them . After four them place them on a plate ate and let them dry . When they are completely dry ,take a sterlized ,dry container or a fridge ziplock bag. It is required that the size of the container or ziplock bag is small and there is no space left above the dried tomatoes. In other words there should be no or very very less space left above the tomatoes. After putting them the ziplock bag remove air above the tomatoes by pressing it or by vacuum sealing.\nThese tomatoes can be stored in a freezer or refrigerator for 12 to 16 months. Their texture and flavor is maintained.", "Unless there is layer of oil above the dried tomatoes there could be problems of spoilage mainly from molds.\nThe main reason is not being able to remove or bind free water.\nYou can overcome that ( for limited time :\nBy drying almost completely ( which will be bit difficult, unless you use a good dryer. Sun drying may not give that quick enough).\nYou may use some approved mold inhibitors/ preservatives prior drying.\nYou may dry and vacuum pack after drying.\nYou may pack the dried slices and freeze.\nYou may pack and pasteurize in water ( about 60 C ) for 30 min.\nYOU CAN COMBINE MORE THAN ONE OF THE ABOVE METHODS.\n[ Fundamental Food Microbiology: 5 TH ED, ( chapters on food preservation), Ray and Bhunia, Taylor and Francis.", "You can buy dried tomatoes without oil.", "Yes"], "topic_list": ["Sun-Dried Tomatoes", "Tomatoes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [10, 26, 18, 2, 8], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Ayan Nath", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "question_title": "Can we keep sun dried tomatoes without oil?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "332", "name_list": ["Keith Dabney", "Kapila Rastogi", "Bibek Ray", "David Masaoka", "Gilda Mascarenhas"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"]}, "243": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Fantastic Cleaners", "Anti-bacterial", "Cleaners", "Cleaning Products", "Disinfectants", "Housecleaning", "Viruses (biology)", "Do It Yourself (DIY)", "Cleaning", "Virology", "Recipes", "COVID-19 (2019-2020)", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 1, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Michael Tolboe", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What are some good recipes to make a virus killing cleaner?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "419", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "470": {"ans_list": ["Look for the induction symbol. Most induction suitable pans made in the last 10 years have this symbol.\nOtherwise test them with a magnet. If the magnet sticks they can usually be used."], "topic_list": ["Induction Cooktops", "Cookware", "Induction (Electromagnetism)", "Cooking"], "view_list": [28], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Mohammed Saiful Alam Siddiquee (\u092e\u0941\u0939\u092e\u094d\u092e\u0926 \u0938\u0948\u092b\u0941\u0932 \u0906\u0932\u092e \u0938\u093f\u0926\u094d\u0926\u0940\u0915\u0940)", "upvote_list": [2], "question_title": "How do I know if my pans are induction compatible?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "354", "name_list": ["Tony Christian Ratcliffe"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020"]}, "111": {"ans_list": ["None of these if you don't do it right, but stainless steel us the hardest to kill which makes it a good set for beginners.\nAs for cooking itself it really depends on what you are cooking and which techniques you are applying. More in deep thoughts can be found e.g. here: Cook the Book\nJust don't expect a short answer like, take this and you will never fail.\nCopper pro:\nBest thermal conductivity of these three. that means that even a small gas flame will heat copper rather evenly\nCopper contra:\nIt is easier to burn yourself, the thermal conductivity works to the inside as well as to the outside\nin it's pure form copper does not like acids or salty atmosphere, so not everything shall be put in\nit's expensive, we're talking about real copper not the cheap consumer ware that is steel with a thin copper foil applied to it.\ncopper must not be overheated, it might even get cracks then\nCastiron pro:\nbetter thermal conductivity than steel though not as good as copper\nas castiron pots and pans often got thicker walls the heat storage is very good and will even out heat fluctuations from the stove very well.\nCastiron con:\nif you don't season the material well it will corrode easily too (rust)\nthus unless you are really, oositivly convinced that your seasoning us prettry well keep the acids out too\nto have the advantage of good heat storage you need more castiron, but that also means you need more muscle when handling the oits and pans\nStainless stell pro:\nits very resistand against corrosion and abuse, scratching good steel is not easy and you can use steel wool to clean it\nStainless steel con:\nit does not excel in thermal conductivity and heat storage capacity", "We use cast iron from frying and similar hot skillet cooking. We use stainless steel when water is used to steam vegetables or boil pasta.", "cast iron for 80% of cooking needs. But takes more care. Stainless is more wear resistant & better to clean in a dish washer. But food sticks & if over heated can blue. So ruined. Copper cladding spreads heat more even than a single metal. Pottery pots are best for slow cooking, & great for individual dish\u2019s you bake. Then move to a warmer to be ready to serve several hours later. But break easy.", "Personally it will depend on what I am cooking plus I also use an outdoor grille", "\u201cbest\u201d is subjective. I like stainless best, but your mileage may vary.", "Cast iron is king must it must be seasoned right to have the non stick properties.\nAnother good thing about cast iron is it imparts some iron into the food being cooked which is a bonus for women.", "cast iron is my preference copper and stainless steel will discolour and distort", "I have two copper pots that I prize. I also haven\u2019t been able to use them since switching to an induction cooktop.", "I\u2019ve been using a traditional wok made of carbon steel (uncoated) for as long as I can remember. It heats fast and transfers heat evenly (round bottom) and over time has formed its own nonstick coating - seasoned. It is easily manageable during cooking, easy to maintain and lasts forever. The all-in-one workhorse in the kitchen.\nThe carbon steel wok is very versatile to use, and have used it for stir fry of course, deep fry, searing, poaching, roasting (nuts-spices), steaming, and even making soup noodles. Wok is the obvious essential utensil, carbon steel is it - the best for Chinese and Malaysian style cooking..", "My choice is stainless steel, hands down.\nCast iron is susceptible to rusting and can shatter if you hit it hard enough. Copper can impart a nasty metallic taste to foods or water.", "Michael Symmons, The Chew, said in an online cooking video, that he thinks cooper pans are best. I htnk cast iron apns, are better. But Cat iron pans are, heavy! You wouldn\u2019t believe just how heavy, even in stores.", "It depends on what you prefer to cook on everyone has their own opinions", "Cast iron for heat retention, copper for conduction, stainless steel for convenience and low cost.", "Skip the copper; it\u2019s a marketing gimmick.\nStainless steel is great for all purpose cooking. Copper bottoms are okay (though a pain to clean), but heavy bases are better for heating evenly and holding the heat. Stainless is excellent for boiling.\nCast iron is excellent for frying, simmering, and even baking, once it\u2019s properly seasoned. It is heavy, so more difficult to use for people with arthritis and other similar issues. Cast aluminum can be a lighter weight alternative, through it doesn\u2019t season the way cast iron does.\nI have a variety of cookware including stainless, cast iron, cast aluminum, coated aluminum, and some nonstick skillets. The nonstick is not my favorite but it works for pancakes and eggs and the occasional grilled cheese sandwich with easy clean up. For baking I use mainly stainless steel.\nExperience will show you what works for you. Don\u2019t tie yourself to one brand or type of cookware. You might, like me, end up with a variety of pots and pans that each work best for specific purposes.", "All three types of cookware have their advantages. I personally prefer cast Iron, due to it's ability to hold heat and maintain a more even temperature with less cost in gas, electricity or wood. Mostly it comes down to what you prefer. I will say that if I were to choose stainless I would want it coated in ceramic. Pure copper ware heats evenly but loses heat fairly quickly as well. Copper is an expensive metal, so expect higher costs. Cast Iron is the least attractive without an outer coating of enamel or other materials.\nPresently I live outside of the United States, so most cookware is expensive. Most of my pans are ceramic coated stainless steel, as cast iron is hard to find, is expensive and most is lacking in quality.", "There is no \u201cbest pan\u201d for all situations. Some pans are better than others depending on what your are cooking, what sort of stovetop you are using, your budget, and what sort of results you are looking for.\nPlain cast iron is great for certain applications (searing anything, for example), it is inexpensive and incredibly durable, and can be made non-stick through proper seasoning. It can be used with any heat source but is not recommended for glass cooktops because it might scratch them. Cast iron also has great heat retention. On the downside, it requires more care (it must be hand washed and throroughly dried after use or it will rust) and the seasoning requires regular maintenance. Similar to cast iron is plain carbon steel. They are still relatively rare in the U.S. but they\u2019re making a comeback. This material works very similar to cast iron, but is lighter and will heat faster. It is a bit more expensive than cast iron, but still affordable. Carbon steel must be seasoned, like cast iron, but the seasoning is a bit more difficult to achieve and maintain.\nThere are also enameled cast iron pans, which give you most of the advantages of plain cast iron, but don\u2019t require seasoning. The enamel is a glass based material which is non-reactive, so you can cook anything in it. These pans are great for \u201clow and slow\u201d cooking. You can have a soup or stew simmering all day on the stovetop if you want. They can also go in the dishwasher, but I still prefer to wash mine by hand \u2014 the dishwasher can discolor the enamel and the pan should last longer washing by hand. The enamel is not as non-stick as a properly seasoned plain cast iron pan, but food doesn\u2019t stick nearly as much as it can with stainless steel. The enamel coating can chip and flake off on these, especially with the cheaper ones, but the pan can still be used even if the enamel chips. Underneath the enamel is just cast iron, which is non-toxic. The higher quality enameled pans can be quite expensive.\nStainless steel by itself makes for a pretty lousy pan that is only good for boiling things. It is a poor conductor of heat, which results in hot spots. A clad stainless pan (a good heat conductor, such as aluminum or copper is sandwiched between layers of stainless) gives you an incredibly durable and useful pan that heats more quickly and evenly than plain stainless. Stainless is very low maintenance (no seasoning) and can be washed in the dishwasher. It is non-reactive, so you can cook anything in it. However, food will stick to it, and when that happens it becomes much harder to clean than cast iron. Also, some stainless pans will not work on an induction cooktop, but any stainless pan can be used with any other heat source. On the downside, a good quality clad stainless pan will be expensive.\nBare copper should never be used for cooking. Copper is toxic in even small quantities, and if you cook in a bare copper pan, the copper will leach into your food. If the inside of the copper is clad with a non-reactive material (such as stainless), it makes for an excellent, although very expensive, pan. Copper is nearly the best heat conductors known \u2014 even better than aluminum, so a copper clad pan will heat very quickly and evenly, and will retain heat better than aluminum.\nAluminum makes for a pretty good pan. A well made bare aluminum pan can be very durable, and they\u2019re pretty inexpensive. Aluminum will heat quickly and evenly, but does not retain heat very well, so it\u2019s not a good choice for searing. It can be used with any heat source except induction. The downside is that it is reactive, so it shouldn\u2019t be used for acidic foods. It also can\u2019t be washed in the dishwasher, but must be washed by hand. It will not rust like cast iron, but food can stick to it. There were news stories several years ago that linked aluminum to Alzheimer\u2019s. Some people avoid bare aluminum for this reason, but subsequent studies have shown no link between cooking with aluminum pans and Alzheimer\u2019s. Aluminum can leach into your food, but you will ingest more aluminum by taking an antacid, so the risk is pretty low.\nAnodized aluminum (I\u2019m talking about plain anodized without a non-stick coating) makes an excellent pan for many uses. It has all of the benefits of bare aluminum, plus the anodizing makes the pan non-reactive, so you can cook anything on it. The anodized layer also prevents aluminum from leaching into your food, so these pans are completely safe. They can go in the dishwasher, but it\u2019s not really recommended. The are inexpensive, but very difficult to find. Food can stick to it, but not as bad as with stainless or bare aluminum.\nCeramic wasn\u2019t listed, but has a lot of advantages as a material for cookware. The most common is Visions by Corning, but even that is difficult to find. The material is very much like glass or Pyrex, but more heat resistant. These pans are very durable, so long as you don\u2019t drop them, in which case they will shatter into many pieces. They withstand heat and thermal shock very well, but I don\u2019t push it. I wouldn\u2019t take one of these pans from the freezer to the broiler even though the manufacturer says you can. I also wouldn\u2019t use them for high heat applications, like searing a steak. But they are very good pans for anything else. The glass-like material is pretty non-stick. I have cooked eggs on them without sticking, and if food does stick, a good soak in soapy water will take care of it. The material is completely non-reactive, so you can cook anything in them. They also go in the dishwasher with no problem. The biggest advantage is you can see through them, so you don\u2019t have to take off the lid to see how your food is doing. They don\u2019t conduct heat very well, so they\u2019re slow to heat up. They can be used with any heat source except induction, and can even go in the microwave. I don\u2019t know of any other pan that can both go on the stovetop and in the microwave.\nLast (and in my opinion, least) is non-stick pans. I\u2019m not a fan. The non-stick coating is too delicate in my opinion to make for a good pan. You can\u2019t use metal utensils (this is the only type of the pan in the list with that limitation), and even if you baby the pan it won\u2019t last very long. If you overheat it, the coating can release toxic fumes into the air. Again, this is the only type of pan with that drawback. All the others will last a lifetime as long as you don\u2019t abuse them. As for the non-stick properties, you can get nearly as good with a properly seasoned cast iron or carbon steel pan. I\u2019ve never had anything stick to either of them.", "Depends on what and how you are cooking. If you are browning meats, cast iron gives you a better result including all the bits stuck to the bottom which should be deglazed for a sauce. For a tomato based sauce, stainless steel is better. The acidity in tomatoes can ruin the seasoning on cast iron, but stainless or enamel lined cast iron are immune. Copper ok too but if you are using traditional tin lined pots don't leave anthing tomatoey in it long after cooking. It will ruin the lining. Copper or enamel lined cast iron not good for super high heat. That kind of heat can ruin both. Copper is good for moderate to gentle saut\u00e9ing, sauces, soups.", "I think that it varies depending upon the dish, but I do like cast iron for the way It holds the heat. Hard to clean. Stainless next for quick and easy.Dont use copper. Think it tastes.\nGennaro", "Personally I like anything that spreads heat evenly\u2026cast iron is great, stainless steel is bullet proof\u2026 some peeps like copper.", "I don't use copper at all. In stainless steel I cook the soup and in cast iron I cook the rice, couscous and slow cooking meat.", "For what? I only own cast iron frying pans so can\u2019t talk about anything else because I see no reason to use anything else.\nStainless steel isn\u2019t good for a frying pan unless it has a lot of aluminum or copper welded to it. Even then, unless it\u2019s a thick enough piece of metal, the stainless steel will get hot spots and it\u2019s not a good heat distributor.\nCopper isn\u2019t good by itself because it can react with foods, so you need to get it lined with tin or stainless steel, in which case it can be really good for a saucepan or a pot.\nStainless steel is good for pots that are going to be used for boiling water, simmering stews and chili, etc.", "Stainless is my go to cookware. It is easy to clean and acidic food like say with vinegar won't react with it. I also have cast iron skillets and dutch oven, it is quite heavy but nice to cook with.", "Copper as a cooking surface is toxic so I assume you mean copper as the heat distributing metal with something else as the liner.\nCopper with tin plating is too fragile for me.\nMy main set of pots and pans have copper cores with stainless steel inside and out. They are fantastic. Durable, efficient, great to cook with and easy to clean. Aluminum cores are also good but I prefer the copper (even though it\u2019s a fair bit heavier).\nI also love my cast iron skillets. They are also durable, efficient, and great to cook with. A quick rinse of the hot pan is usually all that\u2019s needed to clean up but if stuff gets stuck I just scrape it of with my steel spatula (don\u2019t do this with non-stick pans).", "This I a tough question as you will get so many different answers! The SS inside makes them so easy to keep clean too: Cons: expensive &cleaning\nmy day to day saucepans and deeper pans for stews, pasta or jam making, are all stainless steel (most are induction), they are durable, clean up well inside and out and don\u2019t react with any foods. It began to rust if not oiled. Pros: cheap to buy, took a lot of punishment. Which is perhaps the cheapest and certainly the lightest of the bunch.\nI have 1 small non stick frypan for eggs. I do not own any other. I did this as a kid with a kettle of my moms!", "I cook on a stove, I use cast iron and stainless steel pans, a lot depends on what you are cooking", "There are no bests as it depends on what you are cooking. Copper has advantages for some things, stainless steel for others, and cast iron for some things. Le creuset cast iron cookware combines the heat retention of cast iron with the nonstick surface of enamel. My favorite cooking utensil is a well-seasoned Drip Drop roaster made in 1913. It has fantastic even heat.", "Well that really depends on what you\u2019re cooking, and what flavors you\u2019re trying to achieve. I don't find any huge differences in taste or texture. The bread machine loaves have slightly less flavor because they don't rise as long as the hand made loaves, but that's not something that is really noticeable unless you compare the two versions side by side. In foods, seeds are the most common source material. However, there are also non-food flours, such as wood flour or rock flour.\nAll Purpose flour is flour that is milled from a combination of hard and soft wheats. The bran and germ are removed during the milling process, leaving the endosperm. Consequently, AP flour is predominantly comprised of starch and a limited amount of protein; usually 9.5% to 11.5% protein."], "topic_list": ["All-purpose Flour", "Cooking and Baking", "Starch", "Food Comparisons", "Flour", "Food Science", "Similarities and Differences", "Baking", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [89], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Lilly Vugheen", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What is the difference between starch, flour and all-purpose flour?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "128", "name_list": ["Paul McCool"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020"]}, "536": {"ans_list": ["Because the sugars in whatever food you have at a high temp will caramelize and turn brown. Add ghee and heat it for a minute. When ghee melts completely, add semolina (suji) and roast it well.\nWhile roasting the semolina (suji), stir it continuously until it gives out a nice aroma and turns light golden in colour.\nMeanwhile, take another pan and heat in on medium flame. Pour water in the pan and let it boil. When it comes to a boil, add sugar. Stir it well.\nWhen water mixture is ready, carefully add the roasted semolina in the mixture. One is the campfire method. If I\u2019m going car camping I take the pan with me. At the end of the night when the coals are low and glowing I turn the pan upside down and put it on top of the coals. I usually try to cover it with coals as well. In the morning it\u2019s a brand new pan. You need to wrap it up and keep it dry until you can season it as it will start to rust.\nNumber two involves an angle grinder. Ours is a hand tool like a sander. My partner showed me how to use it and we ground the rust off a cute little cast iron skillet we found. It turned out great. I re-seasoned it and it\u2019s one of my favorites now.\nI like both these methods because they take less skill and feel less dangerous than using chemicals and flushing them into the environment. I don\u2019t have a self cleaning oven so I don\u2019t know how well that works. It might be a good choice as it goes to a very high temperature.", "The best method is to use lye (aka caustic soda, aka sodium hydroxide). Fill a large enough basin with enough water to completely immerse the pan, add some lye, stir it with a stainless steel implement (lye will discolor wood and bamboo but not badly for a brief exposure), and leave the pan to soak for a few hours. The encrusted stuff will scrape off easily. If it\u2019s particularly bad it may take a second treatment.\nUSE CAUTION WHEN WORKING WITH LYE. It\u2019s very caustic in concentrated solution, can burn your skin, and is especially hazardous for your eyes. If there are other people in your household be sure to place a big obvious warning over the basin while the pan is soaking. I usually just draw a big skull and crossbones on a sheet of card stock and write LYE in big black letters with a Sharpie. Everyone in my family knows what that means.\nFor clean up you can flush it down the drain and rinse the pan, basin, and any utensils with water. Lye is also commonly used as a drain cleaner so in moderate amounts it will do no harm and may even help keep the drain clear.", "By any means necessary!\nSoak it in water, put it in the oven on self-clean (just be prepared for a lot of smoke) or throw it face down over a big pile of blazing hot charcoal. I've been known to take a circular sander to sufficiently messed up pans.\nThe underlying pan is virtually indestructible, so go nuts.", "Scour it will steel wool. The good news is, there\u2019s no delicate surface to worry about. Scrape up the brown bits from the bottom of the pot.\nPeel, chunk and add carrots, celery and onions. Include the celery tops, chopped.\nPut these spices in a tea ball: 3 tablespoons minced parsley, 1/2 teaspoon each of thyme and marjoram, a crumbled large bay leaf, 10 whole peppercorns, 5 whole cloves, 1 teaspoon salt.\nAdd more water or tomato juice if needed so everything is covered. No bouillon cubes or canned broth!\nBring to a boil, cover, reduce heat to low and simmer 4 hours or so. Be sure it doesn't burn \u2014 if it does, you will have to throw the whole thing out and start over again, because it will taste and smell godawful.\nAdd peeled and quartered potatoes. Russets have a great texture for this stew. Add almost a tablespoon of salt (the potatoes need a lot).\nWhen the potatoes are done, the stew is ready.\nCheater's way of slow cooking: After browning the meat, put everything together, including the potatoes. Bring it to a rolling boil. Put a lid on the pot and put it in the refrigerator. Leave it all day or all night. Mix together butter, salt, and white flour until they are perfectly blended into a breadcrumb like consistency. Add in the mashed potato and mix until well blended. Using your hands, roll dough into a ball, cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.\nNow that the dough is chilling, lest start on the filling:\nTrim the fat off the mutton and cut the meat into cubes. Put the meat into a pan along with the onion, garlic, rosemary and thyme and cook over a low flame. Remove fat from pan as you see it so it will not settle onto the food.\nClean and cut all vegetables.\nOnce the meat has browned add in all other filling ingredients from the list.\nLet it all simmer for 3-4 hours. Check the mixture every occasionally, and add salt and pepper to taste.\nLet the sauce reduce as much as you would like. The more it reduces, the sharper the taste will become.\nPour mutton filling into a pie dish and let stand while dough is rolled out.\nTake dough out of refrigerator and roll out with a rolling pin.\nOnce the pastry is rolled to desired thickness, cut out a circular shape big enough to fit over your pie dish with some to spare to overlap the edges.\nPlace your dough circle over the top of the pie dish completely covering the filling inside.\nPreheat the oven to 180 degrees C.\nPlace the dish in the oven and bake for 30 minutes.\nTake out of the oven when the crust is golden brown. Do this til you learn to cook.", "Yep, learn to cook.\nA bowl of cereal with milk doesn\u2019t require the stove.\nA peanut butter and jelly sandwich, no stove. For fancy PBJ I like putting the bread in the toaster. Watch the bread as it toasts in case it\u2019s set to incinerate.\nSpaghetti is easy. (Then I read all the instructions I just wrote so perhaps it isn\u2019t.) Put water in a pot, don\u2019t fill to the top, leave an inch or two, turn on the stove to boil the water. Find the spaghetti and read the boiling time. Some are 2 minutes, some are 12, read the package. Get maybe a bunch that\u2019s the diameter of a dime or nickel. When the water is boiling, really boiling, note the time, put in the spaghetti, and slowly push it down into the water (kind of like it\u2019s melting). Stir it occasionally to keep it from sticking to the pot. When times up, turn off the burner. Take the pot to the sink and slowly pour off a bunch of the water. Use your fork to keep spaghetti from pouring out. When the spaghetti really wants to escape, stop pouring out the water. Grab your bowl and use your fork to scrape the spaghetti over the edge of the pot into the bowl. If there\u2019s spaghetti sauce in the house, pour some on it and stir it around until it looks like the right amount. If no spaghetti sauce, add butter and salt. Add too little butter and too little salt and stir it around. Taste. Add more if you want it. Cheese is good, olives, I like avocado and chopped up nuts. Add whatever you like, you\u2019re the cook.\nNow, couple of iron clad rules. Never leave the stove when a burner is on. If you have to leave the stove, turn off the burner. Even if you are leaving for just a second, turn off the burner. It is SO easy to get distracted and melt a pot onto the stove.\nSecond rule, clean up after yourself. There should be zero evidence that you cooked (other than there is less food). Scrub all that you used and to really be good, dry them and put them away. Don\u2019t give your parents any reason to complain. Even better, clean the stove and counter top and put away the pot before you eat your spaghetti. Clean your bowl and stuff immediately after eating.\nYou can do this. My son watched YouTube videos and taught himself how to make rice (not as easy as it looks without burning it) and he makes the best Mac & Cheese in the house without using a mix.\nEDIT: My wife says, your parents are acting weird. Assume you\u2019re going to get kicked out when you are older and start preparing.\nYou need to get your social security card. You need a certified copy of your birth certificate. If your school does photo IDs, make sure you have a current one. If you can, snag a utility bill with your mom\u2019s name on it to prove your home address, or some letter addressed to you by your doctor. Read what it takes to get a state ID and make that happen. Save cash. If you are old enough to open a bank account by yourself and you have adequate ID, do it. Good luck to you.\nEDIT2: Whenever it seems reasonable in conversations with people toss in \u201cI think I\u2019ll eventually get kicked out of the house. Hope I can graduate from high school before that happens.\u201d If you do get kicked out, odds are a friend who\u2019s pondered your situation will convince their parents to take you in. Our son asked us to do that a couple of decades ago, she stayed for nine months, and we are doing it again with a friend of our youngest son, it\u2019s been a year and will probably be several more.", "\u201cPrepare\u201d compared to cook. to carrying Staphyloccocus Aereus. Beef has E Coli but that's on the outside of each cut. I've answered elsewhere about steak tartare and carpaccio. Also why hamburger less than well done isn't safe.\nMr Mcluhan explains why chicken contamination is more of a problem than beef.", "There are a few reasons but it mostly boils down to the fact that chickens are smaller then cows.\nChickens are kept in less sanitary conditions then cows (you can fit many many more chickens then cows in the same place), so the bugs which make us sick spend more time contaminating the bird when it's alive and when it's slaughtered the relatively tiny gut of the chicken is much closer to the flesh of the meat on the inside.\nCows by contrast are larger, do not spend their whole existence ankle deep in cow poo, and when they are butchered the meat that we consume is physically a longer distance from the contaminated surfaces of the skin and intestinal lining when compared to the chicken.\nIf chickens were cared for more individually, then the danger of eating it undercooked is minimal. It is our farming practices that make it especially dangerous."], "topic_list": ["Beef Steaks", "Beef", "Food Safety", "Chicken (food)", "Meat", "Eating", "Cooking", "Healthy Eating", "Nutrition", "Food"], "view_list": [242, 294], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Sam Jones", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "Why is steak safe to eat rare, but chicken isn\u2019t? When it\u2019s been soaked place two sheets of foil across the roasting tray both length & widthways place the ham in the centre & bring up the edges of the foil to seal the ham in a loose parcel. preheat the oven to 160c and let it bake for 20 minutes per pound, 30 minutes before the end of the cooking time remove the ham & turn up the oven to 220c now open the foil & transfer to a work surface, drain off the juices & reserve in a bowl for later use, next peel off the skin, now score the fat with criss-cross cuts creating diamond shapes, stud a clove into each diamond shape & using a palette knife smother with English mustard return the ham to the oven & bake for a further 30 minutes. People underestimate the value of a good sharp knife. A sharp knife causes less damage for the onion cells it works its way through and therefore means less tear juice flying in the air.\nDon\u2019t lean over the cutting board when cutting onions. Some people\u2019s onion cutting skills include putting their faces awfully close to where the juice flies up in the air. Position your head so you are not directly over the onion. Even move the cutting board an inch or two away from where you normally cut can make a significant distance.\nWork quickly. This is where the sharp knife comes in handy. The quicker you chop cool onions, the less likely you will get a face full of microscopic onion juices. That doesn\u2019t mean you shouldn\u2019t work safely - the old clawed knuckle trick works well on onions.\nThat said, another technique I use is to take a break halfway through. I do have the onion and, if I start to feel the sting of tears coming on, I stop and go do something else for a minute for the air to clear and come back and finish up.\nI do appreciate the onion giving up its existence for our sustenance but I really do not want to shed any tears over it.", "By a pair of inexpensive eye goggles that fully cover both your eyes and seal around your eyes. I bought mine at a harbor freight store, put them on before cutting a onion. No more tears.", "To chop onions without tears, first chill the whole onions in the freezer for 10-15 minutes to reduce the acidic, tear-producing enzyme they release when cut. Then, use a very sharp knife to cleanly slice through each onion, since the enzymes are released when the cells are crushed.", "You can try eye goggles and see if that helps", "How to Chop Onions Without Tears\nI have attached in the link above several techniques used to prevent the person from crying when chopping onions. That causes the shell membrane to let go of the white.\nIf it doesn't peel, re-shock it. Put the hard-to-peel egg back into very hot water for a few minutes. Take it out and immediately plunge it into ice cold water with ice cubes. After a few minutes, take it out. It should peel cleanly and easily.", "The question is oddly worded but I\u2019m going with \u201cwhy does the egg stick to the shell of some hard boiled eggs?\u201d\nIn my opinion, it has to do with how you cook the egg.\nIf you put the egg in cold water, then bring it to a boil, the egg white slowly solidifies and binds to the shell. On the other hand, putting an egg in already boiling water solidifies the egg white before it has much time to bind.\nAfterwards, if you take the boiled egg and place it in ice water, the egg contracts away from the shell, breaking any bonds it had formed.\nSo my recipe for hard boiled eggs is,\nbring water to boil\ninsert eggs gently with slotted spoon\nlet boil for 10min\ntransfer to iced water bath\nSometimes, when adding eggs to water, the shell cracks from thermal shock. The egg white can then force its way through the cracks. It\u2019s not really an issue for me, but to prevent that, add a bit of white vinegar to the water before boiling. The higher the protein content, the more water the flour will absorb.\nThis means you would need to use a little bit more AP than bread flour: for example, you could use 100 grams of water with 150 grams of bread flour to make one pizza, but you would need 160 grams of AP flour to get the same dough.\nAlso, it\u2019s very important to consider the timing: using AP flour you wouldn\u2019t be able to afford a long rising time, which is what improves the flavours of your dough. Let me rephrase here: you may let your dough rise for long time, but it will become very fragile and difficult to handle, unless you are experienced enough.\nHope this helps \ud83d\ude04", "Absolutely!\nThe difference between bread flour and normal flour is the protein content. Soup does not mean only the liquid part. In fact, some soups, like lentil soup, can be very viscous.\nItalian says \u201cpasta in brodo\u201d (noodles in broth), but again that translates to noodle soup in English. Interestingly, Italian also calls pasta served dry \u201cminestra asciutta\" 'dry soup', though this is now old-fashioned. The idea is that it's cooked in liquid, even though it's served without it. Zuppa, on the other hand, doesn't contain pasta, but is often served with a slice of bread (a sop, in archaic English) soaking in it.\nTerms like \u201csoup\u201d mean different things at different times and places."], "topic_list": ["Asian Food", "Noodles", "Soup", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [50], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 3, "question_author": "Patryk Chaou", "upvote_list": [1], "question_title": "Why do people (chefs and normal people alike) keep calling Asian noodles in soup \u201cnoodle soup\u201d? You dig it out of the ground they way one does with carrots. You wash/shake off the soil clinging to it and then you can proceed to eat it.\nGenerally most people use the garlic in cooking or preparing sauces/chutneys etc, rather than pop it directly into one\u2019s mouth and chew it. (there are some people who do eat it directly claiming it has some medicinal properties - but even that is unnecessary since garlic tablets/pills can be purchased.)\nThe green foliage/shoots can also be used in cooking. (One can buy frozen green garlic at supermarkets.) It adds a lot of flavour to a dish. We try to keep some in our freezer to use in some dishes.\nI can\u2019t think of many Indian savoury dishes that don\u2019t have garlic in them. Garlic is a pain to peel and not surprising various devices have been invented to help carry out this task. Of course some people avoid the problem by buying garlic puree in a tube. In Indian communities it is quite common to buy frozen peeled garlic (cloves) or frozen diced garlic. There are disputes about which is better to use. The prepared forms are not quite as good, but they are very convenient because they save time and don\u2019t give you smelly fingers. I peeled some garlic this morning just before I popped to the local supermarket. Even though I washed my hands thoroughly, there was still a slight whiff of garlic on my fingers an hour later!\nPeople in the UK 30 years ago were very garlic averse - particularly the older sections of the community. Do you hear what you're asking? Just buy bread flour.", "All purpose flour is not gluten free. All wheat flours have gluten. It's not possible to remove it all. But, bread flour is made with flours that are naturally high in gluten content. So, if you want as much gluten as in bread flour, you can add about a tsp or two of vital wheat gluten per cup of ordinary all purpose flour and your bread will rise a bit higher, provided you knead it long enough to develop the gluten.\nBtw, if you are changing a bread recipe to have some whole grain wheat or barley flour (whole wheat, white whole wheat, spelt, kamut, einkorn, bulghur, etc.) or some non-gluten flour (buckwheat - which isn't wheat -, teff, amaranth, millet, rice, oat flours, rye, nut or bean flours) all will give heavy, poorly risen bread unless you add vital wheat gluten, but in these cases, add 1 tbsp. gluten per cup of whole grain or non-gluten flour.\nAlso, it is possible to make breads using guar gum or xanthim gum or something similar instead of gluten to get gluten free breads, but in that case, I'm not an experienced baker so I suggest following a recipe someone else has worked out.", "I don\u2019t get it. Say, you walking into the kitchen and see a mess. Still, with your vision you can at least see all the outer surfaces within a second or so. Supposing, there are 3 tables and you need an aluminium kettle. Your sight has grabbed it and you\u2019re walking straight to that table or the cooker. As for me, I remember that the kettle tends to stand either on the cooker or on the dining table, most likely on the http://cooker.So\n, I\u2019ll come first to the cooker and will wave my hand over it in search of the kettle. If I can\u2019t find it, I\u2019ll go to one side of the dining table and start searching the surface further and further. If not, then I\u2019ll search the rest tables. And what if somebody put the kettle onto the microwave? 10 minutes may pass until I locate it there because not expecting to find it standing on the microwave, I\u2019ll look into the sink, then into cthe cupboards and check the dryer for any case.\nI think boiling is not that interesting. When I fry, I use a lifter and a fork or whatever to support the food from its upper side when turning it over. That\u2019s the way I can control it and be sure it won\u2019t fall off, thus I keep it between the lifter and the fork or whatever the item. I\u2019ve used butter for frying so far, but oil shouldn\u2019t be a big deal. You just buy a jar of a specific volume and a brush for cooking, no clue what that would be called inEnglish. You know the jar may contain oil for 3 times. You dip the brush in, then spread the oil over the cold pan, then put it on the cooker and so on.\nI can\u2019t use inductional cookers having no actual burners but spirals under the glass. I\u2019ve used only the gas cooker so far. In the very first one the autostart or what it would be called in English was broken, so I was advised on how to start it with matches. First, you light up a match, then really quickly put the box aside and open the gas so that it gets set to the minimum. Then make it burn using the match, blow on the match and turn the cooker\u2019s handle to set the strenght of burning as you wish. Originally, culinary terminology referred to meat derived therefrom. These days the word \u201cham\u201d is used to mean a meat product similar in taste and texture to that kind of ham. These days \u201cham\u201d can be meat from other parts of the pig and even from other animals, like turkeys. Other four-limbed animals, like humans, also have \u201chams.\u201d However, we don\u2019t usually call them that when we use them for food. I say that because I use Meyer Cast Iron cookware and their range come pre-seasoned, so you are set for at least two weeks.\nIn case your pan is not seasoned then do not worry, the process is extremely simple. The process of seasoning will remain the same for both old and new cookware, just make sure that your old pan does not have any rust on it.\nSeasoning procedure:\nWash and dry your pan well \u2013 Wash and scrub your pan well with warm soapy water and then dry it thoroughly.\nRub it all over with oil- Once your pan is dry and, rub it all over with cooking oil \u2013 do not forget to include the handle.\nHeat It in the Oven -Preheat the oven to 450\u00b0F and put the oiled pan in it and leave it there for 30 minutes\nRepeat 3 to 4 Times \u2013 Take the pan out after half hour \u2013 be careful as the pan will be hot. Rub the pan once again with oil, again just like before. Then put it back in the oven for another 30-minute spell. Repeat this process 3 to 4 times\nRestoring a rusted cast iron pan\nRust on your cast iron cookware is usually a result of neglect or moisture and is often called \u2018profile rusting\u2019. This type of rusting can be easily removed at home, all you need to do is follow the steps and you will be set.\nScrub the rust off - To remove all the rust from the pot or pan, use a fine steel wool. Scour your cookware until the area returns to raw cast iron\nWash the pan thoroughly- Once you have scrubbed the rust away, wash the pan thoroughly with a mild dish soap and warm water. You can even use a mesh sponge and bristle brush for those stubborn stains\nDry the pan immediately \u2013 This step is extremely important as moisture can really do heavy duty damage to your cast iron. Thoroughly dry your pan with a clean dish towel or paper towels\nSeason Your Cookware- This is also an extremely important step, in order to restore and maintain your cast iron cookware. Once you have dried off the pan, you season it using the technique given above.\nIn order to keep your cast iron looking spick and span, season it once every month."], "topic_list": ["Skillets", "Frying Pans", "Cooking Utensils", "Cast Iron", "Cookware", "Iron", "Kitchen Appliances", "Chemistry of Everyday Life", "Cooking", "Food", "Personal Question"], "view_list": [22], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Gaurav More", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "I just purchased a new cast iron skillet. Pizza dough needs to be proofed, and then hand stretched. It's possible the question is meant to refer to kneading, not stretching.\nDough goes through a number of stages when it is mixed. First, there is kneading, which creates the strong gluten network that provides structure and chew. It can be done with direct kneading, either by machine or by hand, or using the stretch and fold technique of no knead bread.\nNext comes bulk fermentation, sometimes referred to as proofing. This is the initial rest period, during which the yeast helps raise the dough, and enzymes released by the yeast help furthur develop gluten and flavor.\nOnce the initial fermentation is over, the dough is formed into loaves and proofed, until it is ready to be baked. In the case of pizza, if you watch them make your pizza in a restaurant, you will see that they have the dough divided into individual containers, sitting at room temperature. This is dough that has been through the bulk fermentation process, and then proofed as it waits to be stretched. As it waits, it is developing more flavor and relaxing the gluten, which allows it to be stretched to size without shrinking.\nSo proofing, whether done on a counter at room temperature or in a proofing drawer, is proofing. Stretching is the final shaping of the dough, after it has been proofed."], "topic_list": ["Pizza Dough", "Dough", "Pizza", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [123], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Chelsea Robertson", "upvote_list": [1], "question_title": "Is there a result difference between hand-stretching dough and using a dough proofer for pizza dough?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "280", "name_list": ["Beth Goldowitz"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020"]}, "353": {"ans_list": ["If you want to boil a ham before baking it is done sometimes to remove some of the saltiness created with the curing/brining process.\nsimlpy use a pan large enough to hold the ham and be covered with water, place ham in the pot/pan cover with cold water, place on heat and bring to the boil, reduce heat for 15 mins. They are called hydrogenated oils and are chemically processed seeds and beans. Unfortunately, they are a health risk because they oxidize easily and contain too much omega 6.\nAccording to WHO, those oils are responsible for 500,000 deaths annually.\nWHO plan to eliminate industrially-produced trans-fatty acids from global food supply\nNatural oils are better.", "Have you ever heard of olestra. It was a cautionary tale for the food industry.\nOlestra - Wikipedia\nTo a large extent many food oils today are \u201csynthetic\u201d if you use the word to mean manufactured and not occurring naturally. After we found out how bad trans fats from hydrogenated oils were, the food industry had to figure out how to replace it. Hydrogenated fats were the work horse of the food industry. By manipulating the starting fat and the amount of hydration we had an inexpensive supply of fats that could do just about anything we wanted them to do.For most applications, if you can't use oils in their natural state, people have gone to palm or palm kernel oil. Unfortunately these are extremely hard fats and don't always have a good mouthfeel. So the manufacturers have learned how to take the fatty acids off the glycerin backbone and rearrange them in ways that make more functional fats. It's not nearly as easy or as versatile as hydrogenating oils but it gets the job done.\nIf you mean starting with carbon, oxygen and hydrogen and building a fat up from nothing, the reality is that would be an energy intensive waste of time. We have billions of little factories that over time have built the prefect process of taking air, water and sunlight and efficiently producing oil. While they are doing that they do other things like taking CO2 out of the atmosphere and making starches and cellulose which we can also put to good use.", "Synthetic engine oils are not artificial oils at all. They are the equivelent of partially hydrogenated cooking oils. In other words it\u2019s regular engine oil with an extra refining step added. Refiners were actually amazed that people bought the stuff.\nThe word synthetic is meaningless when it is applied to engine oils.", "Synthetic motor oil is made from natural gas or highly refined oil. What would you make synthetic olive oil from? Highly refined olive oil?", "Olestra.", "Most likely - money issues. Do you have any idea how much oil producing people can loose if it is possible? You can do a few things to avoid it. First don\u2019t wash Aluminum dishes in the dishwasher, the environment in a dishwasher will promote oxidation. Next step is watch what you cook in these dishes, acidic foods will cause oxidation to happen faster. Lastly you can properly clean after each use, hand wash with a bit of scrubbing and some vinegar will clean off any mild oxidation that is starting to cause the darker spots on your sheets, if you stay on top of it after every use then it will never get too bad.\nNot really sure what your concern / dislike on oxidation and discoloration on these kind of baking sheets. Proper care and cleaning will avoid it and keep it from getting too bad.", "Have you been putting them in the dishwasher? That could turn them black. A lot of mine are very old and were passed down to me, and they are completely black. I just thought that they were well-seasoned, like my cast iron frying pan.\nI don\u2019t have any particular expertise in cooking, but I prefer cooking with the old, black pans.
