I guess it\u2019s just steel.\nEither kind is subject to rusting if you you completely degrease the pan.", "I have had the same set of aluminum baking sheets since, like, 2016, and aside from lines etched into them by my husband, who is a little heavy handed with the pizza cutter and doesn't always use the correct sheet for cooking pizza, they're in pristine condition.\nYou have to take proper care of them. If you take care of them, the only reason you might need to replace one is if there's a catastrophic cooking failure.\nDon't let them sit in water. Most baking sheets are actually two layers of metal with an air pocket inside. If you let the sheet sit in water, water will get into that pocket and damage the sheet from the inside out. It's better to hand wash them and let them sit to dry than to toss them in the dishwasher.\nIf they do need to soak for whatever reason, like you can't scrub the food off, put your oven on a low temperature and put the sheet inside for about ten or fifteen minutes; the low heat will evaporate the moisture.\nClean them after every use. Whether that means wiping out crumbs or scrubbing them, do it.\nFor easy cleanup, line the sheets. Aluminum foil and baking parchment are popular choices, and silicon mats are also a good choice. Make certain that if you choose parchment paper, that it's actually oven-safe; there are at least three kinds of kitchen parchment paper and only two of them are oven-safe. The other is not and will catch fire. It'll be marked on the box if you can put it in the oven. You should throw away the foil or parchment after use or wash the silicon mat and inspect the sheet for crumbs or grease.\nThat's really it. Don't let the inside get wet and clean them after every use and try lining the sheets.\nTo rescue an aluminum sheet, you can try several methods. Ketchup, baking soda and vinegar, and damp alum powder will all remove rust. Let the sheet sit with your choice of rust-remover, add some elbow grease, and you might be able to save the sheet. I don't recommend using something abrasive, like steel wool or a scrub pad, because it'll leave scratches; instead, just use a regular sponge or a dish wand or a toothbrush.\nWith that said, I believe I bought my aluminum sheets at Target. They came in a pack of three sheets in different sizes. They're lightweight and have held up extremely well. Unless I really screw up and char something onto them, I don't expect I'll have to replace them for several more years.", "I prefer stone. Does not scratch. Does not rust. It does get darker with use, similar to a well seasoned cast iron pan.", "Buy a Silpat, silicone baking sheet liner, or a box of parchment paper sheets.\nUsing one of those items protect the pan from caked on, baked on food and grease. It also makes clean up easier and your foods will never stick.", "Is there a good alternative to aluminum baking sheets? I want something that doesn't turn black after a short while. I've read that ceramic will break too easily.\nI\u2019m half tempted to not even bother answering this since everything I write somehow manages to violate Quora\u2019s alleged \u201cpolicy\u201d and Quora\u2019s alleged \u201cmoderation\u201d obviously doesn\u2019t understand the English language so here goes as this might well be the last time I waste anymore time trying to share information on Quora\u2026\nFirst off, I avoid using aluminum for cooking and baking, but, nonetheless, some of my baking pans are indeed aluminum. Aluminum is a unique metal which oxidizes almost immediately upon contact with air. Yup, that\u2019s right, it rusts really quickly and far faster than most any other metal. This is why if you watch welders working on aluminum, they\u2019ll clean the weld area immediately before running the bead, then stop to clean the next section before continuing to weld. This is because of how fast the oxides form on aluminum and those oxides are detrimental to weld quality just the same as they\u2019re detrimental to food and your health.\nThus, I never scrub any of my aluminum baking pans and I never use an aluminum baking pan until it\u2019s seasoned. Yes, you read that right, I did indeed say \u201cseasoned\u201d in the similar manner as one would season a cast iron or carbon steel skillet. I use an oil with a low smoke point for cast iron, but for aluminum I like using cheap oil despite my aversion to using GMO sourced oils for cooking, it works fine for seasoning be it vegetable, canola, corn or whatever. Apply a very thin coating of oil to the pan, I use a cotton rag. The place in a 500\u00b0F/260\u00b0C oven and let it bake until the oil has solidified on the surface. Repeat this process several times until the surface of the pan is completely covered with a tan-brown coating. At this point the aluminum has been fully sealed and will not come in contact with the food, not to mention it\u2019ll also be fairly non-stick as well especially if you apply a coating of fresh oil before using the pan. Sorry, I don\u2019t have a picture handy, but suffice to say that none of my aluminum baking pans are shiny on the food side, they\u2019re various shades of cured oil brown. - MarkKw", "I made a couple of pounds of croutons last night with some bread that was getting stale. Notice the baking sheet underneath.\nI made some oatmeal sugar cookies last weekend for my daughter\u2026 notice the baking sheet underneath.\nHere is one with some pies sitting on it. I used them to catch any liquid that would come out of the pies.\nHere is a round one I use for pizzas, breads, or just because I don't feel like using a larger sheet.\nI have had most of these pans longer than my daughter has been alive. They look this way because:\nThey are cared for.\nI know how to cook.\nPans don't get ruined because they are aluminum or ceramic\u2026 they get ruined because they are not cleaned or cared for properly, and you are doing something in your cooking process that you shouldn't be doing.\nYour best bet is to use some kind of foil, parchment paper, or any oven safe covering when using the pans. And even when you aren't covering the pans, like I did with my croutons last night, do not get the pans hot enough to cause ingredients or fats to get burned into the pans, ABSOLUTELY DO NOT EVER use any kind of cooking spray (which has polymers that act as glue when heated), and always wash and take care of your pans like a professional cook would.\nAlso, make sure any aluminum anything is washed by hand and never put it into the dishwasher. Dishwashers use oxygen to clean, which will oxidize your aluminum, creating a porous, rough surface that will make dirt easier to adhere to.\nIt is not only gross to see, but it is also dangerous. Those pans that turn black are turning that color because of years of built up grease, fat, food, soap, and haphazard cleaning, combined with bacteria and any cleaning chemical you used in the past. And every single time you use the pan, you not only make it worse, but all that gunk is leeching into your food.", "Look at Amazon. There are lots of alternatives out there, non-stick even.", "Why buy new pans at all? just line them with parchment paper when using, or buy Silpats sized to your needs. Worst case, baking soda mixed into a paste with white vinegar (and elbow grease) will bring almost any pan back to near new condition.", "I use stainless steel baking pans. They do need to be washed well, and scrubbed if you get them greasy. They might darken with baked on grease, but they shouldn\u2019t turn black.", "SILPAT baking sheets are great to use and will help a lot.", "error", "If your aluminium sheets are turning black then there\u2019s something wrong with your process, not with the sheets. I\u2019ve worked in kitchens for about 30 years now, and I admit I have seen blackened aluminium sheets, but never because of a flaw in the sheet itself. Either somebody burnt something on it, or it had been used for a long, loooong time for one task without proper cleaning. Even in those cases, a long soak and some stainless steel scrubbies were able to bring it back to good condition. I\u2019d recommend that you pick a good brand (I like Nordicware), wash more frequently, and evaluate the recipe, and oven, that you\u2019re using.\nThe image below is the result of a lazy dishwasher. If your pans look like this you might want to put them in the oven and set it to self clean. This pan can be brought back with elbow grease and scrubbies, but it will be a long job.\nThis one might just be a long roasting cycle. Here are a few guidelines on this\nNever use soap when cleaning your cast iron. This is the first rule of cleaning a cast iron pan. Soap will strip your skillet off the seasoned layer. Just use simple plain warm water to clean it.\nIf you cast iron griddle has stubborn baked-on stains use a sponge or plastic scrubber under running water. Make sure to do this when it\u2019s still warm. Once it cools down the food particles will be hard to come off. However, you may warm it up again , in the oven or on the stove top, if it is already cold by the time you get\nAn alternative is to slice a potato in half and use one half and kosher salt to scrub off the stains. Adding a few drops of olive oil to the kosher salt will help with lubrication of the scrubbing process. They are also a good source of dietary fibre, vitamin E, B6 and folate. The sweetness of capsicums is due to their natural sugars (green capsicums have less sugar than red capsicums).\nThe different coloured capsicum come from the same plant but have different levels of maturity. Green capsicums are harvested before they are fully ripe.\nYellow capsicums are more mature than green ones and have a fruiter taste whereas the red ones are the most mature and are usually sweeter.\nThe red ones have almost 11 times more beta-carotene and 1.5 times more vitamin C.\nThe best capsicum is Red Capsicum\nThey are the most mature ones with bright color and sweet fruity taste. We paid her salary in full.\nThe general rates in our retirement home vary from Rs 2000 for minimum work and time to a maximum of Rs 5000. There are some underlying life choices on your part which need rethinking in that respect, in my, not so humble opinion.\nA high quality end product mainly depends on the skill of the person making the product. The quality of the ingredients or raw materials might incrementally add or detract from the product, depending on what the product is.\nFor example: if one is making a Mornay, which is cheese melted into a Bechamel, which is milk added to a Roux, which is equal amounts (by weight) of butter and flour cooked together, it will, at any point, suffer from using top quality ingredients, except for the flour, because, the better the any of the other individual ingredient are, the more likely the Mornay is going to \u201csplit\u201d and be really gritty.\nThis is a wall really skilled cooks run into over and over again and the only way they seem to be able to conquer this by hunkering down and insisting on very specific ingredients and methods, where the real answer is to just use the \u201crun of the mill\u201d stuff where it\u2019s appropriate."], "topic_list": ["Quality Product", "High Quality", "Production", "Ingredients", "Product Design of Physical Goods", "Products", "Cooking", "Business"], "view_list": [12, 14], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Thao Dao", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "How do higher quality ingredients translate into a better finished product?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "147", "name_list": ["Erik H\u00f6rnfeldt", "Jan Verschueren"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"]}, "718": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Secret Recipes", "Easy Recipes", "Hoaxes", "Conspiracy Theories", "Baking", "Theory and Theories", "Recipes", "Learning New Things", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Alaca Tonightas", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What are some close to foolproof recipes for good conspiracies?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "324", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "129": {"ans_list": ["\u7cef\u7c73 Nu\u00f2m\u01d0\nYou may wish to note:\nIt is also called glutenous rice or sweet rice. The former is misleading in that the rice has no gluten, it is simply sticky\nSticky rice is not a different variety. It is simply a strain within a cultivar that has a very low or no amylose and very high amylopectin (starch). The sticky rice that Asia eats come primarily from the japonica, indica and tropical japonica cultivars\nChina is not the home nor the country that eats the most sticky rice. Sticky rice appears to have originated in South East Asia. The country with the greatest fondness for sticky rice is Laos. 80% of all Laotian rice is of the sticky variety (attempts to introduced other varieties failed because of this preference)\nThere are degrees of stickiness and these come with different characteristics. For example, Italian arborio rice starch has a creamy structure making it perfect for risotto and rice puddings. Spanish Bomba has less starch but can swell 3 times its size before exploding making it perfect for a paella. Japanese rice is less sticky but sticky enough to be made into balls or for sushi. Assuming that you are using all of those ingredients, except the cheese, you should be able to make a tasty basil oil, but not a real pesto. That's how it got its name; it calls for one pound of each ingredient. Most recipes also call for some sort of flavoring, such as citrus zest, citrus or almond oil, or an extract like vanilla.\nAny lift in the cake comes from air beaten into the batter. The eggs don't provide the lift, they set when baked to hold in air, which expands as it's heated. Early recipes called for a full hour of beating. Modern bakers rely on electric mixers, to do the job in far less time.", "If the ratio is 1 egg, to 1 butter, to 1 flour, to 1 sugar, you will be making a very small poundcake\u2026 which isn't designed to use or need baking powder because it is a dense cake to begin with.\nIf you are trying to make a cake with sufficient lift, use 10 to 20% less flour, 2 to 3 egg whites instead of 1 full egg, 10 to 20% more sugar, and then baking powder. Propane (LPG) stoves do not us a \u2018generator\u2019 because the liquefied fuel vaporizes in the tank at ambient temps. They have a pressure regulator that often doubles as an on/off valve.\nSince this question is a little nebulous and difficult to decipher, I\u2019ll add that there are electrical generators that are designed to run on LPG. Duck eggs are larger than some chicken eggs\n, but not by much. They are about the size of a jumbo chicken egg, slightly more oblong in shape, and have harder, off-white or grayish shells. The yolks are a deeper shade of orange gold than chicken eggs.\nPastry Chef Secrets\nHowever, where duck eggs surpass chicken eggs\nis in ice cream, baked goods and pastries. There\u2019s the total elapsed time from start to finish, but also how much of my time it takes. Some foods are the \u201cset it and forget it\u201d variety, like using an oven, slow cooker or a sous vide machine. This would be for a fresh (not frozen) bird. The timing is also affected by the type of turkey you\u2019re cooking. A bog-standard supermarket turkey will use these timings, but a free range or heritage bird may take slightly longer. The only sure-fire way to cook correctly is to use a low-cost cooking thermometer to check the internal temperature. You check the temperature in the thickest part of the thigh and breast. It should be 73C/165F. Then look for doubles, some countries might have the same national recipe. Specially if they\u2019re close to each other.\nThen study those recipes, how are they made? What ingredients do you need for them, and where can you get those ingredients? Then get those ingredients and start cooking, one country at a time.\nThere are currently 195 countries in the world, so if you would cook a different recipe for each country every day you\u2019d spend little over half a year cooking.", "Start alphabetically and work through.", "Hi RuDu, I would suggest a little online research, then identify national dishes from a list of countries. Italy - pollo cacciatore, France - Cassoulet and so on\u2026. Quite an endeavour! Good luck!", "New Zealand \u2018Possum Burgers\nFirst obtain your \u2018possum. Road kills (DIY for preference) are fine so long as no more than 2 days old and preferably intact. Hang, intestines retained, for a further 5 days. Skin carefully, discard guts and joint carcasse as you would a chicken.* Finely chop or mince thigh, belly and cheek meat together. Form into patties, season to taste and lightly flour. Leave aside while you render fat from remaining carcasse. Spoon two tablespoons of melted fat into a thick based skillet, cast iron is best. Lightly fry patties over a low heat, giving each patty time to absorb fat without browning. Turn up heat to cook until medium rare. A little blood is fine. Place each patty on to a chargrilled half bun with a little wilted lettuce, a small slice of tomato and a slice of tinned beetroot. Avoid garlic, pickles or other spices. Place other half of bun on top and serve. Be sure to have a camera on hand in order to capture your guest\u2019s facial expressions as they bite into this uniquely NZ experience.\n*Be sure to have a positive pressure oxygen supply and mask on hand for this part of the preparation. Scuba diving apparatus works well.", "With the ingredients you have\u2026 so probably Italy. If you\u2019ve never made an oil-based sauce like cacio e pepe then this could be great as you\u2019ve probably got things at last close to what you need in your cupboard. And it\u2019s delicious. Grazie Rome!\nAnother way to start is to check out a cook book you already have or a great, easy-to-follow cook online eg, Delia Smith. If it\u2019s a general cookbook (like say Delia\u2019s summer cookbook), flick through and see what catches your eye and that is not from your home country. Start there. Or google Delia French or Delia Greek and see what pops up. Start with the countries you know or whose food you have tried so you get used to following an unfamiliar recipe through to a semi-authentic outcome. If you\u2019ve had quiche Lorraine or spanakopita or moussaka before, then it\u2019s a good place to start because you know where you\u2019re heading. These are also great \u2018first\u2019 recipes because a ham tart or spinach pie or a kind of shepherd\u2019s pie/lasagna is familiar enough. And you\u2019re just adjusting to just a few, perhaps, new to you ingredients.\nSide note.. some out there may guide you to \u2018authentic\u2019 cookbooks and I say yes to that. Absolutely. If you are a skilled and experienced cook. I love Madhur Jaffray and she does write recipes for novice cooks, but she also writes recipes that, in my opinion, are best suited to professional Indian chefs. Love her, but some of her recipes would be terrifying for someone cooking Indian food for the first time. It\u2019s OK to google \u2018simple\u2019 along with a great chef from a country just to make sure you have a good experience. And read the whole thing to decide if it is \u2018simple\u2019 for you first. Like Martha Stuart\u2019s recipes\u2026 who has three days to make breakfast pastries? Not me for damn sure however amazing they look.\nAs your confidence builds, explore further and head to other continents\u2026 Thai curries, for example, are easy with pre-made authentic pastes, but maybe you want to start from scratch. Well isolation is both the perfect time to start curry cooking because it needs time, but also a bad time because all curries needs LOTS of ingredients you may not have or be able to source. The key is to not replace too many ingredients because then you may find you have strayed too far away from that country\u2019s food. Of course this is only true if authenticity is your goal. If fusion is your goal, go for it. Again, googling \u2018can I replace curry leaves with curry powder\u2019 will helpfully tell you why you absolutely cannot. Sherry and Marsala on the other hand, no problem. Moving geographically can also help because cuisines overlap\u2026 moving from French to Cambodian could work because they have an overlapping food history because of their history history, but it would be easier for a cook new to making food from this region to move from Cambodian to Vietnamese food\u2026 if only for reusing cooking techniques and ingredients.\nGood luck and have fun as you travel cook.", "Mexico! There are a lot of different pizza styles in the world, and many of them are tasty, but they're not NY pizza. And while it was brought to NY by Neapolitan immigrants, a NY pizza is not a Neapolitan pizza, though some people would like to think so.\nDo as little as possible, to the best quality canned, crushed tomatoes you can find. The flavor of canned tomatoes varies a great deal ftom brand to brand. People swear by San Marzano tomatoes, but the genuine article can be hard to find.\nThere are other good types of tomatoes, you just need to see what's available in your local supermarket, and find the best ones. I have the best results with California tomatoes. They should be tangy without bring overly acidic. Too much acidity is what tempts people to add sugar to their tomato sauce, which shouldn't be necessary.\nThe best NY style pizzas have a well rounded sauce that has a little bit of garlic, a hint of oregano, and a sweetness that comes from long slow cooking, not added sugar. I make mine in the oven, but you can do it on top of the stove. That's the secret, really. Don't mess with it, don't throw in a bunch of ingredients that don't belong, take the time to reduce and caramelize the sauce.\nThe other secret, of course, is to use a thin layer of sauce, fresh mozzarella, not the low moisture stuff, and no more than two toppings. It's not a meat eaters orgy of sausage, pepperoni, meatballs, and extra cheese. Its not a deep dish Chicago style pie, which is a wonderful thing in its own right. It's not a grandma pie. I am guessing most likely you are talking or asking stretchability.\nYes, Mozzarella cheese is designed for stretchability. Usually, Mozzarella is sold fresh within one week of making. And by the time Pizza Franchisee gets it often, it is ten days old for ideal stretchability.\nNow the most crucial thing: Cheese should not be too fresh, and it should not be old. In case the Cheese is too sharp, Cheese does not stretch when the consumer eats it. And if the Cheese gets too old, sure Cheese may pull more but the side effect, and cheese oils off on the Pizza. This oiling off is not a desirable defect.\nIn short, if the Cheese does not stretch, it is too young, and if it reaches too much and very runny. And on the Pizza, there are usually puddles of oil.\nI hope it helps.\nSam Arora, M.Sc. Food Science, U of Guelph, Canada, M.Sc. Most pizza places are happy to talk to you about what they do, just don\u2019t try to strike up a conversation at their busiest time.\nSome of the answers below give you good tips. Forget the stone, it won\u2019t get hot enough in a home oven.\nI can bake a pizza in under 2 minutes using a thick steel and the broiler, which is what you\u2019d get if you went out for a Neapolitan pizza and got a good one.\nBut you need to know what you\u2019re shooting for. If you don\u2019t like the crust you get that way, you might want to back off on the heat and add time. It makes a completely different crust just doing that. Ahi, ahi, ahi \u2026 *sarcasm*\nFood is always a one-time experience, it\u2019s like play music with an instrument: the score is the same for everyone (the recipe), but the execution is always different (the final product)..\nThere are a lot of different factors involved when you produce food and is really a miracle if you are able to reproduce exactly the same food everytime. Change a factor and the result will change.\nThink about the process of producing a pizza in a common \u201cpizzeria\u201d: ingredients (each with its quality, shelf date, conservation method and date, \u2026 do you use yeast, sourdough, prefab, \u2026 what? Capers come from? And mozzarella? Where does mozzarella came from? Not the same Targh\u2019s heart, Rokeg blood pie and Warnog \u2026 not today, please\u201d", "It can come close, if that\u2019s your ambition.\nSpelt flour is helpful. Yes, it will be a bit grey-blue, but the texture will be fantastic.\nNot too much sauce, which you must prepare youself, midway between a marinara and a spaghetti, or else buy a good jar of it.\nNor too much shredded mozzarella.\nLook to the pizzerias as your guide, less sauce and less cheese than you think.\nGo to town on the toppings, Bob\u2019s Your Uncle. But easy on the sauce and cheese.\nI have a pizza stone, that I use mostly for bread. For pizza, a big ole cast-iron skillet gets the great results. Put the pizza in it, heat on a hot stove until the bottom is golden brown, then transfer into a 475 oven until all golden brown and bubbly. That gets a GREAT pizza, in my book.\nIf you have kids, it\u2019s a Friday evening they will ADORE!", "I'm Italian American from the greater NY area and I've been eating great pizza for 55 years. My pizza at home is better than most, as good as some, and can't touch Brooklyn. Your problem depends on what's wrong and what you want. You need a crust recipe without too much yeast so your crust doesn't end up like bread. If you're looking for pizza hut style then maybe you do but that's an issue in itself. Next you need a sauce that tastes just right. I use my wife's marinara sauce with a bit of oregano. You also need to use the right amount of sauce something like 2/3-3/4 cup for a 14 - 15 inch pie. Next you need a good quality cheese, I like Poly-O. Finally you need high heat. Believe it or not most pizzerias do not cook in wood fired ovens at 700 degrees. The ones that do will produce a product that you will not duplicate in a home oven. Most independent pizzerias cook at 500 - 600 degrees and according to recent commercials little Ceasars cooks at 475 and papa John's cooks at only 450. My oven maxes out at 550. I preheat with my pizza stone inside for 45 minutes and then bake my pizza for 8 - 10 minutes and I get a nice char on the bottom just like my local pizzeria. I can't fix what's going wrong in your kitchen from here I can only tell you what goes right in my kitchen.", "Here are a couple of tips:\nFerment your dough. If you buy it pre-made, take it out of the bag the day before you need it. It should double in size. If it doesn\u2019t, you need to add some heat. I sometimes put mine in a bowl on top of the toaster oven covered with a towel and put the toaster oven on toast every few hours. Fermented dough is critical to taste. If you make your own, you can add lager beer in place of some water. The beer will replicate the fermented taste of quality dough.\nMake your own sauce, and don\u2019t cook the sauce before using it. Use canned San Marzano tomatoes if you can find them, or just Italian canned tomatoes. Add a small can of tomato paste. The sauce will cook on the pizza. Using jarred sauce will give you crappy pizza: you might as well buy frozen..\nOregano is critical to the pizza sauce, but don\u2019t overdo it. Add a couple of table spoons of good quality fish sauce, or anchovy paste to the sauce. Even if you think you hate anchovy, the best NY and NH pizzerias add this. Again, don\u2019t overdo it. Also add some good quality Italian Romano or Parmesan. I also add red pepper flake and garlic powder.\nHeat: use the highest oven temp you can get. My oven gets to 500F, and I preheat at least 20 minutes. If you\u2019re using a stone, preheat that at least 30 minutes.\nUse full fat cheese. Part skim isn\u2019t as good.\nIf you use sausage, don\u2019t use supermarket packaged sausage if you can help it. If you have an ethnic deli close to you, get your sausage there. Some supers carry good quality sausage, but it can be hit or miss.\nGood luck.\nQ: Why does homemade pizza never taste the same as pizza from a restaurant? Am I missing some secret ingredient or method?", "Just my opinion, I think the lack of their really hot, flat-floored oven. Their consistency - pizza after pizza after pizza - also makes a difference. Just my guess; someone out there who knows, I\u2019d be interested as well - I used to be a fairly good cook when I ventured into that kind of thing, and mine never tasted as good either.", "Well bear in mind it's not supposed to taste like a restaurant pizza.\nRestaurants' pizza ovens get far hotter than a conventional home oven ever could. Your best bet would be to use a pizza stone. Put it in the oven while it's preheating, and set the oven as high as it'll go. Give it an extra 10 or 15 minutes after it's pre-heated, just to make sure it's good and ripping hot. Then, use a pizza peel to transfer it onto the stone, or if you have oven gloves that can withstand the heat you can put the stone on a heat-safe surface for a minute to make the transfer a little easier.", "You will never quite match the restaurant recipe.\nI have made a lot of pizzas from scratch. You can get close.. you do not need a 650 F oven. 450 F does fine if you have a stone or ceramic in the oven to cook the pizza on.\nThe stone being HOT is important to cook the crust before the toppings burn.\nPreheat the oven at least 30 minutes to completely heat the stone.\nA good crust recipe\nA little oil on the crust top to prevent the sauce from soaking into the crust.\nThen a good sauce recipe\u2026\nAdd your toppings.\nBake at 450 F until the cheese is starting to brown a little.\nEnjoy.\nYou can pre-bake the crust to avoid the problem of getting the crust done before the toppings burn.\nThis is the basic idea behind the pre-baked crusts you can buy.", "I got an outdoor pizza oven for last Christmas and it heats up over 700 degrees in five minutes and cooks a 12\u2033 pizza in five minutes. We make our own dough and it comes out in everyone's opinion better than the pizza shops.", "Maybe not an ingredient, but a wood fire oven.", "The majority of it comes down to cooking method. Most residential cooking devices don\u2019t have the capability to get hot enough to re-create the cooking environment that is used in restaurants. After that it comes down to crust, then sauce, then cheese. It can take hundreds of trial and errors to find the perfect home cooking ingredients to make a delicious tasting pizza at home. Also, it comes down to expectations; you have to accept that fact that home-made is just not going to live up to your restaurant expectations, it\u2019s just the way it is.", "The big difference I found is the cheese. Are you using whole milk or part skim. Many grocery stores do not sell whole milk mozzarella cheese. Not in small cities anyway. All the national brands are part skim. That makes a huge difference. I finally learned that some of the mozzarellas cheese sticks are whole milk cheese and I grate those.\nI use 00 flour for my pizza dough which is traditional Italian. I asked when I was in Italy a few years ago.\nIf you live in a big city maybe you can find low moisture whole milk mozzarellas. I live in a small city. I recommend America's Test Kitchens, King Arthur Flour, and Google. While we all are at home, maybe you have time to call your favorite pizza maker and have a discussion about how they make pizza and what special ingredients they use.", "If you\u2019re after that restaurant-style of crust and cheese, then your problem is, as others may have indicated, the heat, or lack thereof. Home ovens simply don\u2019t reach the temperatures needed to cook pizzas like commercial ovens do. You want very high temps that allow for very fast cooking, and when you\u2019re baking at 350, that doesn\u2019t really work.\nThere is salvation. What we started doing recently is using a mix of a pizza steel and a pizza stone. The steel sits on one rack, and the stone sits on the rack above it. We then turn the oven onto maximum temperature (500 degrees), for an hour, so that everything can heat up. We then place the pizza onto the steel using a pizza peel (a fancy paddle thingy). The pizza cooks completely in 10 - 12 minutes.\nSee, by doing this we create what amounts to an oven inside the oven. It concentrates and distributes the heat, and makes for a really tasty pizza that\u2019s got a crispy crust and golden cheese.\nOther tips: make your own crust and sauce. Both are easy to do, especially the sauce. Simply mix a small can of tomato paste with half a can of water (adjust as needed if you want your sauce thinner or thicker), mix in some basic pizza seasoning (oregano, basil, Italian seasoning, red pepper flakes, whatever), and some salt to taste. Also you\u2019ll probably want to use low moisture, whole milk mozzarella. That melts very well.\nSo get the steel and stone. Together they\u2019ll run you a bit under $100. Once you\u2019ve got those, experiment a bit, and you\u2019ll get the pizza you like. Enjoy!", "It all depends on the temperature of the oven. Those at home never reach temperatures high enough to cook pizza in 3/4 minutes, as it should.", "You are missing only the knowledge that homemade food is not supposed to always taste the same. That\u2019s the beauty of it. If you prepare your own food at home it comes out different each time. Differences are based on the quality of the ingredients, slight differences in methods and procedures, slight differenes in cooking times and temperatures. Even the weather often makes your food different in a subtle way (or not so subtle whe we are talking about doughs).\nFood is an artisanal product, and the main quality of artisanal production is the fact that each item is slightly different from the other. Only industrially manufactured products are always exactly the same. This standardization introduced by industrialization is welcome in certain items (I am very glad to have a measuring stick that measures my centimeters and inches very exactly), but it\u2019s a defect in others. With homemade food, the variability is the key to learning to cook better, so that you can perfect your dishes to your teastes, but also customize them so that you will never get bored with your own food, as it\u2019s always different and unique.", "Your ingredients. At different times of the year and ordination of the fruits and veggies used will cause a slight difference in taste, but not so much that I have noticed.", "Why does homemade pizza never taste the same? Am I missing some secret ingredient or method?\nI\u2019m wondering why you think it should taste the same. Mine never does, but I don\u2019t expect it to. I don\u2019t much like takeout pizza precisely because it tends to taste exactly the same every time I have it. So I don\u2019t.\nUnless you use precisely the same ingredients on precisely the same crust every time you bake a pizza, it shouldn\u2019t be a uniform experience. Depending on the season, your veg ingredients should be different, or at least will be, because hothouse tomatoes taste different from summer ground-grown tomatoes, etc.\nSo unless you use a prepared crust, a bottled sauce, and exactly the same \u201ctoppings\u201d from exactly the same sources, and cook it exactly the same way, you shouldn\u2019t even expect that uniformity.\nThe beauty of homemade pizza is its versatility and the benefits that arise from high-quality ingredients. I only get pizza at good Italian restaurants (never takeout any more) because I\u2019ve come to expect a well-made whole grain crust, in-house sauces or pestos, fresh cheese, great olives, and in-season vegetables.\nYour pizza expectations seem to have been trained by chain stores or frozen labels, so it might be a good idea to become a pizza adventurer and break into new territory with new flavors, experimental crusts, and fewer expectations.", "Martin beat me to it. Heat is the answer.\nUse a pizza stone and heat your oven as high as it will go. Preheat the stone for at least half an hour so it\u2019s good and hot.", "Martin Bayer beat me to the answer. You must have gotten one where the packing house worker failed to remove them. Oops.", "I'm wondering if you are correctly identifying the kidneys. The kidneys, in chickens, don't look anything like mammalian kidneys. They're tucked into the small spaces in the bones of the back. You know that liverish tissue inside those little hollow areas of the back? Those are the kidneys.\nAre the parts you're calling kidneys just loose inside the chicken's body cavity? You might be looking at liver, gizzard, or heart.", "I\u2019m guessing you're referring to the packet of giblets that sometimes comes with a whole chicken or turkey.\nHonestly, I haven\u2019t seen a giblets packed with a chicken in a long time. Turkeys, yes, chickens, not so often. The giblet pack typically contains the neck, heart and liver of the bird. Cooks will use those pieces to enrich their gravies. You may have heard of giblet gravy. That\u2019s what that is, gravy with those giblets chopped up and serve in the gravy. I use the neck and heart to fortify the stock, from which I make my gravy, but I don\u2019t serve them in the gravy. I like it smooth, not chunky. I also toss the liver. It has no place in my gravy and what am I going to do with one turkey liver? Not really useful to me.\nKidneys though. I have never seen a chicken kidney before, let alone found one in a giblet pack. I\u2019m not sure anyone eats chicken kidneys. And it\u2019s the gentlest on your sharp/expensive chef\u2019s knives.\nSometimes if I\u2019m feeling lazy I dishwash it, but you should really wash the board by hand. And the knives, of course, never soak, never put in a diswasher.", "Wood. It is naturally antibacterial, killing many pathogens that cause foodborne illness within minutes once dry. The mechanism of how this works is poorly understood, although some believe it to be caused by essential oils in the wood, which does explain how the effect persists when the board is maintained with the proper kinds of oil. So you don\u2019t want to be using anything you\u2019d finish your porch with, any vegetable or animal oils (these go rancid), or any sealant, but good ol\u2019 mineral oil does the job, keeping the wood beautiful while prolonging its life.\nOf course you need to still wash the board properly to avoid drying it out excessively. This means hand wash only with a mild detergent and warm water. Don\u2019t throw it in the dishwasher and blast it for 15 minutes with a lot of heat and harsh cleaners.\nThere are countless studies on wood surfaces. A simple google search will turn a dozen. Wood also happens to be gentle on your knives.\nWhen it comes to high-volume environments where the proper care isn\u2019t always given, a high quality plastic board isn\u2019t bad. But this is only so if the restaurant or whatever routinely cleans the boards in the dishwasher and takes other steps to avoid cross-contamination. The dishwashing cycle actually does a decent job sanitizing plastic boards, but the boards should be replaced once they develop a lot of gouges.", "I use a plastic cutting board and bleach it afterwards. I rinse it well too.", "Believe it or not, a wood cutting board. BUT the wood surface has to be raw, not oiled, not coated with epoxy etc. So that let\u2019s out bamboo (which is a grass anyway.)\nTrees have spent thousands of years evolving to survive in a place where various and sundry pathogens (e.g. fungus, molds, bacteria, virus, etc.) also flourish.\nAbout 30 years ago I think it was the FDA did a study on stainless and high density plastic boards and they through in a maple wood board as a control. They then put listeria, E. coli, and salmonella on the three surfaces and measured to see how long the bugs survived. To the astonishment of the paper\u2019s authors wood killed off the bugs in under 24 hrs. Steel and plastic, depending on the bug, took as long 72+ hrs to become inert.\nPlease note this study was done with a hard maple board, a tree that is common in Canada and the northen USA. I do not know if it would extend to other species, although I\u2019d guess it would.\nThe real key though is RAW wood which almost no home owner permits.", "A wooden board is reliable", "The best surfaces to chop any food on would be Stainless Steel or Marble/Granite as those two are durable (won't easily get cracks or dents that could be home to hosting and growing bacteria) , and they're also easy to clean thoroughly.\nWood and plastic are the two worst. Home made is the very best, though!", "I make my own vanilla and consider it some of the best around. I produce a triple strength vanilla emulsion that is aged for 18 to 24 months using bourbon graded Madagascar beans and everclear. To be sure it is not cheap as a single 8 ounce bottle costs me around $50.00 to make. The closest equivalent to this is a double strength 12 month old commercial variety that will cost somewhere close to $50.00 but the depth of flavor and the rich and intricate nuances are not as pronounced or as deep. A bottle of commercial vanilla will usually have around 3 to 6 lower grade or red beans per pint of alcohol in their emulsions while I use an average of 15 black, high grade beans.\nYou can see that a homemade variety has the ability to be much better than a commercial brand. The making of vanilla extract is very easy and for something like the commercial product can be ready in just a month.\nMy variety.\n15 bourbon grade Madagascar vanilla beans\n9 ounces everclear or any beverage grade alcohol over 150 proof but preferably without any flavor.\nCut beans down the center then into 1 inch long pieces. Put everything into a dark colored glass vessel with a sealable lid and shake vigorously for a minute. Repete the shaking a couple times a day for a week then once a week give it a good shake for a couple of months. After that monthly agitation and inspection is fine. At the end of 18 months or more drain into a sieve and to reduce the amount of solids.\nCommercial grade homemade\n6 red or processing grade vanilla beans cut up into 1 inch pieces.\n9 ounces of vodka\nLike above, put everything in a jar and seal it up. Shake it daily for 2 or 3 weeks then every other day for another 2 or 3 weeks. Drain the contents through a sieve and rebottle for use. This will produce 8 ounces of very \u201cbetter than the store\u201d vanilla for under $10.00.", "Be sure to use real vanilla extract and NOT vanilla essence. Vanilla essence is almost always not vanilla extract; it is a chemically produced replica. You can make your own but if you buy the real thing there is no need!\nSee here for lots of information on vanilla in various forms and how to use them."], "topic_list": ["Vanilla Extract", "Vanilla", "Homemade Items", "Spices", "Flavors", "Baking", "Taste (sense)", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [1, 131, 115], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Jim Davis", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 0], "question_title": "What's the best tasting vanilla? Is homemade better?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "644", "name_list": ["John Long", "William Chambers", "Suzy Bowler"], "date_list": ["Apr 18, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "93": {"ans_list": ["The day before or in the morning if baking in the evening.", "I feed my starter for baking about 24 hours before I want to use it. This timing will vary slightly, but it is a good gauge for developing a rythme with your starter and bread making.", "Can we please agree that we talk about a sourdough starter or a sourdough culture? The \u201csourdough\u201d is the next step when you use the starter to prepare a pre-dough. So the workflow is: Feeding Sourdough starter/culture - preparing the pre-dough called sourdough (dough!!!) - preparing the main dough.\nSince there is no one sourdough culture this is impossible to answer. Every sourdough culture is different,contains a mix of different microbacteria, is held at a different temperature and has different moisture levels.\nI always tell people sourdough culture is a living thing. We need to feed it, keep it warm and take care of it. You need to get to know your sourdough. Watch it. When it starts being active it will rise, eventually it will stop and then fall back down. When it is on top it is most active and then you should use it. So the time between when you fed it last and when it reaches the highest level is the time you should feed it before you use it.\nI keep my sourdough culture in the fridge when I don\u2019t bake. I take it out of the fridge the night before I prepare the pre-doughs. The next day I feed it at 11am and then again at 4 pm. Then I prepare the sourdough pre-doughs at around 9pm and they ferment overnight. I start baking at 6 am the next day. This is my schedule, yours could be completely different."], "topic_list": ["Sourdough", "Bread Baking", "Bread", "Baking", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [1, 76, 228], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Charles Raisor", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "question_title": "When should you feed sourdough starter before baking?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "860", "name_list": ["James Lovette-Black", "Lynn Marinaro", "Peter Niepel"], "date_list": ["Apr 20, 2020", "Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"]}, "40": {"ans_list": ["If your two options are soy butter and olive oil for baking veggies, I would suggest you to stick to olive oil. Grind up (or dice fine) the Pork Chop and reheat it gently at the last minute in a gravy, sauce, stew, or soup. Do NOT cook it through, again, by throwing it in at the beginning of your new dish. Just throw it in at the very end to heat it up to serving temp on the way to table.", "It won't help too much unfortunately. I can think of only 2 ways that might.\nBraising or stewing. But as it's a single pork chop, that might be a bit too much work for too little.\nSlicing it into thin strips and then cook it in the gravy or a liquid .\nThis will give it back some of the moisture, but there's not much you can do to restore it completely.\nBut as I said, that\u2019s a LOT of work for too little a gain.\nAnother option I might suggest is make Chinese fried rice.\nYou'd cook the pork chop in the rice TWICE, once when making the rice to let the fluids hydrate it, and a second time when stir frying the rice.\nAll you need is a cup of rice, an egg or two to scramble and mix with the rice, and the chopped up pork chop with some chopped up veggies to mix with all together in the stir-fry with salt or soy sauce to taste. This way, the chop, even dried up, will actually enhance the dish. Everything else which they add onto the bread have become extra for them. BUT here is where things changes. Overtime, the use of bread become less and less importance and the use of extras started to become more important to the point that it is bread that is an extra nowadays.\nOver the time, this developed into fast food like burgers, taco, steak etc where bread itself could be eliminated from the diet altogether.", "Completely different lifestyles and access to quick food. The majority of this work is done by women and teenage girls. I mean it\u2019s bean dip, why complicate things with dried beans.\nSo, dice an onion, a clove of garlic and a jalape\u00f1o. Chop some cilantro and cut a wedge from a lime. Open and drain a couple of cans of black beans.\nNow heat some olive oil in a pot and start to saute the onions. Get them to the point where they are slightly caramelized and add the garlic. Cook them for a minute longer and add the minced jalape\u00f1o, some cumin and coriander, salt and pepper. Cook the mixture for a minute longer and pour in your beans. Wet them with chicken broth and bring it to a boil. Cook the beans until they are heated through and begin to burst a little. They should be almost dry at this point.\nTransfer the beans to a food processor and puree until smooth. Pour the bean puree into a bowl and cool completely. Drain & rinse one can of beans \u2014 I like white beans (cannellini or navy beans work well). Place them in a blender or food processor and blend or process until smooth with spices, herbs, and liquid of choice (there are many ways to go here). A deceptively simple strategy is olive oil + lemon juice + salt + pepper + herbs. I like to smash a clove a garlic with 1/2 tsp of salt, place that in 1/4 cup of olive oil, gently heat for a couple minutes, strain atop beans in blender, give it a quick whir, squeeze in half a lemon, give it a couple generous grinds of black pepper, and blend until smooth. You can the add up to a tsp of dried or a tbsp if fresh herbs (I usually use Italian parsley) and either blend quickly or mix with a rubber spatula. Taste to see if it could use more sat and, viola, you\u2019re done. It\u2019s great immediately, or you can refrigerate for a couple hours or overnight. Jenkins is a so called CI/CD (Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery) server, Chef on the other hand is a software configuration solution. Both together can take your software and turn that into a running server.\nJenkins is essentially a means to automate tasks. These tasks were traditionally focused on building software. This is taking the source code and turning that into an executable (very roughly and lacking nuance). From there on it made a lot more generic and you can use it to automate all sorts of tasks. Including for example rolling out a server with that executable.\nThis is the place where Chef takes over, when you create a server this is usually empty, it\u2019s not configured, certainly not configured in the way you\u2019d need it to run the executable you\u2019re working on. Chef is able to automatically configure the server, installing the right users, firewalls and software packages that your executable might need as well as installing, configuring and running the executable itself.\nJenkins knows various different alternatives, from GitHub Actions to Gitlab, Atlassian Bamboo and many others.\nChef too knows various alternatives, must notably Ansible is popular these days with many similar alternatives such as Puppet, Salt and here too many others."], "topic_list": ["Chef (Automation Platform)", "Jenkins", "Jenkins CI", "Continuous Integration (CI)", It's a seed that grows\u2026", "Oranges contain quite a high proportion of sugar. Sugar makes them taste sweet. Oranges grow like that on trees.\nThe tree makes the sugar by a process called photosynthesis. Photosynthesis is quite complicated and from your question I don\u2019t think you will be able to understand it yet.\nOranges are not made by people.\nOranges have probably become sweeter over many centuries by a process called selective breeding. This means that people keep the pips from sweet oranges and use them to grow new orange trees. They do not grow seeds from this pips of oranges that do not taste sweet. This means that the tress with sweeter oranges have more chance of passing on their genes for making lots of sugar and putting it in the fruit. You would have to do this many, many times to get a tress that had sweeter oranges.", "Oranges can be naturally sweet.", "No one \u201cputs\u201d anything inside oranges to make them sweet.\nOranges are naturally sweet straight off the tree because of their high fructose content. (I roast my ham at 325 degrees, by the way)\nThe best way, in my experience, is to place the ham flat side down in a 4\u2032\u2019 roasting tray with a lid.\nIf you do not have a lid for your roasting tray, buy oven bags. Reynolds are the best, in my opinion. They are the right thickness and aren\u2019t too small. They retain heat and stay perfectly sealed with the zip-ties that are provided.\nAnywho, I cook ham in a 325 oven for 10\u201312 mins per pound.\nIf you are glazing your ham, you will want to crank your heat up to 425 when there is only 10 minutes left of cook time. Ham Roasting 101\nHope this helps because I get a perfectly tender ham every single time.\nEnjoy, guys.", "Simmering probably won't help, just over cook it even more. Cooking can't be rushed without penalty. Lesson learned for next time.", "It won't toughen it any more, but it might not remoisturize it much, either.\nI wonder if you are confusing toughness with dryness. Many people do. How long did you cook the ham? It may need to be cooked longer, with additional liquid, in order to become tender in the first place. 300\u00b0F isn't excessively high. It's on the low side, I cook most meats at 350\u00b0. Collagen tissue is a big part of what makes meat tough. Collagen begins to melt at 180\u00b0F. Most people cook meat only to 160-165\u00b0F, the temperature at which it's considered safe, but that's not the optimum temperature to make it good. Higher internal temperatures make it tender, and develop the flavors more. You don't need or want a higher cooking temperature, you just have to give it more time. You can cook it at 200\u00b0f, and it will eventually reach an internal temp of 180\u00b0f.\nIf you use a meat thermometer, and cook a ham until it reaches an internal temperature of 180\u00b0F, and hold it there for at least 20 minutes, it will get tender, unless it really has dried out. Usually it hasn't. Ham contains a lot of salt, which tends to make it hold onto water.\nI'd put it back in the pan, add a couple of inches of water, put a lid on it, and stick it back in the oven for a couple of hours.\nIf this ham is already sliced, you might try simmering one or two slices for awhile, anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour, (don't let it boil dry) and see what happens.", "It will help tenderize it; this may also draw out the saltiness. In US markets, hams sold are already cured, using smoke and salt. There are two other options that I have used with mixed success, but they do work once you get the timing down.\nYou can steam the ham, which works quite well the add water to it. If you have a steaming basket that you use for vegetables, just follow that same procedure with ham instead of veggies.\nThe other option is wrap a few slices in a moist paper towel and microwave it for 30 seconds or so. Precise timing depends on your microwave. This trick has been around for decades regarding making stale bread fresh again. I discovered it works for ham too.\nI never hurry my ham nor any other of my meats. Now you know why. However, I have been at the homes of others who did overcook their hams. Once, figuring we had nothing to lose, I suggested we give a few methods a try. Steaming and \u201cnuking\u201d worked best.\nBy the way, save those juices, the rich pot liquor it can be used in so many ways."], "topic_list": ["Ham (food)", "Food Chemistry", "Juice and Juicing", "Food Science", "Meat", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [141, 7, 120, 134], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "Judy Novak", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 2, 1], "question_title": "Yesterday I hurried our glazed ham by roasting at 300'. The amount of chicken will probably stay the same.", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "218", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "642": {"ans_list": ["People say you circulate water so the average temp comes back below boiling, and this is probably true. Another explanation is that \u201cboiling\u201d as in the bubble coming out of the water are dissolved gases coming out of the water. As you stick something in, bubbles form on it before rising, so it temporarily stops releasing gases.", "The liquid in the pot on a typical stove is not being heated evenly. The hottest spots start boiling first. If you stir the liquid, you disperse the hottest water around the pot. The temperature equalizes at the previous average temp in the port. So you won\u2019t see boiling until the hot spots reach boiling temp again.\nOnce the whole pot in boiling, you can stir all you like and it will continue to boil because the average temp throughout the liquid is boiling.", "That's a very good question.\nFor this we need to understand what is boiling process. As we have seen many times,\nBoiling of water or any liquid is a process of phase change of matter from liquid to gaseous state. The changing of phase requires energy we call it latent heat of vaporization. So when you see next time boiling water observe properly it requires continuous supply of heat either by gas berner or any other source.\nNow,\nIn the above picture you can clearly see, when water boils, where the bubbles are coming from?\nWell, from the bottom, right?\nThat's because heat is being transferred from there.\nNow if you stir the water when it's boiling the particles of water in contact with bottom of container ( from where it's getting heat) move away, and transfers heat to other water particles. And in their places new particles of water come. This process continues till water being stirred."], "topic_list": ["Boiling", "Physics of Everyday Life", "Cooking"], "view_list": [7, 25, 29], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Manny Santos", "upvote_list": [0, 2, 1], "question_title": "Why does stirring something make it stop boiling?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "550", "name_list": ["Andrew Quinlan", "Louis Cohen", "Gaurang"], "date_list": ["Apr 21, 2020", "Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"]}, "576": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Whipped Cream", "Canned Foods", "Food Safety", "Dairy Products", "Milk", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Why does canned whipped cream last for months but whipped cream not in a can go bad within days?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "153", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "676": {"ans_list": ["Samosa at home recipe is explain well here as you can see this.\nSamosa Recipe | Samosa | Spicy Samosa | Halwai Style Samosa Recipe | Tasty Samosa\nCheck out my new youtube channel for new recipes\nAnju's Universe", "Ohhh\u2026samosa!! It will probably benefit from sweetning, sugar or sweetner.", "If you want it to taste good, you're going to have to add a lot more stuff than just yogurt. Freezing yogurt will give you an icy mess.\nHere's my favorite base recipe from Jeni Britton Baurer. This isn't flavored, it's straight frozen yogurt. You might want to add some vanilla. To make lemon or lime, make a syrup of 1/2 cup juice and 3 tbsp sugar. Bring to a boil to dissolve the sugar and cool. Whisk it in when you whisk in the reserved yogurt at the end of the recipe.\nFrozen Yogurt Base:\n1 quart plain low-fat yogurt\n1 1/2 cups whole milk\n2 tablespoons cornstarch\n2 ounces (4 tablespoons) cream cheese, softened\n1/2 cup heavy cream\n2/3 cup sugar\n1/4 cup light corn syrup\nIn advance: For the frozen yogurt base: Fit a sieve over a bowl and line it with two layers of cheesecloth. Pour the yogurt into the sieve, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for 6 to 8 hours to drain. Discard the liquid, and measure out 1 1/4 cups of the drained yogurt; set aside.\nPrep\nWhisk the cream cheese in a medium bowl until smooth.\nFill a large bowl with ice and water.\nCook\nCombine the remaining milk, the cream, sugar, and corn syrup in a 4-quart saucepan, bring to a rolling boil over medium-high heat, and boil for 4 minutes. Remove from the heat and gradually whisk in the cornstarch slurry.\nBring the mixture back to a boil over medium-high heat and cook, stirring with a heatproof spatula, until slightly thickened, about 1 minute. Remove from the heat.\nChill\nGradually whisk the hot milk mixture into the cream cheese until smooth. Add the reserved 1 1/4 cups yogurt.\nPour the mixture into a 1-gallon Ziploc freezer bag and submerge the sealed bag in the ice bath. Let stand, adding more ice as necessary, until cold, about 30 minutes.\nFreeze\nRemove the zest from the frozen yogurt base. Pour into the frozen canister and spin until thick and creamy.\nPack the frozen yogurt into a storage container, press a sheet of parchment directly against the surface, and seal with an airtight lid. Freeze in the coldest part of your freezer until firm, at least 4 hours.", "I have done this, but it takes monitoring. While the answer from Coleman Grey mentions having it lose its liquid, there is also the problem of overcooking it without the loss of liquid. I accidently had this happen once, when I got stuck in traffic trying to manage my afternoon 38 minute commute, only to be about 1/4 mile behind a wreck on the Interstate and was stuck for 2 hours. My wife didn\u2019t get home until about 2 hours after my usual return, so she and I arrived within minutes of each other. I had set the cooker up with a delay timer that morning, and it cooked on high for a while, then reduced to low, but instead of having it go to hold/warm, I left it at that because I would be home in time to check and see if it was done. Great plan! When I opened the lid, it wasn\u2019t ruined, however, the vegetables were an indistinguishable mush, and the roast was falling apart so badly I had to use a slotted spoon for get some of it out of the cooker. I didn\u2019t need to make pulled beef. It fell apart into small pieces with just a touch of a spoon. I kept the meat in an airtight container and we ate carryout that night. The next night, I made a spicy sauce, toasted some large buns and we had sandwiches from the beef. I had drained well. It tasted okay, but on the bland side. The sauce helped, but I decided that I would, from then on, set my slow cooker timer to be done two hours after I got home, instead of just after my arrival. There are actually two versions of pasta alla norcina. This one is made with Norcia sausage crumbled into a pan with oil and onion, fresh cream, truffle and pecorino.\nThis is a very simple recipe with few ingredients but so flavourful and creamy you\u2019ll want to make it part of your regular pasta menu.\nRemove the casing from the sausages and crumble the meat filling. Peel and chop the onion finely. Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the pasta, add salt and bring to the boil again. Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat. Add the onion and cook until soft then add the crumbled sausage meat. Brown the sausage, while stirring to prevent it from sticking. Pour in the wine. Allow the alcohol to evaporate (while stirring). Lower the heat, cover, and finish cooking the sausage in its own juices for 10 minutes. Uncover, taste and season with salt and pepper as required. Pour in the cream and bring the sauce to a gentle simmer. Add a few truffle shavings and half the pecorino. Reduce the sauce for 3\u20134 minutes, then turn off the heat, cover and set aside. Cook the pasta in the salted boiling water until al dente. Save some of the pasta cooking water and drain the pasta. Add it to the pan with the sausage and cream sauce. Over a low heat, mix the pasta and sauce together. Serve with a generous sprinkling of grated pecorino, some freshly ground black pepper and truffle shavings.\n400g pasta, 2-3 Italian pork sausages, 1 onion white or yellow, 1-2 black truffle, 200 ml fresh cream, 1/2 glass white wine, 50 g pecorino cheese grated, 3-4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil, salt for pasta and to taste and black pepper.", "I made hot x buns for easter\nWhen I lived in the US, I couldnt find them so I started making them. Chronic poor nutrition leads to an eventual loss of appetite. That loss of appetite eventually leads to starvation. Spicy food stimulate the appetite, helping to avoid starvation. Think about it, in what areas of the world do you find spicy foods?", "Partly. It\u2019s also partly based on early modern Spanish recipes and styles of cooking, which are in turn heavily influenced by Medieval cooking from the Muslim world, which had access to a variety of spices from across the Old World. The use of spices like black pepper, coriander, and cumin [1], wheat, sugar, most animal and animal-based ingredients (beef, chicken, pork, chicharones, queso, etc.), and techniques like frying and baking come through Spain.\nThis one\u2019s particularly weird. Cumin is mostly found in Mexican culinary traditions in the north, which is more or less what we now call Tex-Mex. That region saw a number of crypto-Jews who retained aspects of their religion and culture and wanted to get as far away from the emphatically anti-Semitic Spanish crown as possible, so they settled well up into what\u2019s now the American Southwest. And part of their culinary tradition involved, among other things, heavy use of cumin not found too often in more southerly regions.", "The key word here is \u201cbased\u201d. Ingredients like corn, beans, squash, tomatoes, potatoes, chili, were all pretty common in meso America. Meats (beef, lamb, pork, chicken were not) however there was wild game.\nFlat breads, aka torillas were likely very similar to what is available today, but wheat baking was introduced first by the Spanish, then by the French.\nJust as importantly there was no dairy, so cheese, sour cream, buttermilk, butter, milk or cream were not a commodity. So no queso, no enchiladas, no quesadillas.\nSo if you go back to the \u201cbasics\u201d the food was \u201clike\u201d today's food but different.", "it is based on the ancient method of trying to mask the taste of spoiled meat"], "topic_list": ["Food in Mexico", "History of Food", "Spicy Food", "Mexican Food", "Mexicans", "Cuisine", "Mexico", "Ancient History", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [11, 25, 627, 60, 2], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 3, "question_author": "LJ Blake", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 20, 4, 0], "question_title": "Is the complex and spicy modern Mexican food based on ancient Mesoamerican recipes and styles of cooking?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "1,103", "name_list": ["Gerardo Gold", "Charles Neilsen", "Matt Riggsby", "Bruce Byers", "Paul Friend"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"]}, "582": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Glow Sticks", "Phosphorescence", "Glow", "Do It Yourself (DIY)", "Recipes", "Skin", "Skin Care", "Dermatology", "Cooking", "Food"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 14, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Purusothaman P", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Is a glow recipe good?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "70", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "33": {"ans_list": ["I am just dancing in my kitchen creating as I go. On adding water it produces carbon dioxide gas and an alkaline solution. It is used as a remedy for acidity and gas accumulation in the stomach. Can be used in food preparation also.\nBaking soda is a single compound of Sodium Hydrogen Carbonate. On heating, it produces Carbon Dioxide and an alkaline solution. In fact, my husband can have eggs for breakfast, dinner as well as lunch. So I am sharing two of my all-time favourite recipes. One is from my mom and the other is a recipe I learned while I was travelling to Kerala.\nHope you like both of them.\nKerala Style Egg Curry\nINGREDIENTS\n5 Hard Boiled Eggs, peeled\n1 tablespoon Coconut Oil\n1 teaspoon Mustard seeds\n1 Cinnamon (small stick)\n3 pods Cardamom\n5 Peppercorns (lightly smashed)\n2 \u2013 3 Green Chillies (slit lengthwise)\n1 teaspoon finely chopped Ginger (or ginger paste)\n7 Garlic cloves (smashed and roughly chopped) or garlic paste\n2 medium sized Onions (finely chopped)\n3 large Tomatoes (finely chopped)\n1/2 teaspoon Turmeric powder\n1 teaspoon Coriander Powder\n1/2 teaspoon Chili Powder Red\n1/4 cup Tamarind Water (See Note 2)\n1 cup thin Coconut Milk (See Note 3)\n1/2 cup thick coconut milk\n8 \u2013 10 curry leaves\nSalt to taste\nINSTRUCTIONS\nIn a large pan, heat coconut oil and add mustard seeds, cinnamon, cardamom, peppercorns and green chilies. Once everything starts spluttering, add ginger, garlic and onions.\nCook till the onions turn soft and translucent and add tomatoes, turmeric powder, coriander powder, chili powder and salt. Let the tomatoes cook till they are pulpy and add tamarind water and thin coconut milk.\nStir and bring this to a boil. Simmer till the gravy reduces slightly and becomes thicker. This will take about 5. At this point, add some water if you need to adjust the consistency.\nAdjust seasoning, add curry leaves and pour in the thick coconut milk. Stir a few times, without letting it come to a boil and switch off the flame. Drop the eggs in the curry, and cover and let it sit for five minutes before serving.\nMy Mom\u2019s Egg Curry\nIngredients\n6 hard-boiled eggs\n5 tbsp. cooking oil (vegetable, canola, or sunflower)\n2 medium-sized onion (cut into quarters)\n3 medium-sized tomatoes (cut into quarters)\n2 green chilies\n2 tsp. garlic paste\n2 tsp. ginger paste\n2 tsp. coriander powder\n1 tsp. cumin powder\n1 tsp. garam masala\n1/2 tsp. turmeric powder\n1/2 tsp. red chili powder\nSalt to taste\nOptional: 2 potatoes cut into 1-inch cubes\nTo Garnish: Chopped fresh coriander leaves\nTo Garnish: 2 green chilies, slit lengthwise\nInstructions\nHeat 2 tbsp. of the cooking oil in a deep pan and when hot, add the onions. Fry till slightly golden. Turn off the fire. Use a slotted spoon to remove the onions from the pan and put them in a food processor. Grind the onions, tomatoes, and green chilies into a smooth paste. Try not to add water while grinding, if possible.\nHeat the remaining oil in the same pan and add the paste you just made. Fry for 2 to 3 minutes.\nAdd the ginger and garlic pastes, all the dry spices (coriander powder, cumin powder, garam masala powder, turmeric powder, and red chili powder) then mix and fry till the oil begins to separate from the masala (onion-tomato-spice mix).\nAdd 2 cups of warm water to this masala and bring it to a boil on a medium flame.\nIf adding potatoes to the curry, add them now and cook till half done.\nHalf slit the boiled eggs vertically and add them gently to the gravy. Simmer the flame and cook for 10 minutes or till the gravy has thickened or reduced to about 3/4 of the original quantity (before you added the water). If you have added potatoes they should ideally be cooked by now.\nTurn off the fire and garnish with chopped coriander leaves and the slit green chilies (if using). Serve hot with plain boiled rice and a vegetable side dish.\nHope you like both the recipes. I would love to hear your comments and remember to upvote.\nUntil Then - Happy Cooking"], "topic_list": ["Indian Recipes", "Cooking Eggs", "Curries", "Eggs (food)", "Indian Cuisine and Food", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Indian Ethnicity and People", "Food", "India", "Survey Question"], "view_list": [165], "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Snehasis Ganguly", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What are your favorite Indian style egg curry recipes?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "968", "name_list": ["Amal Nusrat"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020"]}, "501": {"ans_list": ["Tomatoes! A big old pot filled with boiling water, at a roll. Top heat.\nWith salt added.\nIgnore the bullshit about it having to be as salty as seawater. Uugghhh!!!\nI watched an online recipe where the presenter literally put a dessert bowl of salt into the water. WTF!!!\nJust do it to taste. No more than a heaped teaspoon. Do not go mad on the salt. You\u2019ll be adding sauce later which, if you\u2019ve done your job right, will be packing the flavour.\nAnother trick with spaghetti, when adding to the pot, is to (how to describe this?) create a column in the middle of the pot, give a slight twist and let go, allowing the uncooked strands to create a coronet of spaghetti around the rim. Then, with wooden spoon, you push down the rapidly softening proud ends till the whole lot is immersed. Give it a stir at this point.\nDoes that make sense? I\u2019m not sure myself.\nNine minutes later (approximately) the results are fit to be tossed in butter, sprinkled with Parmesan and eaten straight, or doused in sauce/dressing/topping of your choice.\nNever overcook it. If you leave it in the water it was cooked in, even if you take it off the heat, the process continues. Just drain your pasta before introducing it to the sauce.\nIt\u2019s crucial to taste as you go along. That\u2019s what separates the cooks from the recipe followers. Always trust your own instincts and tastebuds.\nIt\u2019s a very fine line between perfectly al-dente and inedible, but also one broad enough to not be too anxious about.", "You don't, plain and simple. You are supposed to time your pasta cooking exactly so that it is perfectly al dente the very moment you are ready to serve it. Suppose meal time is at 1 pm, and you are serving penne with a 12 minutes cooking time. You drop the penne exactly at 12:50, so that you can drain them at 1:01 (by then everyone is supposed to be at the table), completing the dish by sauteing the pasta in the sauce with a splash of water, so that it is ready to serve at 1:02. That is how it is done.", "I\u2019ve asked a similar question here before and the suggestion was to drain and mix with the sauce, something I didn\u2019t want to do. I recently found a solution (for me anyway), to the problem.\nOn a box of Dreamfields spaghetti were the ridiculous instructions to rinse the cooked pasta in cold water and drain. I tried that; the drained pasta did not stick together; the pasta did not get mushy; I\u2019ve done that since.\nNow, is that specific to Dreamfields pasta? I doubt it but I don\u2019t know. There is plenty of heat in the sauce for the cold pasta, at least for spaghetti at our house.\nI know. I know. All my Italian friends are rolling in their graves (and some aren\u2019t dead yet), but this technique solves a few problems for me and I like it. So there!", "Put some drops of olive oil or any cooking oil n pass them through fresh water ,firstly in order to avoid sticking \u2026n then few drops of oil \u2026.", "All the previous answers plus stir in about a table spoon of olive oil into the pot and stir frequently until a steady rolling boil. Once cooked keep stirring occasionally or just add in a little sauce until your ready to pour it on", "Always have a pot of boiling water on d range,start making ur sauce when ur about to finish d sauce blanch d pasta al a danti add it to d sauce.second opt put some oil in d boiling water,third opt after branching run under ice water to remove d excess starch add a table spoon of oil.", "Simple, after draining the pasta, return to the pot and add a tiny amount of oil and toss with a pasta fork. Its amazing how even the smallest amount of oil seems to coat all the pasta", "You should have a little more water than you need because you are not considering the fact when you finish boiling the noodles have more surface area to let the water evaporate, that's why it lacks water and also lacks the slimyness and keeps sticking,\nYou may also add some oil in water before pouring the noodles that will help coverings the noodles and lessen the evaporation rate.", "Make sure the ratio of water to pasta is enough. You can have too little water but you really can\u2019t have too much.\nMake sure the water is really boiling before adding the pasta.\nBegin stirring the pasta as soon as it\u2019s all in the water. For spaghetti use a long handled fork, or long tongs\u2026 anything that will allow you to keep the strands separate as you stir. Then bring the water back to a boil. It will have subsided a bit once the pasta is in.\nOnce the water is back to a boil, let it alone for a while. One secret to pasta is to check it often. You can feel the pasta relaxing in a few minutes. (A metal utensil will actually allow you to feel it better in your hands than a wooden utensil will.)\nSample the pasta. As it gets closer to al dente, sample more frequently.\nMeanwhile, stir on occasion.\nWhen it is al dente, drain in a colander or sieve and do not rinse. Have already prepared a bowl with plenty of whatever sauce you are using and add the cooked pasta to the sauce and mix it, blending and coating the pasta. You will be using some of the starchy water to coat the pasta well.\nI bet you want to know what al dente is.", "What I do is drain it, and then add a very small amount of oil (maybe half a teaspoon per person, preferably extra virgin olive oil) and any other seasoning you may want to add, and then shake it to distribute evenly.\n(Many people add oil at the beginning- this seems to be a waste of oil and time, it doesn\u2019t stick to the spaghetti, nor does it significantly help avoid it boiling over.)", "add one spoon oil while boiling", "I add about a tablespoon of olive oil in the water before it boils before I add the noodles when they are done I drain the noodles into a strainer once drained I throw them back into the pot.
