It\u2019s best to be honest and transparent with a customer regarding food. To avoid this situation, I would find out before they dined about their eating preferences. It\u2019s important to find out if there are any restrictions and be sensitive as a chef about them. Happy customers equal better businesses.", "If I was cooking for a strict vegan or anybody else with special dietary requirements, I would make sure I accommodated those requirements to the best of my ability. I absolutely would NOT serve them something that they do not eat for whatever reason, and would certainly not trick them into eating something they do not eat. I might not share or even agree with their choices, but they are their choices to make. Besides, how do I know their dietary choices are simply voluntary, or if certain ingredients literally make them sick? For instance, I knew a man who had a lifelong dislike of noodles and most bread. Quite late in life he had some kind of test done and discovered he had a gluten intolerance that stopped short of celiac disease, but still left him uncomfortable after eating foods with gluten. His preference turned out to be based on physiology.\nIf a person on a strict diet were just one of a group of people I was feeding, I would make sure there was something substantial they could eat. It's really not that complicated, although it could get complicated if a bunch of guests all had their own individual requirements. Even so, I would do my best to make sure I fixed enough variety that everybody could eat their fill. In fact, I am fortunate to have two kitchen spaces, so with some careful thought and cleaning I would imagine I could even accommodate someone with celiac disease.\nSay, perhaps, I was planning to serve tandoori chicken (which spends several hours in a yogurt-based marinade). Alongside it I might serve rice and a lentil curry that contains vegetables. I like mine with a yogurt-and-cucumber condiment for coolness, but a person could leave that off. a bread made without dairy or egg and some kind of salad with a dressing that didn't include dairy or egg could round out the meal. Meat-eaters, ovo-lacto vegetarians, and vegans alike will be able to leave the table satisfied, I don't have to make a special dish for the vegan that would make them feel singled out, and nobody is tricked into eating what they cannot or prefer not to eat.\nIt really takes more effort to be unkind than to be kind.", "Speaking from a vegan perspective: Unless I made it myself and from scratch, I\u2019m always at risk for eating something that contains animal products. Being vegan in a non-vegan society means being prepared for breeches in one\u2019s dietary code (or whatever we choose to call it) and learning to balance a little vigilance without veering into paranoia. That said, I can count the number of times that I\u2019ve accidentally eaten animal products and then found out about in the last 30 years. I\u2019ve always appreciated someone telling me, \u201cHey, that\u2019s got [name of animal ingredient] in it\u201d while I was eating it so that I could stop. Sometimes this has happened after the facut because someone didn\u2019t know I was vegan, or someone didn\u2019t know what the dish contained, or they just didn\u2019t see me eating it. No one has ever \u201cpulled a fast one\u201d on me nor \u201cintentionally desecrated my beliefs\u201d via the food they serve. I provided her with decaf tea and coffee and at some point I began to feel bad for several days and she served me a glass of tea and I asked if it was decaf. She said no she had run out and had been giving me regular tea for a week. Lucky I had still been able to drive as even that becomes iffy after one glass of tea or coffee. I don\u2019t think I ever forgave her for that. I\u2019m the same way with gluten. It gives me an upset stomach and several days sitting on the toilet. I wouldn\u2019t feel any difference to someone who cooked something for me that had gluten and knew I reacted badly to it. Either you are vegan, or you are not. A strict vegetarian is a vegan. A vegan that makes exceptions is plant-based.\nOther than that, you seem to assume vegans are vegans because they \u201cdon\u2019t like\u201d animal products. No. Vegans are vegans because they don\u2019t want to cause harm to or exploitation of animals. While many vegans do end up thinking animal products are disgusting and not food, that is not the driving force and plenty of vegans never think that. Egg is often used as a binder or emulsifier and cannot be detected in many instances, hence the majority of meat eaters cannot tell if a cake is vegan (when it is well-made).\nSo if you intentionally serve a vegan something with eggs in, and they like it, you\u2019ve proved nothing, and if you tell them afterwards, you\u2019ll just make them feel sick and no longer consider you a friend. You\u2019ll also teach them a lesson in not trusting people and make them more likely to not eat anyone else\u2019s food in future. You also never know if someone really liked a dish you prepared or if they are just being polite, so keep that in mind. If you don\u2019t tell them but tell your mutual friends, and they all start doing it, you are just all many levels of stupid and disrespectful and the only thing you will prove is that. Additionally, some vegans end up reacting to food they have not eaten for an extended period, in which case you\u2019d be poisoning them.\nIf a person is not allergic and not avoiding certain foods on moral or religious grounds, it may be justified to serve them food they think they don\u2019t like to remove their mental block, but this should be done with caution as what makes sense to you may not make sense to another person. For example, someone might like curry and pineapple, but still feel literally sick if there\u2019s pineapple in curry because they can\u2019t stand the mixture of sweet and savoury. So, it\u2019s a complicated matter and unless you know someone extremely well, to be avoided with the possible exception of someone saying they don\u2019t like x because it doesn\u2019t contain y when the difference is non-existent or negligible, and they have not tried it.\nSo to sum up, veganism has nothing to do with \u201cnot liking\u201d something, so force-feeding a vegan said ingredients just makes you an idiot. On the other hand, not telling a person x ingredient is in or not in something in order to encourage them to try it, when you know for certain they are not allergic or opposed to said ingredient on moral grounds and you are both well-meaning and have compelling reasons to assume they would actually like it, may be acceptable in some situations.", "Gods, no, what kind of asshole would do that?", "No, please be further kind to that person. For a percentage of people with such sensitivity, they can die of anaphylactic shock within ten minutes.\nMany people have religious dietary beliefs. For some, eating certain foods is not only offensive and revealing, but is a cardinal sin which they believe can destroy their soul and condemn them to eternal punishment. Some people can be banished from their families, friends, and places of worship for violating dietary laws \u2014 consciously or by trickery. For others, violating dietary laws is an emotional shock which threatens their stability, and which can destroy their sense of self-worth.\nDeliberately making someone violate their dietary practices or rules or laws is one of the most cruel and thoughtless acts you could do. It is absolutely despicable. It is not cute or funny or clever in any way. Not only will it create a reaction similar to that of having been raped, you might cause permanent emotional damage or you might well kill your victim. Boiling is the point at which the pressure of steam of hot liquid. e.g. water, equals the pressure of the environment and the bubbles of foam appers inside the liquid. At that moment the temperature of a pure liquid usually stops rising, as the production of steam uses heat as fast as it is supplied to the liquid. However any mixtures or bodies containing water, as most of the foods, may be heated to the higher temperatures that the boiling point of water.\nUnder lower pressure the boiling point is lower, under higher pressure it is higher. That\u2019s why it is sometimes difficult to cook at the high altitudes, and why cooking in a pressure cooker is faster that in a normal pot.\nFood may be cooked in the various temperature, lower, even, or higher than 100\u00b0C. The chemistry and physics of cooking various foods embrace many processes, not necessarilly conected with the evaporating of water.\nIn the lower temperatures cooking processes may last longer and not all of them may properly or at all.", "While some of your details are incorrect, your thinking is absolutely correct. What you are describing is well known to any barbecue pitmaster. It even has a name \u201cthe stall\u201d. When water evaporates, it takes a good deal of heat away with it. During low temperature cooking around 105 degrees C, evaporative cooling will keep meat at a temperature significantly below the ambient cooking temp. Large pieces of meat with large surface areas for evaporation like brisket can stay stuck at the stall for hours. Eventually as the water evaporates and leaves the meat the rate of cooling slows down and the temperature will begin to rise again.\nWhat Is The Barbecue Stall, How Does It Help Create \"Bark,\" And How Do I Beat The Stall?", "It\u2019s tempting to think that if you are patient you could bake food at a lower temperature for a longer time and get the same result. The reason this is not true in practice is that there are OTHER processes going on when you cook in an oven besides just \u201cgetting hot\u201d.\nFor one, water is evaporating from the food (even at temperatures well below 100C), and the longer it cooks, the more water is lost. That is, if you heat a food slowly you will lose more water than if you heat it quickly. Sometimes this is a good thing. For example beef jerky is made in an oven set well below the boiling point because the goal is to reduce moisture.\nBut for other foods, losing more water is a bad thing. For example, a lasagna would likely get very dry cooked long and slow even if you covered it. And a chicken breast would be even worse.\nIn addition, some recipes require that the outside of the food become much hotter than the inside. For example, consider an apple pie. Cooked at 110C the top crust of an apple pie would not brown, and instead would be mushy and soggy as the vapors from the gradually cooking interior saturated it.\nIn summary, if you want the food in your oven to turn out right, you need to cook it at the right temperature.", "Water evaporates below 100 C. Just think of what happens if you leave water in a dish on your counter. Over the course of a couple of days, that water will disappear because it has evaporated into the air.\nWhat happens at 100 C is water reaches its boiling point (at standard pressure\u2026for you technically correct folks). Below 100C, as heat entering the water body from a hot oven, for instance, both raises the temperature and evaporates some of the water. At 100C all heat that goes into the water is used to evaporate the water.\nIm sorry to say that your last statement is gobbledegook to me. I\u2019ll try to interpret it and provide an explanation based on my interpretation.\nI think you are asking if an oven at 200C will cook as fast as an oven at 300C, because the food is limited to 100C by the boiling point of water. If that is your question, the answer is again \u201cno\u201d. Here\u2019s why.\nThe rate of heat moving between two bodies is determined to a large part by the temperature difference between them. In engineering we call it the \u201cdelta T\u201d, which is the temperature of item 2 minus the temperature of item 1, or T2-T1. In the example i gave, the delta T of the 200C oven is half that of the 300C oven. The food should cook approximately faster as heat enters the 100C item twice as fast. That\u2019s why the chicken you roast at 400F looks different and cooks faster than the chicken you bake at 350F.\nAs an example if you grab a piece of metal that was in boiling water, you\u2019ll get a bit of a scald and maybe a bit of a sunburn type of burn (your skin is damaged in a couple of seconds by exposure to 60C, but it\u2019s the proteins and fats, not the water). If you put that same piece of metal in a 300 C oven and grab it you\u2019ll get a nasty burn. It might not even flake off like a sunburn, but instead sear your hand like the meat it is. Please don\u2019t do either!", "No! water evaporates at at any temperature above -273 degrees Celsius. , What happens is that a molecule escapes the surface and floats away. This reduces the temperature of the remaining water a little. Then if a water molecule falls into the surface, it bonds, and increases the temperature a little. The probability of these events happening depends on the temperature ,as at higher temperatures , more molecules can break away. At 100 degrees Celsius, the amount of water vapour in the space above the surface, can equal atmospheric pressure and boiling takes place. .. bubbles of vapour firm anywhere in the water column , not only at the surface can force their way out. If the water is in an enclosed space, and the temperature is increased, the vapour pressure can easily exceed atmospheric pressure", "One note water evaporated under 100 degrees Celsius too (how would anything get dry otherwise). Capellini\nCapellini, or more commonly known as angel hair pasta, is one of the thinnest types of pasta with a diameter ranging between 0.85 and 0.92 millimeters.\n2. Fettuccine\nFlat, ribbon-like shape of fettuccine makes it a sturdy pasta that can hold up to a variety of sauces. It\u2019s best known; however, for the popular dish fettuccine alfredo.\n3.Farfalle\nThe fun shape of this pasta earned it its nickname \u201cbow tie pasta.\u201d Farfalle is a versatile pasta shape that can be used in most recipes that call for a short pasta. It pairs particularly well with meat and vegetable dishes.\n4.Fusilli\nFusilli gives any dish an unexpected twist with its spiral shape. These short noodles pair well with nearly any sauce, but they also make great summer pasta salads that you can bring on a picnic or to the neighborhood potluck.\n5. Linguine\nLong, thin, flat linguine noodles fall somewhere between the thickness of fettuccine and spaghetti. Linguine is best known for its ability to compliment clam-based sauces and other seafood dishes.\n6.Macaroni\nEveryone knows this kid-favorite pasta. Whether it\u2019s homemade or from a box, macaroni and cheese is a crowd-pleaser. The tube-shape of macaroni pasta is perfect for cream sauces or anything with melty cheese.\n7. Orecchiette\nOrecchiette translates to \u201clittle ears\u201d because the pasta\u2019s concave shape resembles an ear. The indent picks up vegetables or whatever else it\u2019s paired with, making it a great carrier of stronger flavors.\n8.Pappardelle\nPappardelle noodles are similar to fettuccine in that they\u2019re flat, but pappardelle is wider than fettuccine.\n9.Penne\nPenne is a classic pasta type and pantry staple. The short, tube-shape and hollow center makes it suitable for all sorts of sauces and pairings, from chunky meat sauces to delicate creams.\n10. Speghetti\nSpaghetti is one of the most, if not the most, well-known types of pasta.\nThanks\nCourtesy Google", "Each pasta is made in different shapes &different methods ,ingredients they all have a different texture &taste", "There are many shapes of pasta. Around 600 long, small and curled in different designs. Ever there are endless number of stuff pastas.\nChefs use different shapes and sizes of pasta for different purposes because certain shapes hold different sauces better than others. Thin pasta, such as angel hair works better with thin oil-based sauce, while thicker sauces work better with thicker, heavier pastas.", "Whilst there may be pasta shapes designed to be decorative rather than functional most pasta shapes serve a clear purpose. Spaghetti, for example, holds a pesto or a finely ground beef sauce very well, whereas if you used a thicker pasta noodle for something like pesto or just a simple olive oil and garlic dressing there would be too much pasta per forkful to flavoring. Yet a thick tagliatelle would be very suited to a game pasta sauce made with chunks of rabbit or hare. Chunky vegetable sauces work very well with large pasta shells, as the shells catch the vegetable pieces in the sauce, making it easier to eat. Tubular pasta works very well with creamy sauces (such as macaroni and cheese) because it is very satisfying to bite into the tube and feel the sauce releases within. CASE CLOSED.", "Patience and quality cookware.\nThe chief disadvantages of electric compared to gas are slow response to changes in intensity and poor return, meaning that when you add food to a hot pan it returns more slowly to cooking temp than gas would.\nBoth of these weaknesses are avoided or mitigated by thinking ahead, being patient, and using heavy cookware.\nLearn through experience which settings are best for different tasks and stick to them. This has led to the reduction of fat in the meat, and the lightening of the meat to the point where today it is considered, \u201cthe other white meat.\u201d because there is no fat the meat tends to be very lean and dry. The ham of a pig is pink due to a combination of factors: the way it is cooked, and the fat content. Also, most hams are cured (which usually involves the soaking or injection of a brine) and then smoked before being sold to consumers, which helps to preserve the color of the meat. According to Huff Post and their story on Why Is Ham Pink?\nit, \u201c\u2026is the presence of sodium nitrite\n(or less commonly sodium nitrate). It inhibits bacterial growth (the extremely dangerous kind that can cause botulism), ensuring the meat is safe to eat, and also causes the meat to retain a pinkish color similar to its raw state. They are black, like cast iron and heavy(heat retention), and relatively bulletproof, and lastly , slightly expensive. The thing is though, the purchase of cookware, becomes a cost accounting issue. Most restaurants are using inexpensive aluminum pans, of whatever brand(s), they are all the same more or less. These pans are good for some things but, they warp over time from thermal shock. This loosens the rivets and eventually the pans are ruined. The rolled steel pans have the handle welded on and I have never seen one come loose and the steel\u2019s thermal qualities are such that the temperatures to warp them is rarely, with difficulty, and should never be achieved in a kitchen (you will burn everything in pans this hot).\nAs far as pots go, heavy bottomed aluminum or an aluminum alloy are pretty much the standard. They don\u2019t experience the repeated shock of deglazing that saute pans do and the heavy bottoms don\u2019t warp as easily. The price of anything else is prohibitive when evaluated for cost/benefit."], "topic_list": ["Pots", "Cookware", "Professional Chefs", "Kitchen Utensils and Accessories", "Chefs", "Kitchens", "Restaurant Business", "Restaurants", "Cooking"], "view_list": [111], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Hamid Salehi", "upvote_list": [4], "question_title": "What brand/type of pots and pans do professional chefs and high-end restaurants use in their kitchen?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "1,324", "name_list": ["Richard Croft"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"]}, "393": {"ans_list": ["As soon as you show up!"], "topic_list": ["Happy Hours", "Grills", "Nightlife", "Bars", "Time (physics)", "Restaurants", "Cooking"], "view_list": [29], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Cozma Dan Claudiu", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "What time is happy hour at the Bonefish Grill?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "337", "name_list": ["John P. Scallan"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"]}, "344": {"ans_list": ["Use the fat in the pan juices & flour to make a roux. The longer you cook the flour in the roux, the darker the gravy. If the flour is not cooked enough your gravy will taste like paste. Gradually add liquid to the roux stirring constantly until you have the desired consistency for the gravy. The liquid can be stock, water, cream or milk. The secret to good gravy is the roux. If your pan juices have a lot of fat you can skim some off but leave the liquid from the meat there. Season your gravy once it is done because the pan juices can have a lot of salt from the roast and you don\u2019t want your gravy to be too salty.\nI learned to make a roux when I was about six years old, standing on a stool at the stove with my Grammy. It is both an art and a science. Every meat my grandma cooked had gravy and boy was it good. Times change and people are more health-conscious and unfortunately gravy isn\u2019t particularly healthy for you. I still make gravy for holiday meals. It is a natural cross done with selective breeding. It has a natural gene that gives it a huge appetite. Heritage chickens can be butchered at four to six months and still be tender.", "This answer assumes the reader is OK with killing animals for food.\nA nice age to eat a chicken would be about three or four months old. Chickens can live for between 5-10 years naturally and typically you want to eat the chicken before it starts to lay, usually around six months or so.\nAt about 14 weeks a traditional breed of chicken would be young enough to still be tender, while big enough to be worth killing to eat.\nIt depends on what the chickens job is though.\nIf it's a backyard chicken it'll lay eggs for a couple of years and plenty of people eat them after this long. Birds this old can be a bit tough but still perfectly Edible as long as they are cooked in the right way.\nYour standard broiler bird In the supermarket, however, has been genetically engineered to grow extremely fast. They are crammed full of high-calory feed to aid in their growth, as well as given almost round-the-clock light to simulate summer. These birds are typically slaughtered at around six weeks old.\nI used to work for a very large poultry-breeding company. Not a nice industry.\nHappy, healthy birds allowed to mature naturally are better for the animal and taste a thousand times better too."], "topic_list": ["Butchers", "Butchering", "Chickens", "Chicken (food)", "Cooking"], "view_list": [18, 39], "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Smith Gilliam", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "How old should a chicken be to butcher?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "789", "name_list": ["Abby Stein", "Liam Mclachlan"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"]}, "271": {"ans_list": ["The point of deglazing a pan is to lift the flavourful bits (sooks) stuck to the pan. If you want to simply clean the pan and waste that flavour, wash with soap and water.", "Please don't try it.\nThis is my understanding \u201cAcetic acid can be a hazardous chemical if not used in a safe and appropriate manner. This liquid is highly corrosive to the skin and eyes and, because of this, must be handled with extreme care. Acetic acid can also be damaging to the internal organs if ingested or in the case of vapor inhalation.\u201d\nIt doesn't smell too appetising, so I doubt it would taste nice.\nIf no vinegar, wine or water or maybe lemon juice and water can all deglaze your pan, they are safe and taste nice.\nIf your pan has a little residue, you could try a descaler on it (baking soda and lemon juice?) and rinse carefully afterwards but as part of the cleaning process i.e. not when food is in the pan.", "Assuming you mean some form of vinegar, then yes.
